values:
---***--
Continued from Chapter 15 Part 1: In Conjunction
---***---


They sat in complete silence, forehead to forehead. And Severus could feel his cheeks burning with anger all over again, but it was too late. She knew. Where they were supposed to go from here, he had no clue.

He was beyond shocked when she moved forward, hands moving swiftly from his jaw to somewhere behind his back. He was pulled into an embrace he had no idea how to quantify or respond to…except to exhale deeply and bury his face in her neck. She embraced him now the way she had when they were fourteen, when she had seen a horrible memory of his father’s worst fit to date. Tobias had locked himself in the coal bunker as penance for backhanding a twelve year old Severus after a burst of temperamental magic. That she was trying now to protect or at least comfort him after seeing into his memory made him feel safe, rather than embarrassed …

“I lost control,” she said simply, releasing him and turning toward her teacup.

Severus turned sharply to see Lourdes staring rather apathetically into her teacup, tracing the rim with a finger.

“Come again?”

“I couldn’t take that much life and not waste it. I lost control. That’s what he meant.” She stopped short at the sudden disturbance in the atmosphere. Something small and light darted in through the window and for a split second Severus thought it was a moth, but it quickly erupted into a silver flash shaped like a phoenix.

Severus was tempted to go straight through the Floo to Albus’ office and tell him to stay put until things were managed, but that would only make it painfully obvious that something had gone wrong. There wouldn’t have been time for that anyway because the instant the image of the phoenix faded from his retinas, Severus heard a knock at the front door. Lourdes frowned a bit and seemed confused, looking down at her mostly bare legs and back up at him as if wondering whether or not to bother.

“There’s a dressing gown in the second wardrobe,” he muttered, glad for any excuse to buy time alone with Albus.

When Lourdes vanished up the stairs, Severus slammed the bookcase behind her and dimmed the lights in the main room to barely a glow, just in case. Wand at the ready, he eased the door open just a crack and stared out suspiciously.

“Good evening, Severus.” Albus’ tone was cool and firm, but his expression indicated that he was in no mood to tolerate any rebellion.

Severus stepped back to let him in, and gestured to the sofa. “Tea?”

“Yes, please,” Albus said patiently, passing Severus to cross into the kitchen directly and pulling up a chair. “Where is she?”

The creaking of floorboards above gave away her position, and he counted her light footsteps down the stairs before Lourdes finally wandered into the kitchen, back in her robes, clutching a little round tin.

“Albus,” she said mildly before snapping up the teapot and padding over to the stove. Lourdes proceeded to bang around the cabinets, constructing a makeshift samovar out of the kettle and a smaller iron teapot before demanding that someone transfigure a bergamot for her, which she grated violently into the tea leaves she’d brought down with her. The Tngri was summoned, cavorting around the teapot in the confines of the stove burner as if it were some delightful game to heat water.

“Would you care to fill me in on the events of this evening?” Albus said, raising his voice above the sound of Lourdes slamming the tea strainer against the sink with unnecessary force.

Severus hesitated a moment, but saw no benefit in trying to delay the inevitable. “Certainly, but I’m still not entirely clear on what happened myself. We were called, not so much we as her, and myself as the necessary transportation. Something to do with Avery, and Lourdes was brought in to…” Severus stopped and glared at his nearly empty teacup, “punish him.”

“I see. Who was present?”

“Rookwood,” Severus muttered, and paused. Albus’ eyes lit up instantly, he’d been present at Rookwood’s trial for treason against the Ministry and the Department of Mysteries.

“Though, Rookwood wouldn’t say anything to me about what had gone on before we got there. Coming out of Azkaban I’d say he doesn’t trust me as far as he could throw me. Avery was there, of course. I didn’t see anyone else but I didn’t get to look. Lourdes was in there alone.”

There was a tense lull in the conversation, and Albus took the opportunity to give him a very harsh look. Severus’ stomach twisted as though he’d just been caught actively trying to get rid of Lourdes and felt a light sheen of sweat pop out over his forehead. He couldn’t stop his eyes from darting abruptly over in her direction for a fraction of a second and he caught sight of her, lip clamped firmly between her teeth as she glared at the both of them..

“I wasn’t allowed in, I didn’t have a choice,” he said quickly. “But something happened, the Dark Lord wouldn’t say what, though…” Severus faltered, pressing his lips together and tapping his fingers against the table, wishing he didn’t have to say what he was about to. “Though, he wished to impress upon us the utmost importance of Lourdes remaining in control of her magic at all times, and he proceeded to make a visceral impact on her.”

“She was tortured, you mean.” Albus followed that statement by giving Severus what he supposed was meant to be a very significant look, but what the significance was Severus couldn’t be sure. Though, Severus thought dizzily, it felt suspiciously as though Albus was placing blame…

“Pleased to remind you both that I’m in the room,” Lourdes snapped, as she pulled the jumble of pots off the range.

“Yes.” Severus felt a fresh surge of anger well up in the back of his throat when he made eye contact with Albus. How dare Albus implicate him, Lourdes wouldn’t have to BE here, doing this if Albus hadn’t asked her… This was his fault.

“Well, I appreciate that you’ve done your best to care for her considering the situation, and I can’t help but say I’m pleased that you two are working together. But, tell me, Severus, why is it that you didn’t report back immediately, considering the situation?”

This question was sufficiently interesting to pique Lourdes’ interest as well. Severus narrowed his eyes and said coolly, “I know the difficulty involved in giving a report immediately after a trying experience. I merely wished to provide Lourdes with time to collect herself without the stress associated with being in my quarters under summon.”

Lourdes chose to punctuate that statement by slamming the teapot on the table before taking her chair. In surprisingly good humor, Albus proceeded to pour cups of very strong tea all around.

“Severus doesn’t know what happened to incite my… punishment, but I do. There wasn’t anything he could have done to stop it,” Lourdes said coolly, turning her lip up at Albus. “But I have some information you may be interested in, Albus. Rather valuable information unique to my condition.”

“Then I’m eager to hear it.” Considering her attitude, and Severus’ suspicious behavior, Albus was handling the whole affair with remarkable composure, as though he was still in perfect control of a situation that seemed too fractured to see as a whole.

“My information comes at a price. Still interested?”

“It’s not a habit of mine to pay for information Lourdes, you know that.”

“I’m not bargaining for cash, my bank account isn’t suffering while I’m living for free and you know it. I’m asking for something much more valuable in return for some information that may be absolutely critical. The price is a back door out of this, for me and for Severus, if things go pear shaped. Give me a five day reprieve, the Dark Lord won’t be calling me in the next few days. Let me go to Turkey; I have a contact there who owes me a favor and is extremely discrete. He’ll have to be, and I’ll be able to seal him on his word. In return, you get my information and an additional contact within the Turkish government and I’ll be able to pick up my books and arrange a safety net.”

For a moment the kitchen was dead silent as Albus looked politely contemplative, and Lourdes fixed him with an icy, smug smile. Severus watched the whole exchange feeling vaguely suspicious as to why Lourdes was bargaining on his behalf as well - it made him a little uncomfortable.

“Think about it, Albus. You’ve got a very valuable informant in Severus, but he’s in your debt. I’m a different story. I don’t owe you anything after the disposal of those two Death Eaters in Bulgaria. I think this time…you owe me,” Lourdes said, in that ‘isn’t this reasonable?’ tone she must have honed while striking deals with convicts. Though in Severus’ experience trying to strong arm Albus into doing anything never ended well…

Very calmly, Albus had a slow sip of his tea and smiled mildly before he nodded. “An agreeable bargain, Lourdes. Shall we shake hands or would you prefer a signature?” When he mentioned signature, he raised an eyebrow suspiciously and Lourdes smirked.

“Not to worry, never bothered to sign family into anything, and you’re as good as family,” she said, extending a hand to meet Albus’. There was an odd frisson of energy the moment their hands clasped and the deal was apparently sealed.

“He had me take 80 out of 90 years on Avery, but I can’t hold 80 years in one transfer without losing some of it. But, I was afraid he’d find out I shortchanged him, so I panicked and started the transfer before he was ready. And I slipped,” she said quietly. “Lost control for a moment, and…slipped.”

“And what did you discover?” Albus asked.

“It’s more of what I didn’t see.” Lourdes looked up and away for a moment as though she couldn’t quite figure out how to phrase what she wanted to say. “Normally, when I see life, it’s like…string. Spent years are already formed and readable, tied in to memories and other mental structures I can’t directly access as an Evocator. But the potential years are…well they look like they’re wound around their soul…sort of. Everything is bright inside, and everything is intact.”

“But I’m rambling, let’s begin at the beginning. We live in an amoral universe, as much as we, and you, would like to believe otherwise…Albus.” Lourdes paused to give him a very stern look. “But it’s a universe which perpetually seeks balance. For every destructive action there is a consequence: steal unicorn blood to prolong your life and you inherit a degenerative curse, distort the natural state of your soul and you damage yourself irreparably. What I saw in the Dark Lord when I slipped wasn’t like anything I’ve ever experienced. Do you remember when you had us clean out that mirror?”

“I do,” Albus said, nodding slowly as he wore a look of deep concentration. His eyebrows had quirked up the littlest bit, which told Severus that Albus was far more interested in this than he was letting on.

“Well, I found what I now know to be part of him in someone else, that Quirrell person, so I know that the Dark Lord is in sorrier shape than anything I’ve ever seen. His soul is actively disintegrating, even though the body change got rid of the curse he would have inherited from drinking unicorn’s blood. And that loss of soul has made room for more force, more magic but it damages the thing that makes him human – it degrades the quality of his connection to reality. Now, the Bran’s Cauldron spell you said he used to build his current body only gives what they call ‘the breath of bones,’ that is to say cobbled, artificial life like a homunculus or a golem. He wouldn’t get more than 10 years out of the components in the spell so he’d need new life for the new body, or risk acquiring a new body after this one runs out. But changing bodies every ten years? That seemed so improbable and it’s more than a little inconvenient.

“But I was making those calculations around the idea that he had an entire soul to support. But he doesn’t, not even close; I think he needs less life because he’s got less to support, and I think he planned on that before he used the Bran’s Cauldron spell. There’s only a scrap of a soul in there, Albus, and it’s not scraps from a Dementor job. I haven’t seen anything like it; and to be honest I’m still having trouble wrapping my mind around it. But he felt me in there, touching whatever soul was left over, and that’s why he went after me. The only good news is he thinks I’m too stupid to put it all together and figure out that he’s definitely fragmented. I can’t say if its Horcruxes, though, you’re only supposed to be able to split it once if you can split it at all, and even after 100 body changes and seven lifetimes of evil, half a soul shouldn’t be decomposed that badly. So…it probably raises more questions than it actually answers,” Lourdes sighed.

It was very quiet for a few moments while Albus digested all that and finally nodded as though satisfied.

“No, actually… I believe this gives me quite a bit to go on, Lourdes.”

“I know it would be…easier if I knew what I was looking at or some signpost to look for, but its completely alien territory even for me. I wasn’t really looking for it, but I don’t think he’ll have much of a connection to concientia either, he’s more non-being than being at this point. He’s got magic and no law, that makes him far more dangerous than any demon…”

“And how is next week? I can arrange travel for you on Monday. Though, I would caution you as to how visible you are. We don’t yet know if the Death Eaters have plants in Turkey as well.”

“Sounds perfect,” Lourdes said wearily. “Trust me, nobody will notice. Nobody that’ll talk, anyway.”

Severus felt his wits slowly coming back to him; the entire exchange had come as more than a bit of a shock, and his brain was still chewing on the concept of the Dark Lord having a split soul. It was right about then that he realized he couldn’t quite feel his face, and his mouth was hanging open. At a loss for words, he simply slouched back into his chair and sat for a moment as Lourdes and Albus solemnly discussed the niggling details of her travel. There was something off about the way Lourdes was bargaining, and there was definitely an issue they were both skirting...

Before he knew it, Albus was hauling himself out of the chair, shoulders sagging ever so slightly under the weight of this new information before he turned crisply to address Severus.

“I do appreciate the delicate nature of your situation, Severus. I only ask that next time you alert me if you should encounter some extenuating circumstances and need time to recuperate, so that I’m not forced to send signals through your old neighborhood.” Albus looked grim and tired as he said that, but there wasn’t a hint of condescension or a sign that there might be trouble for the two of them to be discussed later, so Severus took that as his cue to relax even further and simply let the silence wash over him as Albus disappeared from the house with a pop and left him alone with Lourdes.

“My head hurts,” she muttered, squeezing her eyes shut and clamping her hand over them. “Would you mind dimming the light a bit?”
Severus complied listlessly, and faced another long stretch of silence as he tried to contemplate what on earth he could possibly do next. It couldn’t have been more than maybe, three hours ago that he’d been sitting across from her at the tea table at Hogwarts. They’d been fighting, but not fighting, something about biding their time instead of active pursuit.

It seemed almost ridiculous to have ever had such a conversation with anyone given what had just happened. Even more ridiculous when he considered it was Lourdes he was dealing with. And even though he felt like he’d catalogued every gesture and quirk, every expression and mood, he was struck by the fact that he knew…almost nothing about her.

He turned his head a bit, and felt his face fall into an expression of cautious incredulity; who the hell was she? Severus knew the face, every inch, but he was horribly aware that beneath the rut-scarring on her cheeks, the tattoos, and her superstitious hairstyle, Lourdes kept ages of secrets, and some bizarre reservoir of magic he couldn’t ever hope to touch.

And now…she knew. She knew his worst moment, and she sat there as though nothing had happened, nothing had changed.
Everything had changed in the most ridiculously short span of time. It made him dizzy, it made him want to lie down and have a sleep, to see if when he woke up it was all just a dream. The last time he’d felt like this, he’d sealed his deal with Albus, turned his back on the Dark Lord and put his life in danger indefinitely…

Did she represent the same amount of risk?

No.

No, she’d just offered to include him in her escape route when she was bargaining with Albus, hadn’t she?

“How are you going to do it?” Severus asked, feeling his eyes narrow and his brows contract into a suspicious expression.

“Do what?”

“Open up this back door. You can’t assure whoever it is you’re trying to rope into this won’t turn on you?”

“Someone owes me a lost career, and three years of my life. I’ve been saving this favor for something big, but I’m not above a binding contract. In fact, I think I’ll do it to keep my hand in,” Lourdes said, with a bitter edge to her voice as she freshened up her tea.

“Why include me?” He pushed, leaning in towards her and feeling more than a little superstitious. She wasn’t usually in the mood for charity.

“Because, now I know,” she said, staring blankly across the room at the wall of shelves packed with potions ingredients and cheap bottles of elf made wine he kept for unpleasant company.

“Know what?” he spat. There was a hot flash of anger in his stomach. Lourdes was being so damn cryptic, and she’d suddenly lapsed into single sentence, deadpan responses when she ought to be… paying attention or saying something. But the flash of anger was quickly doused by the sudden sound of rain on the roof and the pavement outside. It seemed that the storm he’d seen coming from the cliff top had finally crossed over land, and it brought with it the reminder of her pale, blank face staring out over the ocean.

“That you meant it.”
“I see,” Severus muttered, just to fill up the silence.

In fact, he didn’t really see, he didn’t have a clue where they were at the moment, aside from the fact that she was here in the house, in his private place. More than that, she was with him in the grey part of the world between people who thought in black and white. In the part where he was both separate from and oddly joined with both sides as a spy, someone of dubious loyalties, and someone who had made an irreparable mistake an age ago. When in the heat of his anger and ambition he’d made a permanent exile of himself.

But half a world away at a different time, so had she. There was still a gap between them, but it had nothing to do with the space between the chairs.

These thoughts brought with them a very clear recollection of something that had started to grow midway through sixth year, unbidden. An idea about Lourdes which he’d found strange and disturbing. He’d put forward his best effort into keep it malnourished and stowed as far back as he could manage. It had made him question who he thought he was, what he thought he wanted. He had begun to realize he might be attracted to Lourdes too, despite the fact that she was so strange, so like him. She had become a good thing too after so many years of Occlumency, Legilimency, plots and study sessions. So many years of loyalty, comfort and kindness even when he was at his worst…

But how could he have been drawn to both of them? They were polar opposites! There was nothing about Lourdes which made him feel the rapture and possible freedom from himself that Lily brought. Instead Lourdes made him feel more himself, which he was not sure he liked. But it had come to nothing, she had died and the only thing left was the first good thing - Lily…

But now Lily was dead and Lourdes was alive. Right here, right next to him.

His heartbeat sped up from a tranquil beat to an adrenaline charged pound and his cheeks seemed to heat up as a feeling of pressure built behind them when he thought of moving across that gap, of changing the habits of thirty odd years and putting himself in the very real danger of her. It was fine to watch from a distance, but once all of his excuses for never moving closer to her were removed, the only answer to why he hadn’t yet was fear.

And he didn’t much relish the notion of being afraid.

The slow, rhythmic tick of the wall clock and the rain on the roof was the only sound for an age. Lourdes swayed in her seat slightly, eyelids drooping from sheer exhaustion, and for an uncomfortable and oddly exciting moment Severus thought she was going to lean in towards him. But she simply leaned forward instead.

“What do we do now?”

“We wait, I suppose. On Albus, and your deal. This evening’s excursion was, aside from whatever it is you discovered, a dead end,” Severus replied glumly.

“I’m tired of waiting,” she muttered. Her face melted into a distressed looking frown as she hauled herself out of her chair, across the floor, and into the dark warren of hallways and staircases.

Severus knew exactly what she was tired of and could not quite escape the feeling that she wasn’t just moving across the house - she was widening the gap again. Fear turned his stomach upside down as he forced himself to walk toward the bookcase door and hesitated for a moment. Where would she go?

Outside…

_***_

Lourdes had hoped that the cold rain on the back porch would help kill the horrible feeling of searing heat across her cheeks and that fresh air might slow down the heavy pumping of her heart.

But she was only cold and soaking wet.

Dim light from distant street lamps glittered off the raindrops clinging to the hair hanging in front of her face before the water splashed down onto the backs of her hands.

Everything ached, everything hurt. There was a tight, strangling feeling in her throat, and a horrible tingling feeling in every limb and digit, but she wasn’t sure if it was from anger, or residual magic from the spells inflicted on her earlier.

Perhaps it was what she’d seen – all that obsession and twisting of Lily Evans into a surreal object of the most fervent devotion.

Lourdes had no way to understand, she’d never loved anything the way Severus did because she had been shown how. So many happy years with her family, so much mutual love and devotion from Aberforth had taught Lourdes what was nourishing, and what was not. In her gut, she knew that obsession with a woman who had cut all ties when she was only fifteen, whom he’d known as a girl but not as a woman, was a slow poison. But, how would he have learned the difference between nourishing and toxic? Who had ever really loved him? Who had he ever had to watch? Certainly no one in this house…

He must have known it was not healthy either, because instead of carrying this unrequited love like a battle standard for all to see, Severus hid it more thoroughly than any other secret. It represented a fatal flaw in his structure that made Lourdes feel she had to protect him simply because she might be the only other person who had seen its spread and depth, and that almost made her responsible.

But worst of all, Lourdes could not stop the images flashing insistently in her brain, snippets of this evening's punishment, memories of prison that smelled like rusting iron and blood, and the horrible niggling feeling that this could be the rest of her life. This dead end wallow in the worst, and blackest magic, permanently regarded as a convenient instrument of torture, yoked to a man who at any given moment could be poisoned by his own memory. She should have seen this coming, she thought, it had happened before at O.H.K. and she should have seen it coming the moment Albus told her he wanted her for a second spy.

Angrier by the moment, Lourdes let her head slip through her hands and rested it on her forearms, crossed between her knees so that the only thing she was able to see was the water dropping to make ripples on the little puddle of gathering water underneath her.

She hated every second she sat there, every second of dull ache in her chest, and time was so infuriatingly slow now. The very prospect of even another month of this life suddenly seemed like a thousand year sentence that would be agony every second she had to endure it, every second she fooled herself with the hopeful prospect of a way out, and it created a horrible, clawing panic in her chest.
It would be cold, it would be dark, and it looked like she would be alone.

Quite suddenly, the back garden gate looked like a very good idea. Run out that gate, go somewhere, anywhere, get away from this, leave the books, leave the things, leave even Aberforth, but get out alive. Get out now…

She stared, and stared, but could not seem to make her legs want to comply with the rest of her that was screaming to get out, and while she was absorbed in that internal debate.

The back door swung open and suddenly Severus was there in the dim porch light and the rain with her.

Oh, that was right. He was here too, wasn’t he?

“You’re soaking wet,” he muttered, with an expression somewhere between a frown and a sneer as he tossed a bath towel over her shoulders and eased into the little space next to her on the porch.

“Common side effect of exposure to rain,” she said, with a roll of her eyes as she turned a little to look him in the face. That familiar crease of concentration appeared between his eyebrows as he frowned.

“We used to be friends,” he said slowly.

‘Yeah, we did,” she sighed. There was no real tension between them now, she noticed. Just mutual exhaustion and, apparently, shared fear and hopelessness as well. Not a good place to be, but she was glad for the company. He looked so tired now that it was hard to believe this was the same nasty, sneering, occasionally decent Severus she’d been glaring at for all these months. And it certainly wasn’t the bitter, ambitious boy she’d learned Occlumency with.

No. That memory, that slide through his humiliation and raw anger and pain, had changed him permanently in her mind, despite her best effort to rouse some anger, or resentment towards him. He knew what it felt like to come to the edge where for even an instant you no longer felt like a human and after finding that feeling, everything changes.

“I, ah…” Severus stopped and glared again as if he disapproved of what he wanted to say, and Lourdes quirked an eyebrow up and gave him a rather sarcastic smile.

“Don’t get maudlin on me now.”

“Wouldn’t dream of it,” he said, a hint of amusement in his voice as he cocked an eyebrow in return, leaning back a bit as if to survey her better. “I wanted to thank you.”

Syzygy


 For what is a man profited, if he shall gain the whole world, and lose his own soul? Matthew 16:26
“Lumos.”The lone lamp in the living room burst with light, and months of dust puffed and swirled with the draft from the door which was quickly slammed shut and locked.  Being at the house on Spinner's End again was so familiar and comfortable that it gave him the strangest feeling of stepping into his own head.  The momenth he stepped over the threshold, everything outside seemed like a loud, alien fantasy, and that he felt he had to touch, or eat, or drink something from “his world” to ground him again. 

Except that his private refuge had another occupant now.

Severus knew every inch of the place by heart; he could walk around the little house with his eyes closed and not hit a single stick of furniture, unless he wanted to.  The lights were for her benefit, but she didn’t seem to notice.  Lourdes stood in the middle of the room, shoulders hunched and fingers digging into her ribcage as she looked around blankly.

Here there was no obligation to shove her into that dark Head of House passage to face Albus in this state.  It wasn’t that Albus was cruel, but he…just didn’t understand.   But Severus knew all too well the difficulty of trying to deliver a report when your brain could hardly wrap itself around what had just happened.  That, and right now he had to deal with the choking, guilty urge to fix her as fast as he could before anyone noticed the damage that had been done.

It had happened before; he’d accidentally split her across the stomach with sectumsempra.  He’d tested it for ages on his hand and it had not seemed so bad, and supposed it would cause a haze of irritating scratches like a foray into a thorn patch.  But Severus was very upset when they met to practice, he’d just found out that Lily Evans had deigned to do the inevitable; date James Potter.
 
 The spell he cast sliced far deeper than either of them had been prepared for. 
 
The shocking amount of blood spilling over her hands from the deep wound made him panic and want to run as far away from culpability as possible. But he focused instead on fixing her, fumbling with his wand and the battered copy of The Emergency Healer’s Manual which he’d kept stuffed in his book bag since he’d started experimenting.  He’d worked out a theoretical counter-curse at the start of the chapter on curse damage influence in wounds. It had taken five terrifying minutes of chanting the counter curse before it had been healed completely.
 
In the aftermath there had been four sticky, bloody hands, two pale faces, and one ragged, puckered scar from hip to ribs. When he’d helped her wash the worst of the blood off and donned her school robe over her shredded Muggle clothes, she had him curse her again.  Burdening her with the huge set of rams horns Potter and Black were fond of hexing her with so she could turn herself into the Hospital Wing.
 
He’d fixed her then and nobody had had to find out. 

How to fix her now?  Clean her up? Remove any evidence as before?

With a flick of his wand, the bookshelves flew open on the hinges and the musty smell of uninhabited house grew stronger.  Dragging Lourdes by the wrist behind him, he stumbled up the dark flight of steps towards the bathroom at the end of the hall. When the lights flickered on it looked to be passably clean, though there wasn’t much he could do about the perpetual dinge, peeling paint and cracked plaster at this hour.  Thrusting two threadbare towels and a wrapped bar of soap at her, he pointed at the tin bath.

“Wash,” he said firmly.  “I’ll be in the kitchen.”

Lourdes blinked and nodded slowly as he turned to leave, slamming the door firmly behind him.  He was all the way down the stairs when he heard the hiss of water traveling through the old pipes again. 

What now?

His brain stalled for a moment as he moved automatically towards the kitchen cabinets, hauling out the teapot and a dusty tin of leaves.

That’d do.

He concentrated ferociously on all the steps of this simple task - find the pot, find the cups, clean them up, put on the water.  Anything to keep his mind off the usual childhood memories that hovered at the edges of his conscious line of thought when he was at the house. 

Small hands clutching the handle of the old cast iron frying pan to make eggs.

The tinny sound of the telephone, someone ringing from the church to ask him to fetch Dad. 

Mum, collapsing at that table, in that chair by the little door, kicking off her shoes and giving him a weary smile. 

What did my little prince learn today?

-***-
           
Lourdes could not stand still, but she did not want to move.   A horrible ache had replaced the pain from an hour ago, and this new sensation seemed worse than what she’d been dealt by Voldemort.    It pulsed in her chest, or at least that was the location she could vaguely pinpoint.  Like the curse, it seemed to be pain beyond pain but this made her feel sick and heavy and as if right there at that moment she was about to lose her mind.   She was exhausted, and wanted nothing more than to sleep, but knew it wouldn’t come if she curled up on that dingy, cold floor.

The bathtub did not seem real as she watched it fill with steaming water in the grimy yellow light from the bathroom fixtures.
 
She did not know why Severus had told her to wash, especially now that she could examine her body inch by inch as the tub filled. There wasn’t a single fresh mark, no bruises, lacerations, abrasions…nothing.  Not an ounce proof on her skin that it had all really happened, and without wounds or bruises there were no familiar landmarks on how to deal with it, there was nothing she could touch to take care of. 

The heat of the water barely registered when she sank into it.  She let her head flop back against the lip of the tub, not taking care to keep her braids dry as she took in the cracked plaster ceiling and tried for a moment to turn her brain off.

And once again that new ache came in great pulsing waves like the water that had persistently ground down the cliffs she’d been perched on minutes ago.  Her heart beat slowly in her stomach as the image of the ceiling blurred before her eyes and she was suddenly aware that her face was wet, stiff and salty - with tears, of all things.

When had she started crying?

Sliding slowly underneath the hot water, Lourdes felt faced with an impossibly vital choice in that moment.  Inhale and drown, or exhale, scream and see if it would help.   It would certainly be easy.  By the time she’d pressed all the air out of her lungs and the last of the bubbles had vanished, she decided, rather numbly, that it would be better to pull the plug on than risk the temptation.

Once every inch of skin she could see had been viciously scrubbed and inspected, and there were still no cuts or bruises to be found, Lourdes was not sure if she had imagined it all or not. 

Drifting automatically towards the largest bedroom, swaddled in the scratchy old towels, she started to rummage through a wardrobe for something to put on instead of her robes, which smelled like sweat and fear.   The wardrobe didn’t offer much of a selection, but there was a very soft old button down that turned out to be far too large (the cuffs fell well over her hands), clean shorts and a pair of itchy wool socks.

Tempting as the crisply made up but musty bed looked, Lourdes decided against crashing on strange sheets and wandered down the dark hallway with its stale unfamiliar smell, and was glad that she hadn’t ever had to grow up in house like this.

-***-

Why had he always been too cheap to replace the furniture down here?  Everything in this house was too old, even the teacups.  The ones without cracks were the weird ones that belonged to his Mum when she did readings for the superstitious neighborhood ladies.

Right about then, Severus realized he’d been staring without blinking at a scorch mark in the counter top, made when he’d been caught brewing potions outside of school.   The tea kettle was screaming, and he had no idea how long it had been going like that.    When he took the kettle off the heat he could hear the creaking of floorboards right above him, and soft footsteps.  She was in the big bedroom, and now coming down the hall…

When he turned around, Lourdes was staring at the book case that doubled as the kitchen door.  Still damp from the bath and dwarfed by one of his dad’s old shirts, that exposed mostly bare, scar streaked legs, Lourdes squinted to study the book titles while her braids dripped water onto the floor.

She looked paler than usual, and tinged pink around the eyes and the end of her nose from what he suspected was too much crying.   Somehow, seeing her padding around as if she knew the place by heart seemed…right.  Lourdes had been inside his head so often in the past that this seemed perfectly natural.  His brain seemed to stop, lurch, and blur at that notion – Lourdes belonging in this house - before he could shake himself into action again.

“Drink,” he managed, slopping tea over the edges of the cup as he shoved it into her hands.  Lourdes shuffled in to the kitchen without argument and sank into a chair while Severus busied himself with the tea tray before finally taking his seat. 

And they sat for a moment in a crater of silence, shoulder to shoulder, with nothing to say, nothing they could say.  After downing his tea faster than he thought possible, Severus had to stop to catch his breath and saw Lourdes studying the cup with the strangest look on her face.

“Would'st thy fortune like to see? Perchance this cup will show to thee.”  She looked up, slightly confused it seemed, and tapped the rim with one finger. 

“These were my Mum's,” Severus muttered, feeling a little thump in his chest when he realized how tacky they must seem.  How tacky the whole house must look.

“Somehow I figured that,” Lourdes muttered, as she blinked hard, spanning her forehead with one hand to shade her eyes and squeeze her temples.

“Painkiller,” he said suddenly.  It had just dawned on him that she might need those more than she’d need a bath or tea or anything like that.

“No, thanks.”  She started gnawing on her lower lip again, eyes downcast and shoulders drawn in so that she seemed smaller, colder - as remote as the moon.

Severus felt a sudden surge of anger, though he wasn’t sure what to direct it at.  Lourdes had just been completely wrung out, and here he sat like an idiot with no idea how to start dealing with it.  It was no wonder his face felt strangely numb, his brain throbbed and ears filled with the sound of rushing blood. 

“It was just pain.” Lourdes looked up at him as though she was trying to be serene, to be brave about this. “You’re supposed to tell me to grit my teeth, and be professional about it.  It was only ever for the greater good.”

That notion struck him instantly and instinctively as stupid, though all his logical thoughts tried to override that instinct with reasoning and ‘hard cold facts.’  Life was a struggle, this was a war, pain was an unavoidable part of it.   Though, facts hadn’t ever made it hurt any less.

“That is the most foolish thing I’ve ever heard,” he hissed, hand darting out to grab and crush hers, meeting her dispassionate stare with a hard, challenging look. “I wouldn’t tell you that.”

She didn’t look away, but her face softened and her eyebrows drew together in a worried expression that seemed very out of place, given the circumstances.  “Albus will.”

“You seem to have confused him with someone else,” Severus muttered, and then in a voice so low he was sure she wouldn’t have been able to hear it.  “It’s not what he told me.”

Lourdes eyes sparked up ever so slightly, and there was a familiar tiger-in-the-bushes look about her now so she looked as though she was trying to decide whether or not she had enough energy for an attack.  “Why would he tell you that?”

Another long silence stretched out between them as Severus recoiled and gripped his teacup with both hands.  The silence in the kitchen was tense now, and even though he’d fixed his eyes on the damp clumps of leaves in his cup he could feel her watching and waiting. 
 
What he’d mentioned, what he’d meant, was not a memory he frequented often, in fact he kept it locked and shoved as far back in his brain as it would go.  Just the slightest thought of it sent an eerie prickle racing over his skin and made it feel as though all his organs were moving about independently of one another.

A sudden shift in balance.

Shrieks of hyena laughter in the background, pain somewhere in the flesh but it couldn’t rival the overwhelming, rib crushing feeling of humiliation…

And hate, rising hot out of his stomach.

A familiar voice stinging words together – prophecy, child…
 
Lily.
 
“Doesn’t matter,” Severus said in a hollow voice; he hardly had the energy to turn his nose up at her now.

“It does to me.”  There was a hint of smugness in her voice that he recognized.  He felt it every time he caught a student in a lie…  “I didn’t buy your story altogether, it was a little too practiced.  I knew you, Severus.  Sometimes I think you forget that.  And you never mentioned pain before.”

It seemed hard to wrap his brain around the concept of vocalizing the event, the whole chain of events that had lead up to it.   Trying to find the words seemed awkward, impossible even.

“Couldn’t tell you.  Even if I wanted to,” he croaked.

“You don’t have to I’m a good enough Legilimens to see it myself, if you’ll let me.  I know that this is generally out of bounds, but let me in just this once… and I’ll know.”

When Severus dared to move his head to face her, he saw Lourdes’ features clouded by a look of grim suspicion.  He couldn’t tell whether she thought she was not being trusted, or if she thought he was lying again.  

Every second he had to squirm under that look was one second to long, even though knew he’d earned this by feeding her the easy story instead of the honest one.  Right now, more than ever, he hated the feeling of his brain clicking into action and making a thousand calculations at top speed - rushing to evaluate the risk of letting her in versus the risk of keeping her out.  And the horrible gnawing instinct that seemed to be pressing at his chest that urged him to just get it over with already, to just let her know and be done with it to stop the aching feeling of carrying a very well kept secret…

Suddenly, Severus felt as though he were centuries old and hadn’t slept in just as long before he finally surrendered, dropping his head to conceal the fact that his cheeks had seared an ugly brick red.

“All right.”

This time he felt her fingers close around his wrist, tugging him forward; all the while it felt like he was moving underwater.  After allowing himself to be pulled around in his chair while she scooted forward in hers, Severus felt a strange rush of warmth when her fingers skimmed his face,  shoving damp hair behind his ears and cradling his jaw with her hands.

“Open your eyes.”  It was a very soft request, in a tone as close to gentle as he could expect from her.

With what felt like a monumental effort, he complied.

-***-

It could never be said that Severus ever felt anything lightly.  But in adulthood he’d managed to conceal this intensity behind a thick façade of surly, sneering indifference.  Just behind the smooth façade he soared to higher highs and sank to lower lows than Lourdes knew possible
 
The only thing she was feeling was how strange it was to be unimpeded as a Legilimens. It wasn’t quite like intruding into a memory in a Pensieve, where you dropped in and remained isolated from feeling, accessing only sensory memories, able to take in every perspective. A Legilimens had to deal with the whole story; deciding which feelings, networked memories, sensory input and streams of perception associated with the target thought were profitable, and what meaning could be drawn from the whole experience. If you wanted the truth, or as close as you could come to it in the frailty of human memory, you had to be able to adapt to the unique cognitive processes of every person you encountered.  Provide some perspective to biased, flawed memories and leaps in logic.  
 
Trying to process and understand Severus had often proved difficult when they were training at school. Lourdes knew her general lack of emotional intensity was what allowed her to be so analytical, but it also meant she didn’t “feel” as much as her peers. She’d always had a difficult time maintaining a good Legilimency connection with Severus if she found a particularly overwhelming memory.  He’d eventually brought this to use by forcing her to view difficult memories so she’d withdrawal in confusion if he couldn’t directly repel her. 
 
Was that what he was planning on doing now?  Offering her a chance to see, counting that her Legilimency had not advanced far enough to handle a mind like his? 
 
This memory began as a feeling of cold and damp as she found herself on the pavement of an unfamiliar village, the scenery a mere blur and ripple in the memory’s continuity.    She only had a moment to adjust when the cloaked and hooded figure of Severus, clutching a black doctor’s bag, swept right through her and carried her along as he slipped easily down streets and narrow alleyways towards a particularly old little building.  As he walked, she was made painfully aware of a steady stream of thoughts, emotions and sensory information flooding through here as if she were him.  In effort to concentrate she dampened them, and for the moment paid attention to sight and sound.
The name on the door, which Severus proceeded to quietly probe with his fingers and wand, was “Meadowes.”  He seemed to spend an age kneeling on the floor, tense and alert as he unraveled the spells that barred the door and listened for the click of tumblers in the lock before finally being admitted to a flat filled with dim, early evening light.

Quiet as a cat, Severus slipped through the rooms, fingers darting out from the folds of his cloak every now and then to skim the handle of a hair brush, pinching the fabric of the robes in her wardrobe with a sort of appraiser’s intensity that made Lourdes’ skin crawl.  For the moment she could watch and listen to his thoughts - a logical process of matching and elimination as he made high speed connections between what he knew about his victim, the poisons he had in his bag, and the items he’d discovered in her flat.

In an instant, Lourdes knew why he was here - assassination, a slippery little poisoner deciding what to taint it with for maximum efficiency.  But Severus was all hesitation and lingering doubt…

His long pale fingers popped the latch on his bag, revealing a glittering array of crystal phials filled with liquids the brilliant colors of poison frogs and insects, and envelopes packed with powders neatly sealed and labeled. He’d only just touched a phial filled with toxic orange murk when the door handle clicked, and in an instant Severus had the bag closed, his mask down, and his wand out.

The woman who emerged from behind the door had a familiar face; Dorcas Meadows had been a very vocal member of the Wizengamot during the first war. She’d been known less for her skill as a witch and more for ability to inspire political fervor in even the most dispassionate individuals, and her incredibly irreverent treatment of the Dark Lord.  But she’d apparently been fast on her feet, even in her old age.

Dorcas got the first jab in, or so it seemed; her wand shot off a vivid silver dart that took off through the window, giving Severus just enough time to strike first.  Jets of light were soaring across the room in the general direction of each target, shattering furniture and blasting holes in the plaster and boards as Severus seemed to be attempting to move towards the door and Dorcas tried to keep him pinned down in a corner. 

The cacophony only increased as several other wizards joined the fray and the one on one scuffle quickly turned into a three on one brawl.  There was Dorcas, a ferocious looking, bull-necked red head Lourdes recognized as one of the Prewetts, and James Potter…
Severus used the confusion and the clouds of plaster dust as a cover, slithering out on his hands and knees and down the steps at lightning speed. But James Potter was hot on his trail, trying to keep up and keep his wand out of the sight of the Muggles being shoved out of the way as Severus made a beeline for a patch of unkempt grass. Beyond it lay the edge of a scruffy little wood, clearly Severus' destination.

He had just enough time to roar out a curse that brought several Death Eaters Apparating to his aide, and just in time too.  Dorcas and the Prewett had finally caught up, evening the odds for James, and suddenly the quiet patch of forest was filled with the deafening noises of curses being cast and the blinding light of spells.  For a moment the only thing Lourdes could observe was a series of frantic blurs, and that Severus felt too cool, too in control of his actions as he made instantaneous decisions on who to target, trying to predict and steer the fight. 

He had set fire to the detritus on the forest floor and it was spreading rapidly, to draw the Order away from the conflict by threatening the village.  The Prewett jerked around on the spot, screwing his face up as he prepared to attack Severus, who was quicker, and managed to get two hits in: one spell that robbed the Prewett of his ability to speak and a well aimed sectumsempra that cut deep into the tendons of Prewett’s wand arm, causing his fingers to go slack all at once.  Prewett opened his mouth in a silenced roar, and pressed on without  his wand as though he was oblivious to the blood and pain. He turned and slammed his functioning fist into the first enemy body he could find, and Severus took that as a cue to find a new target.

That was when he noticed James, who’d managed to break through the fire but not without being hit by a stray spell.  A bright violet jet of light ripped through James’ chest and left him prone and twitching like a dying insect as the fire crept steadily in his direction, engulfing James and Severus in a crackling ring.

James was right there, and Severus was one killing curse away from disposing of him.  But Severus stayed frozen, wand pointed at James, and Lourdes felt three things collide in Severus’ brain - hesitation, calculation, and a sour, aching hatred growing from a system of vividly recalled memories Lourdes chose not to plumb.

Severus’ eyes met James’ for a brief second and the only thing that seemed to transmit on James’ end was pure, abject hatred and a cold flash of fear at the thought of Lily, alone.   Severus had a cold flash of his own at a sudden realization that brought a lightning fast series of memories; a leering Sirius Black, the whomping willow, and the low growling sound in darkness.  And most contemptibly of all, James running to the rescue, a memory which inspired a vicious spike of hatred in Severus’ stomach. 

He owed James a life debt, but wanted him dead more than anything. 

Severus’ wand hand shook from being held outstretched and immobile for so long and the harsh heavy voice of another Death Eater rose above the sound of the fire and tore through Severus’ concentration.

“They’ve got the drop on us! It’s not worth it… what are you waiting for? KILL HIM”

Severus’ mind was nothing but a swirl of images and the idea of forming the words to the killing curse with his mouth, but it was two seconds too late. 

The ferocious looking form of Sirius Black broke through the fire ring, throwing himself in front of James and sending a full, heavy blast into Severus’ chest. 

Things went black.

“…mudblood!”
 
There was a violent lurch and blur of color and time before Lourdes felt another memory blooming in front of her as though she’d just opened her eyes.

It was unnaturally dark for a place under the wide open sky with the dim lights of a large city casting a wash of light on the horizon.  Lourdes shuddered a bit when she found herself confronted by the stony faces of Victorian angels, half shrouded in vine growth,  holding inverted torches and looking piteously on the scene unfolding below.  She was in a cemetery, a much neglected one by the looks of it.

Amongst the ramshackle gravestones packed as close and crooked as teeth stood a mass of shrouded figures hissing and whispering to one another in the dark. They kept a respectable distance from two figures in a clearing encircled by clumps of light that glowed hazy green like corpse candles. 

The towering form of the Dark Lord glided leisurely around the little clearing, spidery fingers with dirty nails caressing a gaunt, waxy face as he contemplated.  Independent of the fear and resentment boiling in Severus’s memory Lourdes felt her own brief flash of attraction to what had clearly been an extremely good looking man, and revulsion for having felt it.    In his original form Voldemort had a horrible sort of magnetism that kept every eye riveted on him effortlessly.

“It was a simple request,” Voldemort said in a tone of practiced nonchalance laced with familiar malice.  He seemed to be contemplating the disapproving faces of the gravestones while Severus twitched, eyes darting up every second or so to assess the crowd gathered in the shadows. 

“Eliminate the threat of Dorcas Meadowes, and leave without a trace. I know you could have done it, Severus.  But you didn’t and now we must ask ourselves…why.”  Voldemort swayed on the spot a little, smoothly drawing a finger over his mouth and putting on an expression of contemplation. The question was rhetorical, of course, and Severus didn’t dare answer, and Lourdes shivered at the feeling of teeth that were not hers grinding furiously.

“I have often wondered, Severus, if you were as worthy of the Mark as Lucius made you out to be.  What sort of faithful and obedient servant makes a fool of his master by being…sick… in the heat of the moment?  Or by hesitating… Hesitation seems to be your hallmark, Severus.  If you hadn’t hesitated and lingered Dorcas Meadowes would be dead, would she not?”

“I did not hesitate,” Severus hissed, in a tone dangerously close to a full blown snarl as he continued to kneel on the ground latticed with old tree roots and studded with sharp little rocks.  “She was not on schedule. In two weeks of observation, Dorcas Meadowes never arrived home earlier than 6 PM.  It was her routine.”

The angrier Severus became, the more cool and pleasant Voldemort acted, as though he was building up to something.  “More to the point, Severus, is that in the heat of battle, and I mean that quite literally on account of that slippery fire you set, you hesitated.  Did you not have James Potter at the end of your wand?  And yet you failed to kill him.  You hesitated.”

Lourdes was overtaken for a moment by the high volume of Severus’ anger - it flashed hot through his body and seemed almost palpable.  So much so that the Dark Lord seemed to feel it and pulled back a bit as though he’d opened an oven and been surprised by the heat rolling out.

“Promise, Severus.  That is what you had.  But you cannot be forever promising, eventually you must produce.  And you must do so consistently.  I have seen consistency from you, and it is only in the hesitating.… Do you know, Severus, that now that Dorcas Meadowes is surely in hiding?  She is now aware that we know where she lives, and that we will not hesitate to kill her quietly if we cannot make a spectacle of it.  And for the moment she is completely lost to us.  Of course, that will not prevent her from contributing to the papers and making her opinions known.”   Voldemort paused again, for effect, heaving a long-suffering sigh before he began to glide like a shark around Severus, pressing the tip of his wand against his fingertips and pursing his lips thoughtfully.

“Such a chance is lost… and I will have to finish this work myself.  Now I find myself burdened with the task of punishing you.  A master should not have to punish his servants so, but it appears these days the world is wanting for competent, dedicated wizards.  You really must learn this, Severus.  Death Eaters never hesitate.  Hesitate, and you risk not only a death at the hands of our enemies, death by the hand of a mongrel Mudblood or a blood traitor.  Hesitate and you also receive the wrath of your master.  But how best to reinforce this lesson…”

There was another theatrical pause in his indulgent monologue as Voldemort spun manically towards his audience amongst the headstones and made a sweeping gesture.  Lourdes took the opportunity to sift through the memory for Severus’ feelings at the moment and was jarred on the spot by a toxic wave of furious embarrassment and mounting hatred that made her physically sick to her stomach. 
It certainly couldn’t be said that Severus ever felt anything lightly…

Voices from the audience of Death Eaters were reduced to a hissing, twittering chorus of night insects within Severus’ thoughts as his ears buzzed furiously with numb humiliation and every muscle was rigid with anger.  It was as though he felt he couldn’t take this shame any more, and then there was a flash of an idea: standing as fast as he could to fire the killing curse at the Dark Lord’s back. 

Who could say he hesitated then?

The second that thought flashed white hot across Severus’ mind, Voldemort stopped reveling in his presentation to the crowd and his monstrous, melted face twisted into a look of feral glee.

Suddenly, the world was upside down and there was the horrible pressure of blood rushing rapidly to Severus’ head, and nothing was visible through the thick swath of black material that had fallen over his eyes.  The immersion into thick blackness only heightened the other sensations. 

Shrieking hyena laughter rippled through Severus’ consciousness, merging with every instance of laugher at his expense over the course of a lifetime.

The only other thing that registered was pain.

Lourdes had lost the illusion of control she’d had earlier and slipped into the violent rush of humiliation, pain, betrayal, and a feeling of absolute vulnerability that had not dulled in Severus’ memory over time. 

She pushed her intruding consciousness through that endless loop of pain to detect serious damage to the part of him that understood the self-non-self divide.  His connection to concientia - reality, empathy - was not that of a healthy person. The feeling of safety most people associated with their own identity seemed deeply damaged.  Lourdes knew that feeling, when you could not remember if you were human or not, when your mind couldn’t cope with pain anymore.  It could make you pliable, or too hard to penetrate.  And unfortunately for the Dark Lord, the damage he had done to Severus seemed to have rippled across every part of his being, leaving unalterable changes in its wake.  Severus had allowed the damage to make his vulnerability and pain into something hard, sharp and unyielding, eager to be wielded and cause its own damage…

There was a stillness in the memory, a buzzing calm where muffled voices could be heard conversing a few feet away.  Nothing seemed to strike Severus as important until a vaguely familiar voice cut through.  In his haze of pain he could not identify the voice itself, and the body it originated from was hidden in shadow.
 
Lourdes knew that voice though – it was Peter Pettigrews…
 
“My Lord,” his tone was hushed and sly, there was a strange sort of confidence that shouldn’t have been in the voice of a coerced traitor.  This sounded willing, eager almost.
 
“What you revealed – the prophecy, I may know who it refers to…”
 
Severus eyes seemed to slit open just enough to see shadowy informant huddled at the Dark Lords feet, alone but for Severus and the stone angels.   “There are two happy announcements among the Order, Alice Longbottom and Lily Potter are expecting… in about six months time each…”
 
Cold fear overtook everything she could feel in Severus – so intense that she could feel the physical backlash in her own body; the racing heart, rapidly closing throat and the dizzy urge to run like hell.  But he stayed still as a corpse and listened.
 
“It would fit,” Voldemort sounded calculating and thoughtful.  “There were three rather messy incidents with each little pair weren’t there?  But the Mudblood and Potter...”
 
There was a pause there as though he were weighing the Longbottoms defiance against the Potters. 
 
“It’s the Potters,” Voldemort said with startling finality.  Severus could see the informant draw back a bit, as if he had not quite expected that answer, and Severus himself seemed to enter a state of heightened panic.  Lourdes could see a conversation between Voldemort and Pettigrew-in-shadow but Severus’ brain was not giving observation priority.  It was rushing with thousands of memories and thoughts, and his body was similarly overwhelmed by the weakness and lightheadedness brought by a mixture of fear and desire so intense Lourdes thought she would not be able to tolerate staying in his mind much longer.
 
When Lourdes forced herself to become clear headed enough to follow each thought, each feeling, each memory back she found they traced to a single overwhelming source.
 
Lily. 
 
But not really Lily as a woman, or a person even.  He had made her an icon, an object of singular devotion and veneration… Seeing it was like entering the Holy of Holies in Severus’ personal tabernacle.
 
The icon stretched across all corners of his mind like a spiders web, and was unlike anyone who had ever existed.  It was frozen and motionless; its beauty was unearthly, perfect, and radiant in the relative darkness of his mind.  This object of intense devotion originated from a network of memories which were like examining heavily retouched, highly colored dreams instead of recollections; part reality, part self generated fantasy. 
 
The icon’s connections were still there in his present day brain, though degraded and dusty compared to what she could see in the memory.   Some thought or feeling stirred near the icon, feebly as if injured but Lourdes did not have time to examine it.  Coming to the icon generated something in Severus – an overwhelming desire to possess, something more akin to greed than anything else.  It was so intense that it drove Severus off the ground and across the dirt and tree roots to Voldemort’s feet when his shadow informant vanished.
 
“My Lord…Lily…I’ve known her forever and…”  Each word was a desperate prayer and Severus had never seemed so naked, vulnerable or exposed.  Voldemort could see everything; every spare moment with Lily on the creek bank, or in the forest.  On the playground or stolen in her room riffling through Petunias diary.  He could see every dinner eaten with grubby hands at the Evans’ table, and every sinking and soaring moment Severus had spent with Lily in school.  
 
And the icon he had made her in to…
 
Voldmort’s eyes seemed to glitter without the benefit of any particular light, and he cocked his head as if this abject display was the most intriguing thing he’d ever seen.
 
“And what would you do, Severus, if I should spare her alone?  Kill Potter, eliminate the threat in the child?  What would you do for your Lord?
 
There was no hesitation, only an explosion of untempered greedy desire.  Lourdes saw no connections to thoughts of what the woman would feel without her child or the husband.  No thought to the value of both potentially lost lives. 
 
The ONLY thing Severus seemed capable of thinking of was this imaginary Lily. Not a person anymore, excised and isolated from the rest of the world and all her connections to it.  As longed for as heaven and as seemingly unattainable until just that moment…
 
“Anything,” Severus replied.
 
Lourdes hadn’t known anything like it.  The sheer alienness of what Severus was feeling made her dizzy trying to wrap her mind around it.  It was obsessive, it was fervent, it was real to him.  His devotion and desire to the icon represented had become a gaping weakness too massive to miss, too firm not to take hold of and manipulate, too singular not to exploit.  And despite the fact that it disturbed her, that she knew what he had made was not real, or right Lourdes felt the strange need to protect him for it.
 
That was enough for her, Lourdes pulled away from the whole thing a fast as she could, stomach churning violently and her head feeling tight and spinning wildly. 

-***-

Continued in Part 2: In Opposition

In The Dark

Moths - petrified and pinned into specimen cases in the office of one of her Professors at Istanbul. She did not try to disguise her disgust for the site. So many creatures of dust and shadow displayed behind glass under artificial light instead of meeting their end on the earth, the wings joining the dead leaves of trees.

It stung the sense of undertaker’s pride in her. After devoting part of her life to sending flesh and bone back to the elements she knew he didn’t have the right to keep those creatures in stasis. Somehow the sight of all those little furry bodies and powdery wings squeezed her damaged heart under the web of gold filaments and made her sick to her stomach.

Smiling a dirty, sharp smile framed by flabby lips, he’d described, with a sickening thrill, the process of catching them. The worst part was how he lured his prey- with wildly fragrant night flowers or a glowing bulb in a moth trap.

The things they loved the best…

Lourdes sat up with a start, overwhelmed by the smell of flowers, and skin burning hot as if she’d been walking on coals. It was too hot to be sleeping under all those blankets in flannel pajamas. She managed to work off the sweaty pajama top without even unbuttoning it, leaving her considerably cooler in just the undershirt.

She froze, and clapped a hand on her stomach. There it was again. That heavy squirm just under her ribcage that had nothing to do with her organs, and though her heartbeat kept the same slow rhythm, it felt…heavy. It was hard to breathe – very hard to breathe.

It needed a diagnosis.

Helplessness?

Perhaps; she was over her head in a situation she had almost no experience with. She might have been a better spy for O.H.K. with their rules and regulations, but now she was struggling to balance the scale between the Order and the Death Eaters. Lourdes took another shaky breath to try to stop the frantic squirm and flutter, and wanted to scream.

It was deeply frustrating to be groping in the dark, finding the very edges of whatever the trouble was and being unable to force the problem into a recognizable shape, or get a real feel for it.

How to fix it? She couldn’t cure an illness she couldn’t diagnose. Alright, if not fix it, how to get a handle on it?

Her brain flashed insistent images of her mother and uncle Chou the apothecary hissing and clucking with disapproval when Lourdes came back scratched and bruised from a tussle with the wrong goat or a black eye from fighting the boys. The first thing they gave her was a cup of tea. When the capture team came limping back and the healers rushed at them, the first thing they jammed in her hands was a cup of tea. Even Albus knew… tea would help.
She needed tea.    

Lourdes looked up towards the bed where Severus was tangled up in his bed sheets, muttering fitfully. It wouldn’t be a very good idea to wake him up, especially for something as trivial as lighting a fire. He’d probably just hex her and roll right back over.

I can do this alone, Lourdes thought fervently as she eased open the lid of her trunk.

And kill two birds with one stone…

-***-

He sees Mum’s face, thin and worn from too much worrying and work, screwed up as she tries not to shout or cry. Dad’s face is wild as he stoops over her, pointing an accusing finger, his other arm flailing as he screams and bellows.

Hot, sticky tears pour down Severus’ face; fat strands of hair cling to his cheeks as he watches from his corner. His teeth button down on his lower lip so he does not make a sound.

“TELL ME!” Dad screams, “TELL ME HOW YOU GOT THE MAGIC! I WANT IT, EILEEN! HE’S GOT IT! I WANT IT TOO! YOU FREAKS CAN’T HIDE IT FROM ME FOREVER!”

Dad shouts and babbles until he is too tired to scream anymore. Mum is relieved when Dad sits at the table and cries softly instead of yelling, and she makes tea. She asks Dad to take his medicine, but Dad only cries. The mug of Twinings and little pills are ignored. Severus knows it’s time for bed, but he clings to Mum after she opens his window to let in cool air.

“Severus, Daddy is ill, you know that.” Mum's voice is weary, and as she smoothes the hair away from his face Severus can see that the lines in her face are deeper today than they were yesterday. “He can’t help shouting, he doesn’t know any better.”

Some days, Dad is better than others. But he’s been ill a lot lately, and Severus does not know exactly what’s wrong. He only knows that Dad shouted and cried today because Severus was kicked out of school. Two big boys tried to bully him, and the teachers found them against the wall, knocked out with blood in their noses.

He hadn’t meant to do it, but he wasn’t sorry.

You’re magic, Mum explained. A wizard like Mummy is a witch. He’d get to go to a special school later with lots of other children just like him. There he can be a wizard all the time, but here he had to keep it a secret.

Severus is very good at keeping secrets now. How ill Dad is, how tired Mum is, how suspicious the neighbors are…

They are suspicious because the Snapes do not speak to anyone, and because Severus and Dad don’t leave the house often. Mum does the work now, at the Chemist, and she doles out little capsules and secret advice about which plants might help along with those pills. Mum keeps so many secrets; the orchids she grows in the secret green house that are sold to the potion companies, the magic books she disguises so Dad won’t find them. How they don’t have enough money with Dad unwell and out of work so sometimes Mum steals from the till to make ends meet. Severus watches her try very hard not to cry while she sorts through the bills.

Severus stays at home and endures lessons in maths and grammar from Dad before he was too ill. Without fail, Severus wakes up bright and early to make breakfast, cooking the eggs right so Mum has something to eat before she goes to work. Then he sits down for lessons carefully egg-timed, reading everything in the house, getting big books from the library to get ahead in his studies.

It hadn’t always been like this; when Severus was very small and Dad took his medicine, they went on a special trip a long way away to the observatory to see the stars, but now the only place Dad takes Severus is to the church when Dad gets scared that devils are banging around in the walls. Severus hates the pity on the faces of the other parishioners, on the face of the priest. What a shame, they all say when they think he can’t hear. Tobias so sick and his little child has to take care of him. Where’s the mother?

Dad is always scared now. He has been shouting at Mum about money and magic, he wants both. Mum says every night he is just very ill, she uses a big word that sounds funny; Severus does not quite understand what it means. Later he looks the big word up and learns that it means broken mind.

There aren’t really devils in the walls; Severus checked. It is only ever the boiler, and Severus fixes it every time it starts to rattle. Dad’s mind is broken - Severus hates it. He can fix the boiler when it rattles but he cannot fix Dad…

Severus shot up in bed, hand spanning his forehead to pinch his temples. The only light came from the bright full moon streaming through the narrow window, and even that made his head throb violently.

I should have taken more painkillers…

It was all Potter's fault really; if it wasn’t for those damn Occlumency lessons, Severus wouldn’t be having the vicious, lingering headaches and the bad dreams. Lourdes’ fault, too; if she didn’t drink painkillers and sedatives like they were tea he might be able to keep them somewhere other than the locked cabinet in the kitchen.

One, two, three….go ahead, swing your feet out… Severus felt his whole body, and quite possibly his brain, contract when cold stone floor made contact with his warm feet. With a yawn he eased the bedroom door open and froze.

Something was not right here - there was a fire blazing in the grate and he hadn’t set it. Lourdes was kneeling in front of the fireplace in the center of a chalk sigil, the scarred soles of her feet visible, her forearms stacked with heavy amulet bracelets. The sigil’s interconnected lines were slowly blackening and sizzling like a spark up a trail of dynamite powder.

Severus blinked hard to clear the sleep out of his eyes while he tried to put all this together. Lourdes couldn’t start magical fires.  There wasn’t any fuel for a real one, and Lourdes would sooner burn herself than burn a book. His eyes blurred briefly as he stared into the fire, and he could have sworn it pulled a face at him.

It must be a demon or an elemental spirit… No!

People studied this in the Department of Mysteries; they didn’t DO it in people's living rooms. This must just be a dream. He was already in bed, already asleep. Yes. That made sense.

“I didn’t mean to wake you up. Just go back to sleep,” Lourdes said coolly, as if this was nothing more interesting than first year charms class. “It’s under control.” A tendril of flame snaked out of the fire place and around one of the heavy stacks of bracelets, as if the fire was trying to reassure him.

“Is that what I think it is?” Severus ventured.

“Probably. It’s called Tngri, and we have arranged a contract.  I think you call them heliopaths…” She said that as if it were everyday practice to surrender a witch or wizard's valuable blood or flesh to an otherworldly creature.
But Tngris, as she called them, totaled only ninety nine in existence, and had been coveted, murdered for, and highly prized before they were forgotten.  They were not to be tamed like a house elf, each of the known number had a personality of its own, quirks and preferences, different demands it would make of its companion…never an owner.  Like anything elemental, they were wild temperamental magic only tolerated when there had been many more people like her…

As if to prove what she’d said, Lourdes pulled her under shirt away from the soft flesh on her left hip. In the center of a wide, violently purple bruise was the bony top of a fang already half enveloped by healing skin, and a fresh black burn that spelled something in foreign script.

She flicked a finger and the flame wound itself up around her arm and over her shoulders like a stole, taking a sleek almost catlike shape. Little licks of flame flexed like cat-paws kneading in the air as it lounged on her shoulder. “See? Friendly as a krup.” Lourdes gave him a deeply patronizing look, and the fire light threw her scars and features into sharp relief. 

The presence of that magic, or maybe it had been the dreams, made Severus feel uncomfortably young and small even in his own living room.

“I needed tea. You don’t have any matches,” she continued flatly, fingers reaching up to flutter affectionately under the tngri’s… chin before pushing the cauldron holder into place. “And I had a feeling you might be a little mad if I burned those first year essays even if they are all rubbish.”

As the fire leapt into the grate to start its work, Severus gradually felt the shock wearing off so his face could push into some expression other than slack jawed disbelief. But he could only make little sputtering sounds as there were so many things wrong right now that he couldn’t quite figure out what to shout about first.

Taking a slow step forward, he could see something scattered on the floor glinting in the light from the fire place. He sank to his knees to investigate, and discovered the shards of his good ironstone teapot with the spider-web pattern scattered on the floor with neatly quartered fragments of the pile of letters he’d left on the table before bed. Not that he could blame her for wanting to shred them, as Severus had wanted to do it when he’d read them.

Someone had seen Pettigrew’s hand wandering during the roll call and there were quite a lot of nasty comments about Severus losing control of “his pet” to an apparently weaker wizard.

“Did you really need to tear them up?” Severus muttered, every syllable ringing painfully in his head as he spoke.

“Probably not.” She sounded numb.

“How were you going to make tea without a teapot?”

“Hadn’t quite got to that yet.”

“Reparo… And where were you going to get the tea?”

“Hadn’t got to that yet either.”

Squeezing his eyes shut against the firelight, Severus reached out for the table, setting the repaired teapot and shredded letters down before carefully counting the steps to the kitchen door.

“Could you bring some butter, please?” Lourdes’ shout tore through his head as he braced against the wall and fumbled with the incantation to open the cabinet. Three potions and a dish of butter later, Severus wobbled out towards the fireplace and collapsed on the floor next to her, flopping on to his back and covering his eyes with his free hand, leaving just enough space to peek out if he liked.

“Thanks,” she muttered. The fire flickered eagerly as Lourdes pricked her finger with her misericorde and counted three careful drops of blood. There was a hiss accompanied by the smell of browning butter and an odd contented noise from the tngri.

“When the spell runs out the contract’s sealed,” she sighed, tugging her shirt back down over the fang and surrounding wounds.  “But it's really more of a reunion.  Tngri and I are old friends.”

The pain in his skull was starting to subside, and from the vantage point on the floor it was easy to observe her. There was no tiger or predator evident in her right now; with her arms wrapped around her knees and tear tracks dried on her cheeks she looked like a child who’d lost track of her parents in a crowd.

That forlorn look and the outline of her tightly curled body struck at something in him, and he could feel the odd reverberation all through his chest. Severus had never thought he’d see a shred of innocence in a person like Lourdes, with so many deaths on her hands and with absolutely no qualms about tearing open foul creatures or stealing life. But there it was - mixed in with a sort of bare exhaustion.

When everything was stripped off, her training, the education, the hard and lean years there was still something soft underneath, but only just…

It seemed like fertile ground, something that had rarely been touched by anything, or anyone else.

Lourdes reached up and rubbed her cheeks with the back of her hand, dragging her fingers down her face and neck to rest on her chest. His eyes followed and lingered on the v of flesh and tendons that dipped down into the hollow of her collar bone. His brain flashed a scene for him for just a moment - fingers traveling over the cords and tendons in her neck while her pulse beat under his lips.

No! No, he needed to stay focused.

“Ms Mezarci…”

No. Somehow that seemed ridiculously formal for the floor in the middle the night. “Lourdes, if you wanted tea, why didn’t you just ask?” He sounded more exasperated than he felt.

“I didn’t feel like waking you up.”

“I see. So instead you committed the crime of blood-wedding yourself to a fire spirit in my living quarters.”

“Looked like you were having some interesting dreams, I’d hate to interrupt that…”

“Nothing much,” Severus muttered, trying to keep a cool tone and failing miserably.

She turned and gave him an irritated look. “We learned Occlumency together, remember? I know about the rebound dreams, and the headaches. I know that thing with Potter is getting to you. What are you dreaming about?”

“Home,” he said simply. She’d know what that meant if she had any memory at all.

“That seems to be an occasion calling for something stronger than a cup of tea,” she muttered.

He could hear the water in the cauldron starting to boil and held up a hand to cut her off, leaping to his feet to pull it off the fire. While he warmed the teapot, the tngri amused itself by putting on a little show for Lourdes, who watched it act out a battle between two Tibetan sages.

Summoning a box off the top shelf he began rooting around for the right tea for the occasion. Darjeeling perhaps? No, he found four slightly musty teabags at the bottom of the box. Good old Twinings seemed right about now, and there was some whiskey in the kitchen for his tea.
