“Moths,” Lourdes said quietly when he emerged from the kitchen with the bottle of Old Ogden’s.

“What about them?” Severus let the whiskey pour while he counted to three.

“I’ve been dreaming about them for the past few weeks. But I can’t even remember what that stupid Divination textbook said about them.”

“That’s probably for the best,” he snorted.

“I had a professor who used to collect them and keep them in shadowboxes. The whole concept sort of offends me.  May not even mean anything really…”

Severus gave the pot a good stir and took in the cheap, tannin smell he’d come to associate with the bagged tea of his childhood. Two lumps went into her cup, one in his. It was a bit of a trick to settle down on the floor with two fat mugs without spilling anything, but he managed.

The moment the tea passed her lips, she looked appeased and disgusted. “This tastes…”

“Cheap,” he finished

“Yeah, but how did you know how I take my tea?”

“You’ve been here almost nine months,” Severus muttered as he eased himself down onto the floor next to her. “Give me some credit.”

Lourdes paused and gave him that weird contemplative look as if she’d only just noticed he was there.

“We used to be friends, didn’t we?” she said, in a strangely clinical tone.

Severus froze as he sipped his tea, feeling a little blindsided by that question and the rank burn of cheap whiskey in the back of his throat. Narrowing his eyes and lowering his mug he stared at her exhausted expression warily before he heard a pop and sputter from the fire place. The spell was complete, the tngri’s contract was sealed, but it managed one last fluid brush against Lourdes’ face before it was pulled into the fang on her hip.

It was dark now, and Severus had no desire to light the chandelier - it was just easier when he did not have to worry about controlling his expression, or seeing hers.

There was a rustling and clanking of bracelets as she moved, closer, and he caught a whiff of the perfume she’d been wearing since Christmas.

The formula was familiar, because he used to mix little vats of it at St Magdalena’s. It smelled like every comforting thing in the world he could remember.  There were the orchids and steam in his mother's green house where he read and dream during the winter months. The luxurious of harvesting essence of gardenia his employer had entrusted to Severus alone, because of his careful technique.  The smell patchouli leaves that came packed with the rolls of silk ribbon they used on boxes, and the occasional lavish compliment accompanied by anise scented curry from his employer.  All these memories she roused felt like a soft, safe place to be still…

Would she be the same?

Those bracelets clanked again, and he realized she was so close and it was so dark. He had to work to breathe evenly and he let his eyelids slide shut as if to block everything out.

Oh gods…

They came in beats – urgent flashbulb visions.

Hair wound between his fingers. Teeth grazing flesh, tongue tasting salt. Hot rush in the nerves stops the heart cold in the chest for an instant.

The whole concept pulled at his insides and it almost hurt not to touch her.

It was stupid really; this was just inevitable tension between agreeable male and female coworkers in such close quarters.

And moreover, this was Lourdes!  Ever since his sixth year, when he’d figured out that his Occlumency co-conspirator was a girl, and not merely female, things had been more than a little awkward. After all, she’d been there all that time he’d been going after Lily, and never once tried to trip him up or stop him.  He had never thought to ask Lourdes for anything other than a detailed situation analysis, perhaps for some tricks or gift ideas instead. It would have been absurd to ask.  

Lourdes had never really seemed… like a girl.

Not with her self-taught training for the Hit Wizard program, the obsession with the dark bizarre things he liked too, and the fact that he’d once seen her knock Mundungus Fletcher’s tooth out. She’d always just been… Lourdes. The one who knew.  Nothing more, nothing less.   Her lectures about Lily’s feelings had always been attributed to her preternatural gift for assessing motivation and personality from action, not because she might have some insight generated by belonging to the bizarre tribe “girl.”

He’d tried to keep things simple after he realized Lourdes was one of them.  Keeping his distance as vigorously as because there was a fear that if he said the wrong thing, made the wrong move, she would stop being Lourdes and mutate into someone else… And back then he couldn’t afford to lose a valuable asset like a study partner, especially one who might be predisposed to vengeance.

“Ever feel like a failure?” There was a familiar exhaustion in her voice when she finally spoke up.

Severus’ brain raced through the scenarios that might cause her to ask a question that loaded… What had happened last? Pettigrew’s hands went where they didn’t belong, but she took care of that. She’d stabbed the Auror, but that shouldn’t have been a big deal for her. Lourdes had only been numb and tired after he picked her up in the woods, it was when she’d come back from Albus’ office that she really seemed angry.

Unwillingly, he recalled every dressing down, every session in Albus’ office in the slow, tedious process of earning his trust. Albus lectured Severus with the same kindly firmness and cryptic hinting he’d used on the students. Those lectures usually seemed like attacks, but Severus had developed tough skin to repel the chiding words like hails of arrows bouncing off stone walls.

Severus’ problem, he was often told, was his remoteness and an almost pathological lack of empathy that Albus tried very hard to “cure.”

“This wouldn’t happen to have anything to do with your visit to the Headmaster’s office would it?”

“Maybe.” There was definitely a nasty edge to her voice now.

“And what insights did our Headmaster attempt to impress on you? What is your hamartia?” Severus placed dramatic emphasis on that last word.

“I’m not sure I really understood what he was trying to say.”  Her tone was cold and evasive just then.

“It always is,” Severus sighed and had another sip of rank, lukewarm tea.

“Do you ever wonder if he’s made any mistakes as bad as he thinks ours were?”

“Not suffocating Tom Riddle in his bed?” Severus said bleakly.

“That might have solved both our problems. You wouldn’t have been a Death Eater, and I wouldn’t have ended up in Turkey to drown myself in work.” She did something just then. There was the sound of her bracelets rattling again, the mug clanking against the stone, then the pressure of her body sidling up next to his.

-***-

Lourdes heard Severus’ mug clatter alarmingly when she moved closer. She envisioned the hand reaching to steady the china and thought about the person it was attached to. Severus had good hands - long and pale, calloused and scarred in spots from volatile potions with the deep ink stains on his writing fingers. For a split second it was all too easy to replace the thought of Pettigrew’s artificial hand traveling wherever it liked with the idea of Severus’ moving over her skin in its place. Her breath caught in her throat and her shoulders drew up and in at the thought.

That feeling she knew… But she had never associated it in her adult life with the rail thin creature next to her. That feeling belonged to other men – with broad wrestler’s bodies, pulpy lips, and short hair who smelled of hammam soap and raki.

It hadn’t been easy to keep her feelings away from her bed, or anyone else’s, try as she might.  Her tongue had a habit of slipping in the dark when she was still light headed.  But it was only ever a small betrayal of her real feelings here or there.  Lourdes doubted she would be able to stay that remote when it came to Severus. The potential for entanglement, and wanting it, ran far beyond that of limbs. That made Severus dangerous – it gave him the power to hurt her very badly…

But still, and unexpectedly, a second thought of his hands on her body shot straight through her and made her short of breath.

Suddenly the shape of that problem she’d been struggling to define was alarmingly clear. She felt the same squirm in her gut and heaviness in her heartbeat and short breaths as when she’d woken up.

No. No! This was Severus, he was a coworker and that would be against protocol.

Not that protocol had ever really mattered.

That aside, he wasn’t even attractive! Hadn’t she just been wondering about that? Lourdes wracked her brain trying to remember what she found so repulsive about him. Teeth could be brushed, hair could be washed.  When she allowed herself sideways glances at the pool she’d noticed that though he was a bit uneven and bony for his height, he’d taken care of himself well.  He’d actually made his stature a benefit, moving with a lightness and precision a bulkier man could not have.

Closer inspection revealed also revealed interesting things in the details. She didn’t need to see his face to recall every inch; she’d been studying it over the tops of books for months now. The lines and harsh angles of his face had grown endearing, as had the odd curve and hook of his nose.  But the attraction could be attributed to more than just his appearance, there was something to be said about mastery in a field, intelligence, debate, common interest.

This was Severus… he had known her so well.

Lourdes’ listened closely for any clues; Severus was trying awfully hard to breathe evenly. “So my problem is that I don’t have a motivation that Albus approves of. I think,” she muttered, glad that he couldn’t see her because she must have looked flushed and nervous.

“Oh?”

“Says he thinks I used my work to avoid reintegrating myself with more important things.  As if anyone ever goes into my line of work believing that trumped some philosophical bullshit about saving the world. It’s really not worth saving, is it?”

“Maybe not.”

“Why are you bothering then? With all this - it’s not doing you any good,” she said, not bothering to cover up the bitter, selfish bite in her tone.

“I want another life.”

“What kind?”

“You know, I have no idea,” Severus snorted.

There was heavy silence for a few more beats as a lingering shock of arousal made her insides squirm. She tried to stay as stiff and unresponsive as he was, unwilling to risk the rejection of relaxing and discovering that he might not reciprocate.  Despite the fact that one whole side of her body was snugly nestled against his and the only thing that seemed logical was to get as close as humanly possible for the sheer comfort of it.

“I don’t know what I want either,” she said at last, swallowing hard afterwards to keep her voice from cracking. Part of it was anger, at an uncertain future. The rest was because she was so close and couldn’t quite work up the will to do anything about it. The prospect of aftershock was terrifying.

“No more mountains of work, then?”

“I don’t know.”

-***-

The anger in her voice was so thick he could almost touch it, and Severus knew how much that feeling weighed - he carried it too. The rest of the world and his life seemed to go spinning out of focus, leaving behind the painfully cold floor, and her body radiating delicious heat and heavy anger.

“It seems Albus finds a fatal lack of empathy in me,” he offered. “Or at least, it seems that was what he was driving at.”

“You think that’s why he made you a teacher? Beat it into you?”

“The thought had crossed my mind”

“Anyone but him ever show you some empathy?”  Her voice was huskier, almost suggestive when she said it, and it made him squirm on the spot.

He froze mid breath again and tried to remember exactly how many times she’d said something that stole the air out of his lungs. Empathy… Albus was pretty much the only one who’d ever come close to trying in the years since his sea change.

“Not as such.”

“I’d say it’s a pity, but I know how much you hate that…”

Severus closed his eyes, though it was already dark, and tried to imagine exactly what she must look like right now sitting next to him. Her sharp angles, poisonous eyes and lush mouth seemed less like ruined potential and more like harsh, bizarre beauty after all these months.  He was able to recall most of the scars streaked across her face, but had no idea where they’d come from. He knew about the nine razor scars on her shoulder, one for every time she’d given life for an answer from a ghost (he’d counted those on occasion to keep from staring elsewhere).

The thought occurred to him again – his lips against her scars. He could almost hear her pulse, slow and steady despite the situation, unlike his which was loud and frantic.

No.  This could be fixed. He could make the hunger go away, and find himself with one fewer ache in his chest.  When it finally happened it would feel as repulsive as it had with the scant few other women he’d stumbled in to, intoxicated by alcohol and base lust or manipulation.  And neither of them would want anything to do with each other afterwards…

Taking a breath so deep it felt like his lungs might pop, he decided he was going fix this once and for all.

His hand drifted up as he shifted, fingertips counting out each scarred ridge on the meat of her shoulder, sliding across hard collar bone and up to the soft junction of her neck and shoulder. Eyes closed, all he had to do was follow the sound of her pulse before his mouth finally made contact with the spot on her neck just behind her jaw and the world was instantly reduced to the rhythm of her blood rushing under the skin, the overwhelming heat, and the strange blend of perfume and sweat.

There was a soft little sound, her lips parting perhaps, and she leaned into the kiss, pulse speeding up to match his.

More, urged some instinctual part of his brain, he complied automatically, pressing harder and opening his mouth just a little against as he moved down, following the blood rushing to her heart. Her hand found the back of his and there was a flurry of awkward movement. 

A realization struck him hard and fast -she wanted this…him.

He wound up with one arm trapped under her, the other hand nearly crushing her collar bone, and both her hands grasping the meat of his arms to try to take some of the weight off. But he kept going.

About the time he’d reached the hard edge of her shoulder the rational part of his brain managed to break through, screaming that this wasn’t making the situation any better.  Her squirming wasn’t an attempt to withdrawal, but an attempt to put herself in a position to reciprocate. He felt an icy stab of fear deep in his gut; fear of the strangeness of this situation, fear because he did not want to stop but did not really know what to do.  Severus managed to pull away by sheer force of will and straightened up as fast as he could.

It was much, much colder without the benefit of her warmth pressed snug against him and the world felt strangely alien now. He heard her swallow, hard, and smack her lips nervously.

With his cheeks burning and his brain reeling dizzily, Severus managed to keep himself completely still, waiting for what she might say. Though his judgment of time might have been a little off, it seemed like an eternity since he’d touched her, and the reverberation of the sound of her bracelets clanking seemed to last three times as long as it really should have.

Lourdes surprised him this time, reaching out to grab the first thing she could – his thigh – and in an instant her hands were at the sides of his head, fingers skipping up his jaw toward his ears.  Her mouth, soft and full, brushed his.
For a moment everything was a cross between utter confusion at this unexpected development and a desire to give in because it was soft, and warm and promising.  Just as soon as giving in may have won, a new horrible and cold thought in the back of his mind expanded suddenly and he froze on the spot.  He’d started this and he had no idea what would happen if he finished it.  After a few seconds, or perhaps it was hours, he felt her pull away.

She gave him hard shove on the shoulders.  He didn’t move.  She shoved again, and as much as he wanted to collapse and let her carry out whatever revenge she intended, he stayed put.

That was when she hit him, starting with one solid fist to the left side of his chest.  Then, a flurry of heavy contact registered, becoming less and less painful as she pounded his chest like a door she was refused entry to. He made no move to defend himself.  Finally, his elbows buckled and it was all he could do to keep his head from bouncing on the tiles as she collapsed into him and groaned.  They lay in silence for a moment, motionless with her face buried in his robes and both fists in tight knots.

“I hate this.”

It came out as a snarl, and ended as a whimper.  Her fists relaxed and she went limp.  Severus had no idea what she meant by this.  But her weight on top of him offered too many possibilities he could not entertain now. Whatever had just happened was already gone.

Severus had thought about this a few times, what it might be like to be this close, and presumably this trusted. Despite the fact that he could easily wind his arms around her, there was still the strangest tension that kept them a little more distant than he would have liked…

A few more moments of taut, awkward silence passed, and he reached up to stroke the nape of her neck in an attempt to comfort her.  He did not dare try anything else. It took a moment before his heart slowed down to a normal pace and he could pretend this was completely normal and not at all tempting.

But it was tempting.  For a few seconds there everything had vanished. The war was gone, the Dark Lord was gone, Albus was gone.  His students, this castle, the entire world, and that strange pang of hunger that had nothing to do with his stomach just…vanished. He wanted to remember exactly how it had felt but it was getting harder by the second…

“Any news from the others?” she asked weakly.  There was some comfort in her asking for mundane news about the Death Eaters.

“Nothing. Not yet.”

“And Potter - any progress with the lessons?”

“Definitely not.”

-***-

She did not move.

Some part of her she could not quite name ached, and she was infuriated by how good it had felt.  The instant she had reciprocated Severus had seemed to realize what a terrible and dangerous idea it had been, and froze. 

And here they were.

Sitting next to him in the dark she might have imagined him to be anyone.  But here, the stark hardness of his bony, ropey ascetic’s body under hers meant he could not have been any of the others.  She could smell him, aseptic potions, sweat and dirt, and hear his heartbeat.  She could not fool herself.  This was Severus, and he had pulled her in and pushed her away in the span of a minute.  In that brief flicker of time she’d been lifted higher and fallen further than she had in years.

“So where are we going from here?” she managed.

“Damage control,” Severus replied firmly. He shifted uncomfortably underneath her, and she heard his mug grind against the floor.

His hand twitched against her neck and her brain responded automatically by spinning out another daydream of heat, rhythm and pressure. It was too satisfying a sequence of thought to ignore and Lourdes squirmed a little, rolling over and using him as a pillow. Severus didn’t stop touching her though, his fingers switched to repetitively tracing the jagged edge of her ear instead of her neck.

“…more letters I suppose.” Severus’ voice drifted back into focus just then.

“Letters?” she muttered.

“Weren’t you paying attention?”

“No, not really.”

He responded with a little indignant grunt and she could imagine his face twisting into an annoyed sneer.

“Who did that to your cheek?” he said at last, voice kept low and too even.

The question yanked her firmly out of the warm, dreamy little cloud she’d been enjoying and reminded her that 18 years had passed since their time at Hogwarts. She’d had a job, lost it, been in jail and on the edge of respectability and bore the marks where anyone could see them - and wonder exactly where they’d come from.

“That’s a little out of the blue,” she sighed.

“I’ve been meaning to ask.”

I’ll bet he has… she thought darkly. The anger was a little helpful; it was something hard to hold on to.

“Ozymandias doesn’t employ Dementors. They prefer their cruelty to be cultured, and with brains. When O.H.K. wanted to send an agent in to talk to me about a serial killer who was stalking families, I refused on principle and sent him out half dead. They decided to see if the Master of Confessions could persuade me. They started here…” She reached up for his hand and guided it  the scar extending from the outer corner of her eye.

“Well, let’s just say the Confessor does not appreciate it when you don’t cry or scream, sort of takes the fun out of it for him. I think it hurt, but I don’t really remember. I just sort of concentrated and waited for him to be stupid enough to make eye contact with me. He did it right about here…” she pressed his fingers to a trench on a soft spot on her cheek dangerously close to her lips. “I just dove right in and drug up every rotten memory I could find - sent him off in a vomiting panic. And they were clever enough not to come calling after that.”

***

Without even thinking about what he was doing, Severus let his fingers race back to the jagged edge of her ear, attempting to ignore the fact that she was leaning into the touch entirely too eagerly. His brain was urging him in the opposite direction though, down the curve of the neck, over the hard ridge of the collar bone to seek something softer…

“Who did that to your ear?”

She let out a short, bitter laugh. “On my very first collar with the capture team, we went in to bust a vampire and some psychotic Muggles who wanted to be vampires, and I was the first one in. It was the stupidest rookie mistake, I caught one of the Muggles in the chest with an elbow and tackled him from the front, and well, I got his arms pinned down but that didn’t stop his teeth. Got me in the ear and on the cheek. Everyone was very impressed that I didn’t cry when they told me they weren’t going to be able to reattach it. I tell you though; I never made the mistake of hitting from the front again.

“Don’t you have any scars then? In spots acceptable for social viewing?” Lourdes yawned.

That question froze his heart in his chest. He’d worked hard to keep his skin completely unmarred, daubing on oceans of dittany, giving all his wounds with every conceivable treatment he could to remove all evidence. But there had always been the one mark he couldn’t get rid of.

“None at all,” he managed.

“No fair. And here I thought you were going to be honest.”

“I am.”

“I’m afraid I’ll need proof,” she muttered, in a playful tone garbled by a yawn.

Snorting a bit, Severus muttered something about taking his word for it and fidgeted, trying to come up with something to follow that with.

“You need to get to bed. You’re supposed to teach in the morning.” She sounded weary and annoyed this time.

“It would be best,” he said, relieved for a reason to take some of the heat off the situation.

When Lourdes extricated herself from the tangle of limbs, his skin prickled where she’d been pressed against it as if his whole body objected to her absence.  Any time he had gone to bed with a woman, he’d slipped out the door as soon as he finished.  He never stayed the night, and hadn’t wanted to. Part of him already seemed to know how satisfying it would be to sleep with her nestled against him, warm in a little cocoon of blankets after all was said and done.

There was, of course, the frightening possibility that Lourdes would want to…talk about it. Know what it meant. How could he tell her something he didn’t know?

“Lumos.” Severus winced automatically at the dim light of his wand tip, and watched Lourdes struggling to her feet.

He was only too happy to put one hand on the small of her back to guide her when she started stumbling.  And to give her another sedative without being asked, so she would be asleep, unable to talk about what just happened.

She collapsed into her bed un-aided, and fussed with her blankets until she’d spun herself up in them again. While he watched her fall asleep, feeling vaguely seedy for it, a skirmish broke out inside him. Something raw and demanding fighting the rational part violently and it made him dizzy as he plodded over to his own bed, which looked like a vast desert wasteland right now. Severus ran an inventory of what he’d need to do in the meanwhile to keep his mind off her as he stared at the wooden bed top.

The seedlings for the summer garden at Spinner's End needed to be started so he could plant as soon as it was warm enough.

There were piles of essays to mark.

Someone had to start the preliminary research for the Cruciatus formulas.

He owed Avery a very, very nasty letter…

Mixed Signals

“You were sick, but now you are well again. And there's work to be done.”~ K. Vonnegut (Kilgore’s Creed)


It was quite possibly the most satisfying shower she had ever taken.  Nothing felt quite as good as bracing her back against the cool wall while the water carried away all evidence of a stranger’s blood and the thousand year rot smell of Dementor. 

Strange, Lourdes thought as she watched the water running down her stomach change paths every time it hit her most prominent scar, she was quite used to being touched by people.  She could take a hit better than most men, and it had never bothered her to fend off a headlock. But in a fight she was a viable opponent, a real thinking, fighting target, Pettigrew’s treatment made her feel distinctly like an object. 

But then again everything made her feel like an object these days. 

Lourdes’ every nerve was frayed and raw; her skin felt hot as if she was running a fever. The only thing she wanted to do was to finish washing up before going to bed.  But there was a brief to deliver.   She felt worn and sore on the inside.  The feeling isn’t real, she thought dismissively, as she squeezed her eyes shut and turned the water up, it’s just the after effect.  The cold stream stung sharply when it hit her skin, but she didn’t particularly mind.  Fresh pain meant everything was back where it belonged, even if the slapdash reinstallation of her soul left the mind and body raw. 

Once Lourdes had donned her oldest, softest jeans with the holes at the knees and a snug T shirt, she found a few bloody little finger prints on the towels and her waistband.  She’d scrubbed so hard at her nails in the shower that all the little cuts on her fingers had broken open. 

I’ll clean up later

When Severus discovered the mess left on his towels, he’d insisted on sealing up each small cut with his wand rather than leaving her body to its own devices.  While he went about his work, he cradled her injured hand in the palm of his own- which was clammy and shaking a bit more than usual as he went about his repairs.

Repairs- just the same way it had been at O.H.K. where the healers had rushed to her first on her superior’s command.  Not because they particularly cared about her well being, but because they could not risk losing their Evocator.  Maintenance- that’s all this was, she thought blandly.  There was a sudden sense of déjà vu – that this scenario had already played out and it had not ended well for her. 

From where she stood now everything looked as though it was lining up with past events; the strange stirrings of desire borne out of work and close quarters, the danger of being involved with a coworker who might not be good for her, hanging herself with her own ambition, and a commander who might have to leave her in prison if she were caught carrying out his orders…

It’s just the shock and the Pettigrew thing.  Your perspective is a little skewed… she reminded herself.

Severus spent the next few minutes browbeating her into taking a dose of painkillers.  She only listened to half of what he said as most of it had to do with her “bravado” and “pig headedness,” and those were the nice accusations.  After a few minutes of trying to ignore him, she downed the goblet he was shoving under her nose in one gulp and followed with a rather rude hand gesture.

That shut him up.

Whatever sort of painkiller it was, it made her body feel as numb as the opium did, but her mind was nowhere near as calm as she took the long dark walk up the Head of House passage to give her report to Albus.

When Albus flung open the door to meet her, the office was filled with the buzzing, clicking, and whirring of the once-dormant instruments in his cabinets finally at work.  His expression was tense, and there were none of the usual niceties, jokes, and offers of sweets.   This was serious.  Lourdes did her best to adapt, and used her most straightforward, cool tone to deliver a fairly coherent report of the events.  And then, all she could do was brace herself and take a deep breath, unsure of what sort of response he’d give.   She had most definitely not anticipated a look of deepest disappointment from him. 

All the air left her lungs at once as suddenly as if she’d fallen flat on her back.

He was the closest thing to a commanding officer here, she thought frantically, he was duty bound to support her unless she’d broken protocol! Only there wasn’t any protocol, she thought as a familiar icy panic took over and her skin broke out into a cold sweat. 
   
“The Auror, is he all right?” she asked as coolly as she could, to get things rolling and over as soon as possible.  Her hand ran over her stomach to the spot where she’d had to stab him.

“Kingsley and Tonks report that he was quickly mended.”

“The Ministry, have they said anything about it yet?” 

“No, not a word from any corner.  They aren’t rushing to the Wireless to alert the public.  I’ve been keeping watch,” Albus gestured heavily to a stream of tickertape spewing from a heavily modified wireless unit.

“The Death Eaters are free, and I fear we’ve merely reinforced Tom’s army.  We don’t know yet if this is going to force Cornelius to come to terms with what is happening.  I fear that this was a mistake.  But what is done is done,” he finished in a dead sort of voice. 

He looked up at her with that disappointment again and sighed.

Lourdes felt the grip of pure, cold fear when she was sure that disappointment was because of her.

Visions of Hashim dressing her down with the same disappointed expression raced through her brain, and she connected that feeling, that look, with the here and now.  This was how Hashim had started to wear her down… and it wasn’t long before she was trying – desperately - to make up for every perceived mistake.  Lourdes always stood still and stony to hear the accusations, and the disappointment, swallowing every one of her objections to keep her job.  The only way she could fight that disappointment, warranted or not, was to learn all the rules and play by them, even when Hashim was just making them up as they went along. 

Here there weren’t any rules, any standards; it wasn’t her fault if she broke rules she didn’t know about!  And…if she didn’t know the rules, what was she doing here?

“I need a reason,” she heard herself say in a cold, hard voice she hardly recognized.  “Give me a reason to put up with this from you. To have to go out there with those people like I’m one of them, and then have you look at me like I’m really am, like I failed!  I’m NOT one of them Albus, I never have been.”

“Because you promised that you would.  You value your word.”  Those words fell flat in the space between them. 

Oaths, vows, department contracts, she’d put faith in all of them, and they’d all fallen from underneath her. She had this conversation before and it had ended with the same words.

Because you swore the oath – protect and serve.  What we’re asking is part of that…

 Fuck this. 

Never in her entire career had Lourdes stood up to a commanding officer.  She’d spent years thinking that the organization must know best.  In return for obedience, they were supposed to catch you when you fell carrying out their orders.  They’d sent her to prison instead…  Albus would have left her there at Azkaban, the way he’d left Podmore.  The way Hashim had left her in Ozymandias!

You can’t trust any of them. 

She was going to settle this now, make it known that she would not go quietly.

“I expect to take hits in the field, sir, that’s part of my job.  But what I don’t expect is to be dressed down like this for completing my task, inflicting as little harm as possible and avoiding capture.”  She forced the words out in a cool, crisp tone, but the top of her throat was closing up tightly.  It was very hard to breathe.

Albus seemed to be composing a response, and Lourdes had no proper concept of how long it had been since she’d spoken.  It felt like an eternity.  Striking forward like a snake, she spat old fear and new anger.

“What was I supposed to do? You don’t know!” she hissed, slamming her hands on the desk.   “You would have left me there if they’d caught me!  You’d leave us both if you thought it would damage your credibility to have to fish us out, wouldn’t you? You left Podmore! Wouldn’t want anyone to know you’ve got an Evocator up your sleeve, worried about how that might make you look aren’t you? You just get rid of things when they get too complicated don’t you? You got rid of me!  Just the same way he did…”

She paused, and felt her mouth gape open, hearing the crackle of a thousand connections making themselves in her mind.  The room, Albus, even the air went hazy as her brain shifted into over drive, and time as she knew it warped so that past and present seemed to slam together.  Lourdes dropped back into her chair, things she’d been avoiding for ages were now demanding attention, trying to tell her the same thing at a volume so high she could not make the message out. 

She could just barely tell that his face had rearranged into an expression that seemed sternly sympathetic.

“You must…accept my apology, Lourdes,” he said, in a strong, kind voice that cut through her swirling panic easily.  One wand tap on the desk later, the samovar appeared.  Albus poured a glass and sent it floating in her direction.

When her free hand shot up to wrap around the warm glass, it felt like a handle on reality.  Yes.  Tea made sense, but his apology?

“Apology?” she murmured.  She had no idea where this was going, but had the distinct feeling that she would not like it.

“After I, as you say, got rid of you, I petitioned for your acceptance to the police program through MKIP.” He gestured to her Police Academy T-shirt before continuing.  “I had imagined you would be very good at any job you chose.  I had no idea where it might take you, or who you might meet there.  I knew that after some years you had achieved your ambition to pursue the psychological end of investigation.  But as much as you have learned about the mind, as much as you already knew, I am alarmed to discover how little you know of your heart.”

“The heart hasn’t got much of a place in my line of work.  Objectivity gets the job done,” she said automatically.  Although she was not sure she meant it, it was just…what she always said.  She maintained objectivity on so many of her investigations, because so few of them touched her. 

“If objectivity was your sole modus operandi, Lourdes, I could not have brought you here.  I will not employ mercenaries.  You know all about motivation, don’t you?”  Albus asked, in the coolly curious tone she knew all too well. 

It was an interrogators tone.  …

“I know what you’re doing,” she replied in the most even, passive voice she could muster.  Almost unconsciously she felt every other thought every other feeling drain and dampen so her mind was nearly blank, and calm.

“Why did you start in the Special Operations and Security unit when you began work after your time with M.K.I.P. in Ankara?  There were so many other divisions you might have chosen from when you received you certifications…why pick the most dangerous one?”

“I hate desk jobs, and S.O.S. didn’t mind if I couldn’t use a wand.”

“And again, when you were selected for Ozel Harp Kuluru, to rescue and then to investigate? Why did you take a high stress, low pay civil servants job with such a high potential for injury?  Immersed in the worst the world had to offer you when there were so many other avenues for fame or rewards you may have taken, given your skills and your history?”

“The job suited me,” Lourdes said simply. “I like puzzles,”

“And yet you never do the crossword,” Albus said shrewdly.

“That’s not my kind of puzzle.”

“I suppose you are right.  Your line of work brought you a lot of things did it not?  Long hours and countless resources invested in the apprehension of a single person.  Weeks of carry away food and very long nights I suppose.  Not a job most would choose no matter how much the like puzzles.  So I wonder Lourdes why you picked this kind of puzzle?”

His tone was maddeningly gentle just then, as if he were a parent asking the child where they’d gone wrong…  

“It was always to survive. I had to make a living. There was no shame in doing something I’m good at.”  Lourdes could never really say exactly why she was good at it, but she knew why she liked it.  She had picked dangerous jobs that fed her most instinctual curiosity, or her need to do something she could account for at the end of the day.   The money never mattered, she had never been unhappier than when she had to simply deal books, though she’d never had been richer.  When she was at OHK, in either division, she had been as happy as it was possible to be when your life revolved around work.

No one questioned her skill as an investigator as they had her magic. If she simply played by the rules and kept her nose clean, the job was supposed to bring her praise and excitement; achievements she had thought could not be killed or taken away.  

“The job, in many ways, suits the best and worst aspects of you perfectly,” Albus interrupted.  “No, when I apologized I meant to say that I am sorry for having taken away your reason, as you say.  I suspect that after you realized you could not have your families back, you worked because it was the only thing that made you happy, and the things the job would bring to you are not as easy to lose as people.”

There was an urgent, beckoning quality in his expression now, as if he was standing a mile ahead waiting for her to catch up.  Or perhaps he was waiting with baited breath for her to take just one more step.

“I liked my job, I liked being good at it…”  She paused and took a deep breath, now keenly aware that she was about to put a foot down in a trap of sorts.  Lourdes squeezed her eyes shut, anticipating the pain of being caught.

“But the motivations and assurances that drove you day to day before must not satisfy you here as they did before.   You said it yourself not moments ago, you have completed all the tasks myself and Voldemort have set you on.   You’ve completed them well, even without the full benefit of Severus’ help.  If excelling at the work is enough, why have you asked me for a reason?”  He raised his eyebrows expectantly and tented his fingers.

She didn’t answer, her brain was throbbing and wasn’t really in any shape to be playing mind games.

“You already have your reason Lourdes, though right now I wonder if you realize it.  And I wonder who you might be, with your skill and your drive, if had I not taken you away from my brother, from your friend,” he replied in a gentle sort of voice.

“Don’t change the subject. If you’re not going to support me when I follow your orders through without fail then there’s no way I can do this. I’m not going back to jail because of bad orders or another change of heart… So give me a reason,” she said darkly.

“Let us speak frankly - there was no great reward for you here and you knew that in coming.  Even though you were correct those months ago when I presented you the task of working with Severus.  You did not have to fight, spy, or follow any order once your contract was broken.  But here you are.   Why did you come Lourdes? Everything you won before was taken away, even though you sought it out because you believed it could not be lost. ” There was that look on his face again, waiting for her to catch up…

“That wasn’t all I wanted!” Lourdes’ hands froze in mid air as if she were trying to clutch something.   “I wanted… to do something that made me happy.  What did I have left but work?   If I don’t work, I slow down.  If I slow down I have time to think about all the things I don’t have because you took them away.

“Let’s not pretend you brought me here because you want me happy!  You brought me here because of what I am, not who!”  Those last words were embarrassingly childish and spiteful, but she’d said them and they could not be taken back.

“You know that isn’t true Lourdes.  Though you are one of a handful of what you are, as you say, there are a hundred other things I might have done instead of recruiting you if I were only concerned about the ‘what,’ and not the ‘who.’  I have already told you that what I value most is your skill and knowledge.   If you wish me to give you a reason, let us follow your old pattern and say the reason is to work.  Work with us, keep your mind off the things you think you do not have. 

“But I cannot pretend that I don’t pity your unhealed wounds.   Was there no one in Turkey who you could have loved, or made family?  Or did you hesitate and distance yourself because you feared loosing anyone you might grow to love?  Drowning yourself in work and its rewards would have kept you safe from that particular sadness, but I fear it also made you as miserable as ever in the end. When you asked what I could give you in return I offered you very nearly anything.  The only thing you asked for was to come home.  Is that not reason enough?  It’s your responsibility to find out if you have the strength to embrace the things you fear losing, or if you would prefer to remain in the same path that’s kept you safe though unhappy…”

Albus exposed her without pity, and it struck her with dizzying force to have her façade stripped away so quickly.  He knew she had nothing to stand on anymore, that she had lost everything…  Her hand flew instinctually to the spot where the demon wound had been.  She was alarmed to find it closed up, even though it had been that way for months now.

“We have all been damaged, Lourdes, but some of us have found courage enough to heal.” There was a strange tightening in her gut, as her brain flashed images of the old raw wound and connected them to Albus’ words- she had not healed on her own, she had no courage…

“I’m not a coward,” she said shakily.  It was true; she’d faced every task that had been laid in front of her without flinching, hadn’t she?  She’d taken the Dark Mark, looked the Dark Lord in the eye, and stormed the Dementors without a flicker of cowardice…

“You do not shy away from a task when you know you have control,” he said firmly.  “But you’ve yet to discover the courage it takes to have faith in anything other than your mind and protocols.  You’ve only seen the worst of what people, yourself included, can do Lourdes.  For that, I am sorry.”

That was the last thing he said to her before he quietly guided her to the passage door, gently prying the empty tea glass out of her hand before dismissing her with the air of a disappointed parent.  In the tunnel, on her way back down to Severus' quarters, Lourdes felt a sick wave of claustrophobic panic.  She hit the wall and sank to the floor, wobbling on the balls of her feet before she fell all the way down.

Everything in the world was wrong now.  Albus had just exposed a weakness and wounds she had doggedly ignored. 

He was manipulating her, she thought frantically.  All this garbage about courage and the worst in people was just slapping a thick coat of rhetoric on a rotten structure.  Albus was just like anyone else- he just wanted to win, didn’t he?  Who did he have in his life? An alienated brother?  Distant colleagues? He was as much a hermit in a tower as she was!

You only see the worst in people…

There was a dizzy flash of heat somewhere in her brain and she felt an airless panic and anger trapped in her chest. 

How to get it out? 

Scream.  She didn’t feel like arguing, so she forced herself up on her elbows and bellowed at the top of her lungs with the reminder that this was a dungeon; it had been built to contain noise like that…

She kept it up until her throat was raw and her stomach hurt from sheer tension.  It was the simplest thing in the world to do right then, an easy outlet for unfamiliar feelings. Afterwards things felt a little lighter- as if just enough pressure had been relived to keep her from exploding.  Lourdes slid down back down to the floor again.  Everything felt alien right now, her body, her brain, this damp tunnel. 

Thoughts began to run muddy.  It was hard to separate one feeling, one thought, from any other.  The chaos did not sit well with her…

She tried an Occlumens trick to right herself; reorganize, separate, sort.  Pulling an old thought out of the mess slowly to feel it again- Aberforth was the first live thing to surface.  Aberforth in the third summer she’d spent with him, fussing over a boom of springtime kids.  They’d all been weak that year, born too early when it was too cold.  They spent the evenings swaddling, medicating, and keeping the poor creatures warm. 

She could remember holding squirming bundles wrapped in flannel, tiny goats with floppy ears and a velvet soft muzzle grazing her chest as the kid moved its head around looking for a familiar sound - a heartbeat.  There was something good. 

It was a reason- her surrogate father who’d shown her how to be a surrogate to the goats, she could work to protect that.  She held on to that notion and thought harder about other good things she could remember:  her favorite patrons of the Hog’s Head, the memories of her parents, and the once-close friend she’d had in Severus. 

Severus… that was lost now wasn’t it?  She’d destroyed any chance of moving closer into orbit with him when she’d attacked him months ago. It wasn’t as if she could expect forgiveness given all that she’d said, and what she knew about him.  Thinking of Severus suddenly made her insides move like eels in a tank because nobody ever knew, and Aberforth only suspected, how quickly she’d come to be infatuated with him after they started doing lessons together.  
   
It was hard not to get close to someone when you routinely broke into their mind and had access to the memories and thoughts that shaped them.  Lourdes had seen all sorts of things in Severus; beautiful memories from very early years with his parents when they were still healthy, the frightened feelings of being too small to fix the problems that made life slide down hill-  all the things that made him who he was.  He’d seen the same things in her mind - she hadn’t learned to hide herself then.  He saw who she was and stopped seeing what she was. 

Severus was, like it or not, the one living person who knew more about her than anyone else.  It was frustrating in a way to know that she couldn’t control the way he saw her.  She couldn’t execute the task of moderating every second of her behavior and every possible external cue in her life to convince him  that she was icy, strictly work minded, or completely uninhibited, unattached and that she won every time.  He already knew who she was, as did Albus, and there were precious few places to hide from the two of them now.

Once she’d dragged herself back to Severus’ quarters, she ignored him doggedly and went straight to the bedroom.  She was feeling too raw and too exposed to bear contact with anyone but herself right then, and was perfectly content to lick her wounds in privacy like an animal.  She lay in bed on her back in the dark willing herself to fall asleep, but there were no case files to read, and no research projects that needed her attention.  The utter absence of anything to take her mind off the situation made her frantic.

She’d crack, Lourdes thought, if she couldn’t just get to sleep.  Quiet as a ghost, she rummaged through his nightstands and under his mattress for anything that might put her down.  A thorough search of the bathroom yielded nothing either.

The last resort was that Baku Philter Severus had given her ages ago, and had not taken away the last time she tried to sleep through her anger. She drank a quarter of the bottle in one go, leaving her with hardly enough time to re-cap it before she dropped heavily onto Severus’ massive bed with one of her pillows.  As her eyelids sagged shut, she felt all the muddy memories and thoughts that had been so violently stirred up sinking like so much silt settling, leaving the body of water clear and calm again.
She sank down into heavy sleep underneath the weight of all those thoughts, all those feelings and forgot to dream at all.

-***-

It was damn exhausting to be alive right now.  Severus felt numb most of the time as if he were moving in slow motion and the rest of the world was whizzing past.  Severus stood with his hands braced on either side of the Pensieve, looking down on the memories that he’d just poured out.

Tonight was an Occlumency evening.

Other than the Occlumency lessons, not much of note had happened in the week after the breakout.  The Prophet reported it of course, obscuring enormous chunks of information regarding the break, publishing only the bare essentials.  Whether this was at the request of the Ministry or not, Severus could not be sure.   The staff of Hogwarts had promptly been banned from sharing any information about the break or assuaging student fears by the issue of a new Ministry gag.  Fair enough.

However, some of his Slytherins were acting up and out, emboldened by the escape.  He’d done his best to station himself in their vicinity when students whose families had been victims of the Death Eaters passed, to discourage any unseemly taunting.   Not that his presence affected that little Malfoy idiot, who made it clear he was ready to get his Dark Mark right now.  And Severus hadn’t even managed to get anything useful from Draco.  He’d had to squeeze the boy for information about Potter when he’d stopped by earlier that evening.

It was with great relish that Severus turned his lip up at the little twit and told Draco that he hoped this new responsibility as Umbridge’s thug would not affect the Slytherin team’s chance of winning the cup. That would keep Draco out of his hair for a good while, and so much the better, Severus didn’t fancy seeing more students after hours.  With the task of teaching Potter in the evenings, Severus’ free time was pared down considerably.

The free time might not have been an issue, but Potter was not even trying.  It was not a difficult request; self restraint, a modicum of control and an effort to simply allow his mind to go blank.  He’d seen Potter's eyes during Potions lessons, a blank mind would be no great feat. Yet he seemed to resist out of spite.

There was a knock on the door.  Speak of the devil and he shall appear…

“Enter,” Severus said, low and calm as he could manage.  Potter slunk in, looking guilty as always and sunk round-shouldered into the chair in front of Severus’ desk.

This lesson was no different from any other.  The first few tries were dismal.  Clear your mind, Severus would instruct, let go of your feelings.  But with almost no effort at all Severus evaded Potter’s every defense and was able to wrench up any stream of memories.

“I might be able to do it,” Potter hissed, from his usual spot curled up in a ball on the floor, “if you told me how!”

“Sit.  Gather your thoughts,” Severus said coldly.  He pointed one finger, still shaking slightly, to Potter’s chair before sinking slowly into his own.

Explanations, he fumed, Potter wanted explanations.  Was Severus also supposed to figure out how Potter's miniscule mind worked and then devise an infantile list of steps on how to shut it down?  You either could, or you couldn’t, that was the only explanation Severus could provide.  Albus should have known that.

And then there was the scar, which peeked through the rat's nest of hair as Potter breathed heavily across from him, shooting Severus a vicious look.

Bitter bile rose in Severus’ throat every time he laid eyes on that scar… every time he thought about it.  That scar, that leftover link between Potter and the Dark Lord was a sort of Dark Mark in itself.

Potter hadn’t even earned it.

For a fraction of a second, Severus felt revulsion at himself because he had earned the brand on his arm.  Worked for it, wanted it.  Now, he all he wanted was for the damn thing to simply disappear so he could just forget.  Severus was vaguely aware that his fingers were halfway through the process of twitching across his lap towards his left arm, and he was leaning forward like a cobra deciding whether it should strike.

Deep breath, relax, lean back.

Lived… Potter hadn’t even really lived - no, survived - on his own.  A bawling infant that dripped and wailed mindlessly had not defeated the Dark Lord.  

Lily’s sacrifice was responsible for Potters vaunted survival.  Her sacrifice was hardly the baby’s boon.  Yet that child had replaced Severus, twice.  Once as a baby and now as an inept teenager who could hardly stand on his own.  It wasn’t as if Potter was special, remarkable, or even clever.  He had no discernable talents of his own, outside of the Patronus and that odd ability to lead his friends astray and break the rules without being punished.

Potter was, after all, the favorite. 

Exceptions would be made if it was Potter; Potter could be the youngest and fourth competitor in a TriWizard tournament.  Potter could stalk around Hogsmeade without a permission form.  Potter could set an escapee from Azkaban on the world. Potter could be made head boy even though he had never been a prefect and rarely behaved well. As far as Severus could tell, there was no difference between father and son, save for their eyes.  They were both detestable thieves...  Though Potter’s son had stolen something that was worth far less than what his father had taken.

None of that mattered, apparently, everyone wanted to believe Potter now because they all placed their faith in a teenage boy.  That this insolent, unimaginative, and often stupid teenager would have the strength to defeat the Dark Lord…

It was supposed to be me; that thought sprang to mind so violently that Severus nearly had to shut down his brain entirely.

Severus remembered being the one Albus had faith in, the one who might have been the hero, when he might have gotten what he deserved.  Seeing that faith transferred to so unworthy a recipient meant every moment spent alone with the usurping Potter was added insult to injury. 

Insult to injury?  That’s putting it lightly, Severus thought.  He hated the child who had stolen his place, his fame, his honor. Potter would know how it was going to feel when this war ended and his name would be shouted and praised. He hated the child’s father – who took Lily away from him.

He hated the child who had taken Lily away from him.

“Up Potter. We’ll try again.”

Standing at the ready Potter steeled himself to try to repel another attack. 

“Legilimens!”

The pricking-hot feeling of Potter's anger washed over his brain first, followed by a blur of un-important memories.  Hot and sour anger at a fat woman with a fat dog.  A mournful ache as he watched a blond pig of a boy unwrap a mountain of presents.  The tingling feeling of un-cried tears blurring a vision of dust motes dancing in the light filtered through cracks in a room too small to be a room.

Cool darkness, the sound of feet on stone, a point of light at the end of a long stone hallway.  An unbearable ache high in his stomach that moved into his throat as a hand that did not belong to him reached out to touch a door that was still too far away…

The Department of Mysteries…again. 

Severus broke the spell too quickly, to spite Potter. A considerate Legilimens would have slipped out quietly to avoid giving both parties the ringing headache that came along with too many thoughts stirred up too quickly.  Severus usually gave no clue that he was stealthily perusing student thoughts, but here in the lessons it did not matter.

Because Potter was still dreaming about the Department of Mysteries, and Severus suspected in the bitter pit of his stomach that Potter was trying to deliberately out-do him once again.  Severus glared at him as he dragged himself up off the floor; the stupid boy was welcoming the dream.  Welcoming the chance to look through the Dark Lord’s eyes and pass the information on the way he had when Arthur Weasley had been attacked. 

Oh, Potter loved being the hero, didn’t he?  Loved being…special.

No, Potter, you are not special, Severus thought vehemently. He had to bite his tongue to keep the words from spilling out.  It is not your job to find out what the Dark Lord is planning. It’s mine.

Potter wanted that too, did he?  Did Potter want to watch torture, and spend fourteen years watching every word, maintaining every connection in a network of people that would turn his stomach?  Did Potter want to live in limbo, chained to a teacher’s desk with a quill marking down essays while his contemporaries rose ever higher in their fields?  Did Potter want to live every day as though he were starving – not for food, nothing that simple, but for something that could never be reclaimed? 

It didn’t matter, Potter couldn’t have the job.  

It’s MINE.

“That’s enough for one day,” Severus said coolly. 

Severus dismissed the boy for the night with the usual warning to let his mind go blank and passive before he fell asleep; not that Potter would actually do the homework despite the fact that it was mind numbingly easy.  Potter's inevitable failure to master Occlumency would be Severus’ boon.  Stopping the lessons meant Severus would not be pinched painfully between the Dark Lord and Albus, and Potter’s failure would prove that he was not as clever as everyone thought…

But it was not, for once, entirely Potter’s fault that he was here after hours failing miserably, Severus thought numbly as he drifted through the door leading from his office to his quarters.  Some of the blame could be laid on Albus who would not deal with Potter at all.  Albus’ resistance pushed a niggling splinter of resentment under Severus’ skin.  Didn’t he know how badly this assignment squashed Severus between the two sides, the danger it put both spies in?  What the hell was he avoiding? 

For a second Severus thought he heard that cord snap, the tether of Albus’ trust, and he had had no idea why Albus would take the trust away.  Had Black’s words, I don’t care if Dumbledore thinks you’ve reformed, I know better, sunk in?  Severus had to control a brief, sweaty moment of panic at that thought.

Was Severus spending all those hours down there training his replacement?  Who needed a spy in the flesh if you had one who could circumvent all the tedious networking and delve straight into the Dark Lord’s mind?

What would he have if he could no longer spy?

Nothing.  He would have absolutely nothing.  That struck him with the cold force of a wave, nearly pulling him under into complete panic.

No, that was unreasonable!  If there was something, if Severus was suspected, wouldn’t Albus have the dignity to tell him?  Albus was nothing if not forthright… usually.  Severus vowed to concentrate on assuring Albus that he was the best man for this job, and he spread his net wide to see what letters and tidbits of information he could catch from the other Death Eaters with the new status and respect won through Lourdes.

Happily, when Potter was not in his sight, it was easy enough to forget about him because there were so many other things to worry about.  Tonight was a swimming night.  He dutifully went through the motions of dressing to swim and escorting Lourdes down through the corridors to the pool.

Then there was the problem of Lourdes herself, Severus thought, giving her a sideways glare as her body broke the surface and she became little more than a blur under the water.  She’d become a walking bomb since she’d come back bruised from the Azkaban outing.  Only he didn’t know when she was set to explode, or how hard he would need to jostle her to set her off.  He wasn’t exactly sure why she was so angry, but he had a pretty good idea based on his own experiences dealing with Albus.  

There wasn’t much opportunity to ask her either.  Lourdes did two things now that she had no projects: she slept and she swam.  Despite Severus’ stern warning that she should keep exercise light until they knew for sure that she hadn’t sustained any deep organ injuries

It was not as easy to concentrate on keeping his strokes even and precise when his mind was more occupied with the business of her.  Severus stopped once in awhile to watch her, doing his best to avoid being caught staring, because it wasn’t just her attitude he was assessing.

The attraction would not be rationalized.  There was something about being the subject of Lourdes’ full focused attention that was a little bit like being an ant under a magnifying glass on a sunny day.  That peculiar intensity made her hell in an interrogation room, but the other side to that coin was that when Lourdes focused that raw gaze on you in any positive sense, you began thinking like she did.  That if you just fought harder or thought harder you could do anything. 

But that was not a complete explanation.  He would have been perfectly satisfied to keep her at arms length and secretly, grudgingly, admire that un-nameable quality from a distance.  This time the thought of maintaining quiet distance upset him, and called up something raw and demanding in his gut, a feeling that was both familiar and alien

Severus put that thought on hold, gaze drifting over to Lourdes when she hauled herself out of the water and stood under the spray of the poolside shower to wash the chemicals off.  As long as she kept her eyes closed, he was free to look wherever he liked.  Somewhere along the line she’d traded adolescent awkwardness for a sleek, rangy ease that made him think of a tiger leisurely pacing its corner of the jungle.  He made another slow, visual run up the length of her legs, across the plane of her stomach, up and over the modest rise-and-curve of her breasts all the way to the calm smile on her lips.

The sight triggered a greedy hunger that made him feel as if someone had torn out a vital organ his body was frantic to get back.   This disturbing sensation was not quite lust and not quite longing.  Whatever it was, it hurt in a very unfamiliar way.  As soon as he saw her reach for the water tap, he looked away and began the process of toweling off.

Lourdes was not…her.  She could never be.   Lourdes would not ever be the first beautiful thing he had ever seen.  She was too sharp, too dark, too hard.  Lourdes would not ever be the first face which had always been full of light.  Lily’s joy and curiosity had been the only thing that ever sated the primal hunger all children had, all adults for wonder, beauty, and joy.  They were things Severus had rarely experienced, and could not produce for himself.   He needed those things like he needed air, and without Lily in his life in those last years of school, he had run a deficit of them Lourdes could not really fill.  Lourdes would never be the enchanting, radiant, joyful girl who lit up the room, charmed everyone, who saw good where there was scarcely any.   

Lourdes was too much like him.

And yet…this new hunger and hurt persisted.

They did not speak when it was time to go back to his quarters.  She merely gave him an expectant look before he transformed her into a moth for transportation, and then proceeded to ignore him and guzzle sleeping potions as soon as he was in the bathroom.  He doled out sedatives to her get her out of his hair, out of his sight, but it wasn’t taking her off his mind.

Severus passed the feather bed on his way out of the bath, and frowned at the little shape sleeping there. It had been a week since the Death Eaters' escape, and something about the experience still seemed to be following her around like a ghost. It had set her on edge, and it wouldn’t be long before she couldn’t run from it anymore.

It was down to sink or swim now.

And they couldn’t afford her sinking, not with all the Death Eaters fresh out of prison and eager to please. They were in the thick of it, able to access the Master and tap any line of information any time they could manage it. Not like him and Lourdes; they had to rely on the damn letters.

With her body twisted up in the sheets she looked like an unfortunate insect trapped in a spider web. Lourdes squirmed in her bundle of covers and his stomach squirmed with her.

It wasn’t as if he’d asked for all this, or even looked for it. It had just sort of... happened.

Feeling numb and oddly disconnected, Severus drifted back to bed and tried to just lay still and drift off. But that feeling and the vicious pounding headache from the Occlumency lessons made it damn hard to fall asleep as he lay in bed willing his insides to stop their rebellion. He let the culpable thoughts about her slip through his consciousness into dormant darkness so he could find a way to sleep without them rattling around his brain and guts, perhaps eventually he would make sense of them.

That small, stunned smile that made him feel as though he were falling with no place to land…

Her skinny little hand lighting on top of his and leaving behind a warm electric trail…

Watching the path the water took when it ran down the angles and curves of her body…

With those thoughts and images slipping away, other memories reeled themselves out as he fell into the quiet place between full sleep and waking.

Of being small, being helpless, being scared….

Damage Control

War makes thieves and peace hangs them.  ~George Herbert

 

Lourdes spent most of the hours leading up to her soul removal sorting through her old Capture Unit gear. Metin, her partner during her full time service in the unit, had conveniently “forgotten” to confiscate her gear when they raided her home during the arrest. Not that it would have done the department any good to take it; it certainly wasn’t going to fit anyone else.

 

To their credit, O.H.K. had done a brilliant job designing strike uniforms; the body suits covered everything except the head and fingers past the second joint, but they were outlandishly expensive because they were made of rubbery Graphorn hide, seams hand stitched with reinforced unicorn hair. Graphorn replaced the cheaper dragon hide favored by most M.L.E. teams because if properly tanned, Graphorn still retained the ability to deflect spells- not that the initial impact of the magic was diminished.  Lourdes’ had been tooled with specific incantations, runes, and her own amulets by a leather charmer for extra protection.

It was a pity, though, that they’d never figured out how to dye it without degrading its ability to protect, the murky gray-purple had earned the capture unit several unflattering nicknames. Name calling and fashion faux pas aside, the gear had saved her life more times than she could properly count. Severus caught her while she was straining to examine the effect of the suit on her backside in the mirror, and his only response had been a sort of grim smile and cocked eyebrow. “Oh, fine for you to laugh, but try being the only woman on a capture team wearing that! I looked like I got off a shift at an S&M club,” Lourdes objected, with a frustrated gesture at the complicated seams, zips and molded armored plates necessary to make thick leather fit a female figure. Well, she thought, at least it still fit nicely, which meant she was back in working shape and wouldn’t have to spend time letting the seams out. Truthfully she was nervous, she hadn’t participated in a raid in four years, but the ritual of preparing her gear and taking care of her weapons helped ease her anxiety a little bit. This was the second time in the past few months that she’d realized exactly how deep in she was, and how one hundred and fifty percent illegal it was to be ‘spying’ for a militia within a terrorist cell without the government’s express approval.   She was no longer toeing the line – the line was long gone. That evening, as she looked over what had once been her uniform, Lourdes stewed over the memories that had resurfaced over the past few days. Thoughts of collars, good and bad, with the capture team and everything about life with O.H.K. drifted lazily through her brain. Once, she’d been the one they wanted on the case, not because of the magic but because she was a damn good profiler, and hell to face in an interrogation room.  Her post in Behavioral Analysis had been the best time in her adult life.  Hashim left her alone and in effectively in charge for the last five years while he tried to engineer his political career. Work there pleased her; she enjoyed every facet of it – picking the cases, grading her team, going on the hunt, and being completely unfettered by the sticky bureaucratic end of the work.  And there was no denying that she loved the attention it brought her and the department when her team succeeded. Considering those motivations, she wasn’t so sure now that she ought to be all that proud of any success she had there. Not when Lourdes knew others in the Order were playing for higher stakes; family, friends, and that slippery concept of ‘the safety of the world,’ instead of awards and headlines in the professional journals. She’d never made time for high stakes, not after having lost two families and an only-friend.

                                                                                                                                                                                          

More unwelcome memories surfaced when she thought of family. As the last child of an undertaker, she’d insisted on being allowed to take care of the bodies, and still vividly remembered the clink of bullet slugs dropping into the kidney dish as she fished them out one by one, dutifully sewing up each hole. Even wizards could not resist cold lead. All of the funerals had been taken care of as instructed; some were cremated, some embalmed, some just buried, but her father had always been a special case.  It had been no mean feat for a thirteen year old girl to wheedle and fight the Iranian Zoroaster into letting her use one of the Towers of Silence for her father. But she’d managed, and for the first time Lourdes started to believe that she could do anything as long if she worked or fought hard enough. There was no fight for her father’s memory here; hell, she didn’t even have a position here really worth protecting. That new resentment had been sparked by the arrival of several letters addressed to Severus. Only to Severus - which made Lourdes painfully aware that she didn’t hold the same level of sway he did, not even close. Now even the Carrows cut him a wide berth when he walked through a crowd of Death Eaters. He’d finally reached a steady little plateau in his ascent up the confidences of the Dark Lord. But Lourdes didn’t even have a name as far as they were concerned; the Dark Lord, and everyone else, referred to her as ‘lich’ and ‘corpse’ (or irritatingly, in Malfoy’s case, as “Severus’ pet”). So far, Severus had been good enough never to bring it up outside of the presumptuous contact letters from other Death Eaters, who were eager to latch onto the coat tails of someone rising through the ranks as quickly as he was. She remained a mere object, simply an inhuman extension of Severus’ power. Lourdes hated the whole ugly concept, in spite of herself and her constant reminders that there was no shame in failing to be recognized in this arena. But it was the principle of the matter, the mere thought that she was being used by Severus the way she’d been exploited by Hashim… Lourdes froze at that thought, slumping down over the table with her head on her arms, taking a deep breath to try to banish the feeling that she was coming apart at the seams. She could hardly imagine how long Severus had lived under the strain, but all his seams were apparently unbreakable. Speaking of Severus, he seemed beyond nervous about her assignment (it really would be a shame, she thought bitterly, for him to loose such a useful tool to an incompetent guardian) and had worked himself into a bit of a frenzy. He rushed between his office and the kitchen, muttering and hissing when he ought to be answering those letters or reading up on the Occlumency books. “Have you got a potions holster in this mess?” he snapped, swooping down over the table to scowl into the pile of leather. Lourdes held up a dragon-hide belt covered with little compartments and pockets and an assortment of knife holsters. “Standard issue,” she said, to avoid hissing I am the trained professional, you know.

“You’re bringing a knife then? Do you think that will do you any good?”

 

“The six and a half meter rule applies Mr. Snape, within six and a half meters the trained short blade user has the advantage, I can be at your side causing pain, debilitation or death in one point twenty five seconds - long before you can aim and hit.  Outside that distance I have other options.”

“Good.” Severus slammed down the little tray he was carrying and seated himself across from her.

“What’s all this?” she asked, raising an eyebrow and gesturing to the tiny bottles and ampoules glittering in the tray. “Measures to assure that I won’t be planning your funeral,” he replied in a very matter-of-fact tone. “You will be able to handle the Dementors with few problems, you say?” “They’ll be too distracted once I split the first one open- like throwing breadcrumbs at a flock of pigeons. With my soul out I’ll be able to manage contact with them long enough to do my work. It won’t be like it was at the castle.” “In any case, chocolate,” he huffed, sliding a wrapped up chunk over to her. “Chocolate.” Lourdes struggled to keep a very serious expression; in truth it felt ridiculous to put sweets in her tactical belt. “Dragon’s breath.” He slid three little glass ampoules shaped like chili peppers towards her. “Break the ampoule with your teeth and you get about thirty seconds of fire breathing. The potion is designed to be resistant to saliva so your mouth will be fine, but be careful of your eyebrows and hair. Three ampoules of Garroting Gas, and two Strengthening Solutions, and for your escape plan should they decide to abandon you…” Severus neatly laid out six wrapped wads about the size of very large gobstoppers, with an expression that suggested he was giving up a dearly held treasure. “Six hours of Gillyweed. That should give you more than enough time to swim to shore. You are bringing the compass, correct?” Lourdes held up the little gold, glass topped tin with a tiny map of Britain painted on the bottom where the compass directions should have been. The needle was charmed to point towards Hogwarts at all times. Considering that it was the personal property of the Headmaster, it was extraordinarily generous of him to lend it to her, considering the circumstances. “I’ve got enough Muggle money to call the safe house if I can make it to a telephone. You don’t have anything for hypothermia in there, do you?” He sighed, and slid several potions in screw top phials over towards her. “The potion in the red phial is for hypothermia, the potions in the blue bottles are powerful analgesics without sedative effects.”

 

After arranging the assortment of phials and packages in the belt’s various compartments, Lourdes strapped the belt on to make sure she’d remember where she put what, along with her respective daggers. Then it was with some cold dread that she approached her trunk to get the chalk and the guides for the soul removal… -***- Severus hadn’t ever seen a soul removal before, and he was rather curious about the process, but unfortunately his lessons would keep him from witnessing it. Albus had loaned out Helga Hufflepuff’s solar for the affair as it was quiet, out of the way, and had a sufficiently smooth floor for Lourdes to draw on. As far as he knew, Lourdes had spent the better part of fifteen hours in a state of ecstatic meditation in the middle of the most elaborate spell system he’d ever seen. When Severus rushed to the solar in the middle of supper he found her sitting still as a cemetery statue (and about as cheerful looking) on a battered chair. The floor had been wiped down and a little silver Ghau set with a chunk of red coral sat on the table, sparkling innocently in the late afternoon light. She’d already suited herself up in tactical gear (Severus did his best not to stare ungainly when confronted with Lourdes in second skin leather), fringe pinned back and the rest of her hair secured under a knitted cap with her cloak and mask ready.  He’d never actually seen a Dementor’s Kiss, but soul removals were supposed to be beyond horrible to watch and beyond horrible to experience, and it showed. Lourdes seemed… grayer somehow; her skin, her hair, just about every thing looked lifeless. Only her eyes retained any real color. “Here,” Lourdes muttered, standing up and snatching the Ghau on its chain off the table. As she passed, Lourdes looped the chain around his neck, and when her fingers brushed his face he couldn’t help shuddering. She was as cold as a stone. The forest was disturbingly quiet for this time of day, as was Lourdes. While they waited near a group of trees, Severus pretended to be absorbed in collecting tree bark to avoid talking to her in this state. Mercifully, within minutes of their arrival, a flash of drab brown scuttled over his boots and a short, watery eyed little man appeared with a look that was part simpering, part shrewd. “Lich,” Pettigrew squeaked, though his eyes were assessing her thoroughly as she pulled her robes and mask on over the tactical gear. “Pettigrew,” she replied flatly, tugging her hood into place. This whole affair and the first Occlumency lesson, which he was probably going to be late for, made Severus’ stomach churn. Pettigrew could not be trusted with his old friends, let alone someone who had the potential to be a very heavy burden. He had to send Lourdes out unprotected, and the thought crashed against him like a cold wave, a nervous shock that spread from his heart down to his fingertips. Severus had to ball his hands up in his pockets and breathe deeply to keep himself from shaking. A hundred imagined experiences rushed his brain for just a moment, not just of what would happen to her, but what would happen to him if she was absent. That seat across the tea table had been empty for years, but now he could not imagine seeing it empty again. He did not want to pass the feather mattress in the corner at night and not see the familiar outline of her body, asleep. There was the thought that she would just vanish as she had before, taking all the years and hours with her. He hadn’t prepared himself for this sudden panic. What had his last words to her been before?
