As if you could conjure that thing up… Just as Pettigrew was about to take her arm for a Side Along, Severus leaned in to whisper in her half-ear. “You’ll live.” There was no questioning tone, no shadow of doubt. It was more of a command than anything else. What else could he tell her?  Her only response was a knowing smile and a sly sideways look. Severus turned and dropped a hand on Pettigrew’s shoulder, flashing a thin, venomous smile as he hissed, “If you do not return the body in one reasonably functioning piece, I will make sure the Dark Lord lets me soften you up for him, Peter. Why, I think the little punishment he might give me for ah…accidentally killing you would be entirely worth it.” He took a step back as Pettigrew snatched Lourdes’ wrist hastily and the two of them vanished. His skin, his whole body, felt oddly heavy and sluggish as he turned on his heel and started back to the castle.

 

It must have been the cold. -***- Of course she would live, Lourdes thought patiently; after all, here she sat positively surrounded by vital force. For an Evocator, a clean soul removal turned things around in the head, dredging up centuries old instincts.  Disconnected completely from concientia she had only her rational thought to guide her actions.  But she could see the life burning off her body and the four others in the little boat with her as the seconds ticked steadily by. The presence of all that warm, abundant life summoned a primal hunger in the back of her brain that she had to work very hard to control. Thinking it better not to stare at the veritable buffet surrounding her, Lourdes chose to watch the sun die for the night, while the grey, watery curve of the earth began to blur into the dark sky. With a tap of Malfoy’s wand, the little boat and its passengers became invisible. They bobbed with the waves while the Auror’s Guard Boat, out checking for bodies in the ocean no doubt, rounded the corner of Azkaban towards the guard Auror’s island and vanished. The Death Eaters were quick on their feet; Lourdes was pushed onto a broom behind Pettigrew while McNair and Gibbon mounted brooms of their own, each with a bundle of spare brooms tied underneath. When the second the party was airborne, Malfoy flicked his wand again, causing the boat to groan and vanish into the sea. While Lourdes sat precariously balanced on that little strip of wood, she had to bite down hard on her lip to restrain her eager, squirmy hunger (was this how vampires felt when they were around warm, blood-filled bodies?) for the life trapped in Pettigrew. After just a few minutes, he elbowed her hard, signaling her to slide off the broom and land as gracefully as could be expected on the ground. He retreated into the black mass of water and sky, leaving her stranded on the darkest, dreariest slab of lifeless rock she’d ever seen. When Lourdes took a deep breath, she smelled the centuries of death and decay… The Dementors had found her. In this state, they looked stranger than usual. In addition to the swirling masses of black, she saw a warm glow of light through their robes and carcasses, right in their centers, making them look like so many little milky galaxies floating in mid air. They had no lives she could see, nothing burned off them. They seemed suspended in their state of decay, happy to thumb the spot where their noses might have been at the whole concept of time. Instinctive cold sweat broke out on her skin as she stood, ready to pounce while the Dementors circled; they didn’t seem to know what to do with her. At least thirty voices whispered hoarsely, disorienting her, making her feel like she was going to spiral away, until she remembered to put a hand on the hilt of her father’s dagger; it gave her a good feeling of control, something solid under her feet like a ocean floor in a heavy tide. The whispering sounded like logical conversation now; they were urging each other to discover the nature of the intruder. One Dementor reached out cautiously to touch her and recoiled as if burned. Lourdes forced herself to remain still, trying not to inhale too deeply as the Dementors from the far side of the island swept over to join their colleagues in assessing this new addition to the environment. She had to have them all in one place… It offers no food, the mind seems empty, one hissed. No soul in the body, but it had one once, whispered another, it wasn’t our work. There is no magic we can take, the one who’d reached out to touch her hissed, its magic is old, in the blood and the bones… As they continued to hiss and sputter, trying to decide when they had last seen someone like her, Lourdes used the brief calm as an opportunity to select the fattest, fullest one. Two Dementors into the crowd, there was an extraordinarily old, rotten one bursting with other people’s souls. Pushing her way into the mass of black, she reached up and grabbed it right where its neck ought to be, driving hard iron into the creature’s sternum, hearing a heady, satisfying crack as a reward for every blow. The silver mass inside its stomach burst out, twisting and warping in the air in an attempt to separate into the distinct beings it used to be. Lourdes was quickly forgotten, jostled from side to side as every Dementor on the island descended like vultures at a sky burial, all trying to suck up as much as they could of the mass of light. The Dementors’ magic had an almost gravitational pull on the souls, which remained trapped in orbit while the Dementors battled each other for the privilege of devouring the most. She felt that control slip from under her feet again, disgust and hatred rising to fill every cell of her body.  Who could compare her to these…things? Lashing out quickly, she grabbed another stuffed greedy creature, hammering away at its chest before leaving it to hiss and deflate. The writhing creatures didn’t even notice the bodies crumpling in their midst… By the time she heard the shouts of the other Death Eaters as they touched down, she was in the middle of cracking open a fourth.

Crossing the gap between her edge of the island and the prison’s massive oak and iron doors at a heavy run, she came to a halt next to Gibbon and the massive form of Azkaban itself. The building rose straight up from the rock as if it was hewn from the dead island itself - a dismal tower with the tiniest dark gun-slits for windows. It smelled indescribably filthy, though Lourdes soon realized that some of the stench was her. “Lich, Pettigrew, flank these doors and keep watch. Pettigrew, send red sparks if the Aurors approach,” Malfoy hissed as he, Gibbon, Avery, and McNair rushed the entrance. There was a heavy crackling sound as the doors flew off their hinges and a strange rainbow of light washed over them- the residue of seven or eight wards shattering in mid air. She turned to check on the Dementors, and from here it looked like they were having the time of their lives swarming the remnants of their fellows. The air was thick with the crackling of souls released from the Dementors’ bellies and the creatures’ own ravenous hissing as they fought; they’d be occupied with this for a while yet. “Gods, how much longer are they going to be…” Pettigrew bounced nervously onto the balls of his feet to see as far as he could. He did look deliciously warm and alive; Lourdes felt her tongue slip out to wet her lips- nobody would have to know if she stole a little life on the sly. That was when she saw them approaching in their little boat. Eight…no- nine warm bodies. “Here they come,” she said in an oddly hollow voice. Pettigrew reacted much faster than she would have expected, sending a brilliant red comet streaking into the prison, but Malfoy and the others seemed to be dawdling. Lourdes’ first instinct was to run for cover within the clump of Dementors, but she stood her ground. Wiping her fingers on her robe, she reached into the potions belt and fished out a Dragon’s Breath before swapping her phurba for the misericorde. Ready when you are. Malfoy emerged at the head of a clump of wild looking people who were touching their faces and filling their lungs with night air as if they could not believe this was really happening. A few were looking around for the Aurors, pausing to gawk at the mass of Dementors too preoccupied with devouring the remnants of their colleagues to do their job. “Gibbon, Avery, McNair- take the rear. Pettigrew, lich- flank them.” The escapees, led by Malfoy, made a beeline for the brooms just as the Aurors crested the hill. The Aurors were flinging hexes left and right, obviously trying to stay on target, but their aim was sloppy and they were slightly out of breath from the run and the panic (apparently they could not believe this was happening either). The other Death Eaters fanned out, forming a shield to keep the escapees safe as they rocketed off the island. One of the former prisoners, a woman with a gaunt face and a matted mess of hair, was begging loudly for a wand with a bloodthirsty look in her eyes before Malfoy shoved a broom in her hands. They were supposed to hold the Aurors back as long as they could, to give the escapees enough time to fly out of range, but only Malfoy seemed to have any skill at dueling. Everyone else was firing off the Death Curse and Cruciatus as fast as they could get the words out, blowing huge holes in the ground and kicking up clouds of dust. She’d nearly reached the island’s edge where the brooms were supposed to be lined up, but she caught sight of the slight hunched form of Avery mounting a broom and speeding out.  In the midst of the thick, dusty air and panic, Lourdes was failing miserably in her search for Pettigrew, and then she felt another body collide with hers. She was suddenly nose to nose with a blond man considerably younger than her- an Auror… The Auror was just as surprised as she was, and fumbled trying to get a curse out. In her haste, Lourdes resorted to a dirty old trick: she clamped an ice cold hand around the poor thing’s neck, and loosened control over her magic just enough to stop him dead in his tracks. Raw contact with an Evocator would send a jolt of cold, paralyzing fear through her victim. Any less control and she might have killed him. While he gasped and flapped his mouth like a horrified fish, Lourdes’ knife hand floated in front of his body, looking for a spot that would let her disable but not kill. In went the dagger, down and just off to the side of anything important. “It’s just a little shock, don’t fight it…” Lourdes whispered. The metallic smell of blood overwhelmed the Dementor stench for a moment, and she felt that squirmy hunger for life crawl up inside when the warm sticky-wet feeling of it seeped over her fingers. Before she could even think about stealing life, she felt a strange tingle run over the back of her neck before several curses hit her squarely in the back. While the body armor neutralized the spells’ effects, their physical impact nearly cracked her spine and sent her crashing down on top of the Auror. Slipping the dagger out, she forced herself to slither through the dust, trying to find that musky rat smell that meant Pettigrew was nearby. A few more spells missed her, then one hit her leg; the body armor stopped the worst, but the spell had hit the vulnerable part near her ankle, and it might have broken a bone. Taking cover in the dust stirred up by the spells that missed, and attempting to ignore the pain of her back swelling up into one gigantic bruise, Lourdes rolled over to grope in her potions holster for a fresh weapon. Mild panic gripped her when the only thing she came up with from the first try was a few fingertips full of splintered glass and the potent smell of painkiller. There went her escape plan. Mercifully, she’d stuck the offensive potions in a hip pocket, and finding a Garroting Gas and a Smoke Solution still intact, Lourdes hurled them as far as she could manage. Two very satisfying explosions followed and she lost sight of the Aurors that had been firing at her. Starting forward again, she caught Pettigrew’s scent on the air; he was right on top of her. A strong silver hand grabbed her wrist, caked in dust and blood, and he hauled her up and over to the last broom. A couple of Aurors who’d just broken through the gas and smoke were taking aim, but Lourdes rolled out the Dragon’s Breath ampoule hidden in her cheek, biting down and blowing a large cloud of fire in their direction. They shouted frantically as they extinguished one another while Pettigrew mounted the broom behind her, tipping her onto the handle sidesaddle. One hand stayed on the broom and the other snaked around her waist, forcing her to match the curve of his belly with her body whenever he hunched over to steer. Claustrophobic panic, gut level revulsion at the breath on her neck, and the pain from the pressure on her bruised back took over for a moment, and she threw off her hood and mask to get a face full of cold air. As the shock wore off, she realized one hand was still wrapped around the dagger, and the other had been sliced up by the glass shards from the potion ampoules. She meant to shove the misericorde back into the holster, but the path was blocked by Pettigrew’s silver hand, the fingers of which were creeping down her side. Lourdes narrowed her eyes dangerously as she watched the hand’s progress. There seemed to be something off about the way Pettigrew was touching - no, holding her. His hand had slipped up under the filthy black robes and was sliding along the cool skin of her armor. It wasn’t clear yet if this was a measure to keep her properly anchored on the broom, or something less innocuous. “This is not a date, Pettigrew,” Lourdes snapped, swatting his wrist with the blade while trying awkwardly to swing her good leg over the broom handle for a better seat. The broom shifted dangerously to one side, threatening to dump Lourdes backward into the water before Pettigrew’s hand pressed flat and too-low on her stomach, bracing her against his body. “STOP!” he hissed. “Are you trying to get us both killed?” He righted the broom admirably and they zipped along in silence for a moment. ”Any casualties?” Lourdes asked grimly. “We were the last ones out. Malfoy left the second you were hit.” “Remind me to take seven years out of him the next time I see him,” she hissed. Just as the words slipped out, Lourdes realized she ought to watch her mouth; this wasn’t Severus. “McNair and Avery were right behind him. Gibbon stayed because he’s too stupid to think on his own; I had to tell him to get on his damn broom.” There was a little surge in Pettigrew just then, an unexpected glimmer of something competent. “So the rat is a commander at heart. Is it true you took out thirteen Muggles with one curse?” Lourdes muttered, swirling her tongue around inside her mouth looking for any little pebbles of melted glass left over from the Dragon’s Breath. “Yes.” Pettigrew replied suspiciously. “Why the hell did you just stab that Auror?” “I can’t use a wand, you idiot.” Probably not the best thing to say to someone who could dump you into the North Sea with one roll of the broom. “In case you failed to notice, I did manage to keep the Dementors happy.” Pettigrew snorted derisively, and Lourdes ground her teeth against the inside of her cheek when she felt his thumb trace the ridge of her hipbone, almost playfully. “And they say I’m a coward,” he said in a slightly mocking tone. He was so close that his lips brushed her cheek when he spoke. Lourdes turned her head to give him a look that could have frozen a volcano. “What was that, Pettigrew?” “A dagger? Not a sword, or even a mace.” “It requires skill.” “Highly concealable, anonymous, cowardly and treacherous, and exactly what I’d expect from a Slytherin.” His tone turned her house name into an epithet. “Wasn’t a dagger the weapon of Brutus and the Senate when they killed Caesar?” That was a stroke of sophistication Lourdes would not have expected from him, a dangerous underestimation on her part… She tried to think where he might have picked up the idea that she could be pushed around (oh, he was definitely trying), and it dawned on her rather quickly. Pettigrew had only seen her in meetings, where she was soft spoken and pliant. Her guardian protector, Snape, wasn’t here right now, so there was plenty of time to feel her out. In a very literal fashion: Pettigrew’s hand was starting to travel again. By responding, she’d played right into his hands. He’d had brains enough to see if the behavior she presented at the meetings was the real deal, or if there was something else he needed to know. Dorje Bragsen preserve me, she hissed internally. The hand had stationed itself on her thigh, a definite attempt at coercion. Fine then; if Pettigrew wanted to see her true nature, Lourdes would be more than happy to show him… “It took twenty three strokes to kill Caesar; I’ll do you in two if you don’t get that hand off my leg,” she growled, turning to bare her teeth at him. Mercifully, the rest of the broom ride was short; they arrived above a little island where a dark knot of people were gathered on the sand, clutching their brooms. Pettigrew touched down, his hand quickly moving up in what seemed like an attempt to get a handful when he went to ‘help’ her up. Swatting him off as if he were a bothersome fly, Lourdes forced herself to stand on her good leg while Malfoy checked to make sure all necessary parties were present and accounted for. He double, then triple checked the name Rookwood before his eyes landed on Lourdes. For a fraction of a second, Malfoy looked disappointed, before he gave his list a cursory glance and said coolly, “And the lich, of course.” She fought not to wince every time she put weight on her bad leg and mulled over the amount of additional damage she might be doing. It was a chance she was willing to take; there was no way in hell she was going to sit down when everyone else was standing. The crowd thinned slowly as Malfoy, McNair, and Avery Side Along-ed other Death Eaters to the various safe houses. Lourdes felt a sharp surge of hostility that she had been kept waiting here when Pettigrew could just as easily have taken her away as soon as their names were called. There was one last pop, and then it was just Lourdes and Pettigrew. Suddenly, he grinned maliciously; it twisted his face up and his posture changed to something rather aggressive. “Is he fucking you?” The instant those words registered in her brain, her first instinct was to kick him in the head hard enough to knock his skull off his spine. But the second she shifted her weight, she received a painful reminder that her whole body was in rotten shape. Instead, she fell forward onto Pettigrew, slamming her skull firmly into his to destabilize him. He fought a little as she struggled to pin him down, pricking him with the misericorde to distract him so she could sit up and get one boot wedged firmly under his jaw, with the dagger poised right above the tear duct on his left eye. “Honestly, Pettigrew. I find your lack of professional courtesy astounding,” she said, somewhat dizzily. It had been a long time since she’d delivered a head-butt to anyone, and it made her ears ring faintly. “I mean, if you did manage to get that hand on something interesting, don’t you think I would at the very least tell Snape? Luckily for you, I prefer to settle my own scores. Do you know that if I just let this slip,” Lourdes let the knife drop just a tiny bit, “right down past your eye and into your prefrontal lobe, I could keep those hands from wanting to roam - permanently. Now, I have no qualms at all about performing a bit of neurosurgery if you should find yourself incapable of answering my questions. The first of which is: why would you ask me a question like that?” “Merely confirming a suspicion the others hold,” Pettigrew choked, trying to reduce his voice to a simpering squeak to distract her from the fact that he was trying to aim his wand at her. “Drop it. I’ll have this through your eye before you get the words out. Precisely who are these others?” she asked coolly. It was a bizarre accusation, terribly clumsy, but it might be worth filing away whatever he had to say for future reference. “Well, Lucius…” “That’s a lie. Lucius Malfoy knows you only by reputation. He thinks you are garbage, and I am willing to put money on the assertion that he doesn’t particularly care about anyone’s nocturnal activities but his own. Try again.” “There’s a wager of sorts…I could use the money,” he began, obviously struggling to breathe under her weight positioned on his rib cage. Lourdes rewarded Pettigrew by pushing her boot harder against his throat. “What was that, Pettigrew? Please, feel free to interpret this as an interrogation. You know what an interrogation is, don’t you?” she said in her ‘isn’t this reasonable’ voice. “I’ll give you a definition: the withholding of pain on my part in exchange for information on yours. Well, let’s see: right now I’m withholding, but you aren’t talking.” ”There’s a bit of a pool going to see if he has to put a sack over your head or if he just turns you around,” Pettigrew said nastily, attempting a smirk which was quickly replaced by a strangled expression and slightly bulging eyes when Lourdes bounced and shifted on his chest to knock the air out of him. She stared at him appraisingly for a moment, trying to decide what was really going on here.  It certainly wasn’t the sort of sexual accusation she was used to, no one in OHK would have been fool hardy enough to mention the widely held suspicion that her unit commander liked to have her around the flat, or that she might have gone home from the bars with her old partner.  There really wasn’t much for Pettigrew to gain by that unless he was simply attempting to humiliate her because she was a woman.   That in itself was rather self indulgent and stupid. Shifting her leg so she could lean in uncomfortably close to Pettigrew’s face, Lourdes pursed her lips and shook her head disapprovingly. “Some of us have the Dark Lord’s best interests in the forefront of our minds, not our baser instincts. You might do well to reconsider your priorities…” Lourdes slipped off, struggling to her feet and re-holstering her weapon as Pettigrew massaged his throat, looking entirely too calculating. As if trying to decide whether he was going to take his chances and retaliate, or just take her back where she came from. “Let’s get one thing straight Pettigrew. Within this organization, I’m subordinate to two people: the Dark Lord, and Snape. And neither of them will be very pleased if you don’t get me back right now.” Pettigrew did a rather good impersonation of a simpering person, gingerly grabbing her clean wrist. With a pop she was back at the edge of the forest. “Get out before someone sees you,” she snapped, and Pettigrew, cringing, obeyed. Lourdes managed to hobble into the little clearing of trees and slumped against one to wait. The pain felt much duller than usual; bruises and broken bones were definitely supposed to hurt more. If Severus didn’t get out here soon she’d be a tasty, tenderized meal for whatever nasty creature was lurking in the bushes. -***- Severus found her sitting rather calmly in a stand of scrubby evergreen shrubs. He would have thought her dead if he hadn’t been able to see her chest rise and fall just a little bit. A wave of relief washed over him, but did not completely remove the slightly twitchy feeling in his body, residual irritation from the Occlumency lesson, and his unbearable nervousness over her outing. The minute he got close enough to give her a firm poke with his wand, Lourdes reached up and groped with an ice cold hand for the chain with the Ghau on it. There was a brilliant burst of light and searing heat, and when the spots cleared from his eyes he saw Lourdes had been blown a good five feet away, judging by the trench in the snow and the fact that she seemed to be in significantly more pain. “That was worth it,” Lourdes panted. Color had returned to her skin with a vengeance, and between the bruises, cuts, and red flush from the cold, she was certainly not at her prettiest. “What happened to you?” Severus had only just realized that he was gaping at her. “Nobody covered me, and I’ve never had to deal with that.  I’ve always had the luxury of a competent partner. These morons kicked up so much dust with their curses that we couldn’t see where we were going. I got surprised by an Auror and ended up knifing him before I caught a few curses to the back, and a broken leg I think. Malfoy was out of there like a shot, and Pettigrew of all people was the one who hauled me out.” While the Dark Lord wouldn’t be too happy to hear that Malfoy had been careless with his new toy (though this might bode well for Pettigrew), the real problem right now was how Severus was going to get her back to the castle in this condition. He might transfigure her, but prospect of that going wrong was a little too gruesome to contemplate, the Thestrals would lick at her wounds, and a stretcher would never make it across the open ground between the forest and the castle unnoticed. He was going to have to carry her. “Give me your arm.” Severus lifted one arm and gestured toward her. “What?” “I can’t put you on a stretcher, and you obviously cannot walk unassisted.  You’re going to have to use me as a crutch.” “This is going to take ages,” she muttered, floundering through the snow to learn heavily on his shoulder as she favored her bad leg. With a grunt, Severus stood up, but he quickly discovered that aiding an extra nine or ten stone (he didn’t dare ask how much, exactly) through the snow was harder than he’d anticipated. It seemed like a good idea at the time, he thought, but in hindsight his brain had figured out several really much easier alternatives. Why the hell hadn’t he just used Mobilicorpus? If she complained he might have just knocked her out. The trip took three times as long this way, and Lourdes dug her fingernails into his chest every time she put too much weight on her bad leg. Once they reached the forest edge, he scouted the grounds to see if anyone was out and about, but at this time of night in this miserable weather they were the only ones daft enough to be outside. If they hurried, he could get her in through the lakeside entrance with little trouble. Once they were inside the castle, Severus dragged her through several dark halls until they arrived at his quarters in one piece; there’d been no sign of the toad Umbridge anywhere and the portraits weren’t about to talk. He deposited her into a chair, where she struggled out of the filthy Death Eater robes. “Do me a favor and burn these for me, would you?” She thrust the dirty bundle at him before starting to unzip the hidden seams of her sleeves and the legs of the suit “With pleasure,” Severus muttered, stuffing them into the fire with a poker. “Are you going to get the Healer?” Lourdes asked, exhaling hard while she worked the front zip down, peeling the body suit off to the waist to reveal a snug undershirt and some mild bruises on her arms. In this light, he spotted another nasty bruise and cut near her hairline, as well as a very prominent gash across her nose and cheeks. Though for a fraction of a second he caught himself staring at the new view the undershirt provided… Automatically, his head snapped up and he tried to focus on the top of her head. Being constantly surrounded by females in two age brackets, too young, and too old for his taste had trained him to keep his gaze firmly anchored above the chin at all times. In fact, the whole world of feminine things remained blessedly remote. Though he would have given his left kidney for the assurance that he would never hear the phrase “Professor Snape, I need to go see Madam Pomfrey, I think my…thing started…” for the rest of his natural life. However, Lourdes fell into neither forbidden age bracket, and the pronounced change in her physique had been brought into the open in a most inconvenient fashion. Severus cursed whatever confluence of exercise and genetic material had given her the ability to transform the addict’s body she’d arrived with into something strong, lean, and vastly more appealing. Wait…Madam Pomfrey - why did that seem important? Oh, yes, her back. “We will not need her,” Severus said once he’d gotten his wits back. Darting into the kitchen, he started flinging open cupboard doors to gather the potions and spell books he’d need to patch her up. “Someone has to put my leg right!” Lourdes yelped over her shoulder. “As long as the fracture is not severe I’ll be able to take care of it.” Severus set the little tray of things he’d collected from the kitchen down and started thumbing through books to find the pages for pain killer spells. “Are you out of your mind? What do you know about healing?” When she lurched forward to threaten him, certain things… bounced, a motion that was apparently not possible in a swimsuit or robes. He was quickly mortified to realize that she was obviously in pain and that it was probably incredibly improper to notice. “Death Eaters are hardly welcome at St Mungo’s, Ms Mezarci. One learns to heal oneself, and I spent my first years out of school at Saint Magdalena’s Apothecary. Turn around so I can have a look at your back.” “Saint Magdalena’s makes fancy soap and perfumes. I don’t think that’s Healer’s work,” she hissed. “They also make liniments and ointments,” he replied, holding up a tin with the Apothecary’s blue and white label as proof. Lourdes remained firmly in place, arms crossed stubbornly as he plucked a few live, light purple leeches out of their tank and set them in a reserve dish. “You aren’t seriously going to put those on me, are you?” “Leeches assist in the reduction of bruises. If yours are as deep as I suspect, the leeches will be more effective than any spell would be. Turn around, Ms Mezarci. That is not a request.” She turned around to straddle the chair backwards, stripping off her undershirt (Severus’ brain launched itself into a mental recitation of the ingredients of the most gruesome potion he knew), letting out a hiss of pain when she tried to raise both of her arms up at once. Lourdes hadn’t asked for a painkiller yet, which was…well, he wasn’t sure whether it was bravado or something else. Her back was a mess, to say the least: deep black-purple and red bruises were swelling grotesquely all over, distorting the scarred skin. He couldn’t have asked for a more thorough mood killer. After surveying the damage carefully for a moment, he began to apply the leeches in a neat grid. “Are you covered, Ms Mezarci?” he asked primly. “Yes. Not that anything of interest is in any shape to be seen, or that there’s all that much to begin with.” Lourdes attempted a weak laugh and slumped over, her hand darting up to rearrange the fabric covering her as she rested her chin on the back of the chair. Severus had to kneel down to get a good look at her, pulling back the thick swath of hair that had come unpinned to inspect the big bruise covering her cheek, next to her ‘bad’ ear. It sat under a scar he’d never seen before that looked suspiciously like a bite mark. “I have to tie this back,” he said shortly, conjuring stuffing the hair back into her hat so he could apply the leech. “Urgh,” she objected, frowning as the leech got to work. “You’ve been cut rather badly here,” he muttered, applying purple antiseptic that hissed and smoked as it worked to clean out the cut down her nose. “Lovely, now I’m going to have to move the part in my fringe over further to cover this when it scars. At this rate it won’t be fringe anymore, it’ll be a curtain and I won’t be able to see at all.” “I hardly think so; I have some dittany tincture which should prevent any severe scarring. Is that not used in Turkey?” Severus asked in a distantly disinterested tone as he disinfected the cut near her hairline, before applying a few drops of potion to the little cuts on her fingers. “Ah well, when your manly male colleagues take you to the healers and give you a hard time about women not being cut out for the work because of their natural vanity, you sort of… opt against any treatment that might make you seem weak. Of course, some of these were beyond preventative treatment, so I’m stuck with them anyway.” Smiling weakly, she winced as the large cut across her face contorted. “Did I mention that Pettigrew claims there’s a pool going to see if you prefer to bag my head to sleep with me, or if you’d rather just ‘turn me around’?” She laughed, but it rang a bit hollow in his ears- as if she wanted it to be funny but didn’t really think so. Severus jerked back and looked at her suspiciously, but his brain was conjuring a rapid image of that second suggestion.  No, he had to shake that off for now. “How did you come to find this out?” “Pettigrew tried to pull a power play on me, asked if you were ‘fucking’ me. Naturally I threatened to give him brain damage until he gave me all the details; I ended up just giving a lecture on the Dark Lord’s best interests. That should put a stop to that,” Lourdes said crisply. He nodded in reply, a little worried that Pettigrew might be attempting to move up in rank as well. Just one more thing he’d need to keep an eye on. “This isn’t so bad that you should be impairing your depth perception.” Severus ran his fingers lightly over the spider web pattern carved in her cheek before aiming his wand at the long cut across her nose and cheeks. “Severus, you don’t have to talk down to me,” she replied sheepishly, crossing her eyes to watch the wand tip travel over her cut several times as the skin knitted closed. “I’m well aware of what I look like.” If she really knew, Severus thought miserably, she wouldn’t be so bloody casual about that undershirt and other people’s come-ons… “I resent the implication that I would attempt to appeal to your vanity. However little vanity you might have…” he muttered, running a finger over the pale, smooth line that had replaced the open wound. “Ms Mezarci, you act as though you are somehow seriously disfigured, but I see that you have all four limbs, both eyes, and most of both of your ears. Seeing as Moody is limping around on a false leg with a false eye, you should count yourself lucky.” “It’s all well and good for Moody, men get away with that sort of thing in this line of work. Apparently I’m supposed to do my work without picking up a single scratch or putting a hair out of place. You know, my nickname at O.H.K. in my later years was ‘the hag.’ On account of my appearance, and my disposition,” she said with a smirk. “On the subject of name calling I’m afraid you’ll get no sympathy from me. If I am not being addressed as Snivellus, I hear the student nicknames through the grapevine. Greasy git, big-nosed git, and overgrown bat being the most common,” he said lightly, pausing to pick the gorged leech off the bruise on her face. “Kids just aren’t as creative these days, are they? What about the perennial Gryffindor-girl taunt ‘slimy snakey Severus Snape?’ Or my favorite, ‘Sevviekins’?” Lourdes asked innocently. “I was under the impression you wanted to have your leg healed.” He shot her a filthy look as he placed the fat, happy little creature back in its tank. Brandishing a tin of bruise paste that smelled strongly of mint, Severus began dabbing it onto what was left of the bruise. “I’m not sure what to think about Pettigrew though; there was something off with him. Kept running his hand down my side when we had to share a broom,” she muttered, with disgust and contempt etched all over her face. “Tried to go for a bit of a feel up right in front of everyone too.” Severus knew what to think of Pettigrew when that revelation registered, and he imagined the scene. One eyelid twitched uncontrollably as he muttered something about murdering the rat if he ever touched her again. Lourdes face softened and she gave him a strange little smile that actually carried through to her eyes. It really should have seemed like the smallest, most insignificant of facial tics, Severus thought nervously. Only there was something so familiar and warm in her expression, an apparent gratitude for his protective outburst mixed in with something that could only be described as oddly…alluring.

“Thanks, but I don’t think you’ll need to.  I’m a big girl, I can handle it.”

She really shouldn’t look at him that way; it gave him a very unnerving shock in the chest, and his hands felt three times bigger than they actually were.  Feeling extremely irritated with himself, Severus returned the tin to the table.

 

“Dittany,” he snapped, before he thrust a little crystal bottle at her. Lourdes sighed, and droppered some onto her finger to rub onto the scar.  Meanwhile Severus removed the leeches on her back and fixed the ribs he suspected broken with a charm. “Re-dress yourself and we will see about your leg.” Severus turned on his heel smartly, folding his arms neatly over his chest, and used the time to try to force his skin to return to a normal color instead of gaping at her like an eager fifteen year old. When he turned back around, with Lourdes properly clothed and busy unlacing her boot, he avoided anything above her knees, focusing only on the injured area. Her leg was swollen and bruised, but on examination it seemed to be just a bruise on the bone itself, and not a break. The bone was fixed with a simple charm, and the bruising wasn’t so bad that it needed leeches. A bit of paste would do just fine, so Severus thrust the tin at her and stood up quickly to replace the leeches and the other healing potions he’d brought out. “Something wrong?” Lourdes asked, with an uncharacteristic shakiness to her voice. Probably just exhaustion, he thought. “I’m afraid I have no idea what you are talking about, Ms Mezarci,” Severus muttered, as he put the top back on the leech tank and carried it to the kitchen. Much to his annoyance, his tried and true avoidant method wasn’t working, he kept involuntarily reliving that soft smile she’d given him. “Alright then,” she said quietly, popping the lid off the bruise paste and slathering a generous amount onto her leg. Sharp, sudden pain pierced his skull sharply as if someone had just driven a railway spike into it; he was definitely in the first stages of a raging headache. Perhaps it was because he’d spent the evening shackled to the incurably stupid Potter. Maybe, he thought, fighting the thick swimming feeling in his skull, it was that he’d panicked at the thought of being without her. And he had no idea exactly what that meant exactly, only that the panic was not related to losing a spy. Some of it, at least, was because of Pettigrew; the thought of his hands anywhere on her body made Severus want to kill something. Suddenly mortified by that last thought, Severus felt himself go ugly, dark red across the cheeks and turned abruptly so that she wouldn’t see. “I will be making use of the bathroom, Ms Mezarci, I’m afraid you’ll have to wait,” he said coldly, as if he were punishing her for something. “I’m covered in blood and whatever Dementors are full of, I think I’ve earned a nice hot bath,” she snarled. “Distressing as that sounds, I have spent roughly two hours beating my head against a wall. That is to say Potter’s first Occlumency lesson was today, and in light of that I think that the right to the bathroom is mine. That, and the bruise paste needs set for at least a half an hour.” He turned on his heel and made it to the bathroom in a few long steps. It was Friday, it wasn’t nine o’clock; this was not his scheduled time for a bath, he thought, as he discarded his robes and snapped the curtain shut around the tub. He contemplated the cold tap and his mental state for a moment before he twisted both and stepped in to a spray of comfortably warm water.  The sound of the water gave him enough mental solitude that he could linger and think as long as he liked without any distractions. Strangely, though, as he tried to concentrate, Severus thought that he heard faint, manic laughter carrying through the pipes. It must have been his imagination.

Give and Take

 

All compromise is based on give and take, but there can be no give and take on fundamentals. ~ Mohandas Ghandi.


 The holidays here were rather different here; instead of getting slightly dirty looks from her devout co-workers during Ramazan fasting, Lourdes had the task of finding Christmas gifts. In the past few weeks leading up to the holidays, she’d worked on forging the customs forms for Aberforth's Christmas gift.  As it turned out, having Mongolian goats imported to the United Kingdom was much harder than it really should have been.  She'd made a few attempts at writing to her contacts at O.H.K. on Albus' behalf, but always ended in her bed under a mound of blankets and her furry hat knitting socks while listening to Days of Destiny on her wireless unit.

The socks were for Albus: three pairs of the pointy toed style popular in Turkey, knitted in lurid colors from her left-over yarn. Nomadic practicality and many long weeks between opportunities to do laundry had taught Lourdes that if there was anything everyone could use, it was more socks and underwear.  In between stitches, she assembled profiles on the soap opera characters and ate out of the baskets parents sent Severus. One had to stay sharp, after all.

Once it had arrived, Aberforth had been beyond delighted with his Christmas gift, a just-weaned nanny goat to replace the one he'd lost earlier in the year. In return he'd sent Lourdes a bottle of proper perfume, Borneo No 14 from the Saint Magdalena Apothecary, and a luxury hamper from Bon Vivant, along with twenty photos he'd bullied a patron into taking. The photos featured Aberforth cradling the brand new white kid, festooned with holiday bows and 'waving' its hoof at the camera.  The best of these were taped to the inner lid of her trunk by the bedside along with his postcards to provide a view that wasn’t of half frozen lake water.

The perfume’s function was rather obvious, and Lourdes rather liked having something feminine after avoiding it staunchly for years.  It was the hamper that presented a problem; it was full of food, or rather things that had the potential to be food if you knew what to do with them. The most alarming contents were two blue-brown lobsters that waved their ribbon bound claws at her from their little box. There were also tins of Iranian caviar, old vinegar, smelly truffles and cheese, little chickens under a fresh preservation charm, "vintage" fruits and vegetables (what on earth did that mean?). The only thing Lourdes knew what to do with was the pomegranate, which was squirreled away to ripen.

The only thing Lourdes could make, per se, was a ploughman's and instant heat Whizz Dinners (pull the cord and watch it cook!). She'd spent the past ten years subsisting on whatever was fast and handy, which usually meant street food and carry away. Her first thought on examining the hamper was that most of it was going to go to waste, but Severus poked through the contents and vanished into the kitchen with his copy of The Grand Dictionary of Cuisine. As it turned out, Severus could cook.

While Lourdes did the dirty work of transcribing the events of the Dementor session, Severus did magic and turned some of the contents of the hamper into dinner; lobsters first aside a creamy sauce to top fresh pasta. Last night it had been Turkish figs stuffed with Roquefort cheese, and glazed in the thick balsamic vinegar, next to rice pilaf and the crispy-skinned chickens, cooked in wine and stuffed with grapes and herbs. A far cry from the school kitchen meat and two vegetables with a pudding they'd been sentenced to every night prior, and far nicer than anything she’d eaten in the past few…well most of her life really.

For lunch today, it was a pile of flaky croissant sandwiches with melty cheese, tomato, and fancy lettuce served with a great big pitcher of dry martinis, and a roaring hot fire which meant Lourdes could emerge from her mountain of blankets. She was just about to finish her third sandwich and martini, and was nowhere close to finishing the Dementor report for Lupin.  She kept getting lost in writing detailed explanations of various magic theories that may or may not apply, in case Lupin wasn’t up on his pure theory.  Severus was still working on the first half of his sandwich, and the second half of a gigantic Healers' reference book.

"I could get used to this," Lourdes purred, stretching back in her chair like a lazy cat before hastily swallowing her mouthful of cheese and tomatoes. “On the job we never ate this well, ever!  The closest I came was some pretty good carry away when I was in the masters program.  I wouldn't have pegged you for a cooking person though."

Severus looked up coolly and raised an eyebrow, as if he was not sure whether she was insulting or complimenting him. "Why is that, Ms Mezarci?"

"Well, there isn't a whole lot of power in cooking," she nodded, taking a hearty swig of her martin and savoring the alcohol burn on its way down. “’That’s why I never bothered with it. No time, no point.”

"You fail to see how presenting the proper image through food and drink impresses others?  Not to mention being able to feed yourself…"

"You don't need to impress me Mister Snape," Lourdes said with a sly grin. "I've already seen the contents of your underwear drawer, I'm afraid your reputation will never recover from that."

He gave her an exasperated look as she reached for the last sandwich and another helping of martini.  “What? I’m a growing girl!”

 

“Growing out…” Severus muttered.

 

“Don't look so sour. I mean it’s a compliment!  See that’s the thing, all this? Fancy sandwiches, little decorations on the plate, it’s a little more precious and artsy than I would have expected from you."

Severus looked a little scornful as he took a hearty slurp of his martini. "Cooking is not an art, it's a science."

"I do love science," Lourdes sighed, resting her cheek on the heel of her hand and stuffing the last of her sandwich into her mouth.

"Speaking of science, Ms Mezarci," Severus said coolly, looking over the top of his book. "I would like to… request your assistance on a project."

"Oh?"

"That MKIP program gave you access to Muggle fields of study correct?"

"Certain fields, yes," Lourdes replied, taking a large, ungainly bite out of the new sandwich.

"What do you know about their study of the functions of the damaged brain?" Severus continued.

"Physical damage wasn't really my field of study; though I had to take a few basic neurobiology courses when I did my masters. What are we talking about here?"

"A regimen of potions to correct damage done by the Crucatius Curse, something more effective than the regimens they're using now."

"I never pegged you for a healer either, Mister Snape. Is this about Damocles Belby getting that Order of Merlin for the Wolfsbane potion?" Lourdes asked shrewdly, recalling some of his earlier rants on that subject.

 

She wasn’t the only person he’d shared a productive rivalry with at school. Severus had it out for Belby in the worst way ever since Belby’s paper won the Potions Club prize in fourth year, over Severus’ admittedly intriguing but off-beat treatise on poison cults. Belby was the golden boy genius, the Slug Club darling and the pride of Ravenclaw. Snape was the weird, greasy black sheep who did everything “backwards.”  Apparently their “friendly rivalry” had continued after school as well.

But for just a fraction of a second there, she thought Severus looked a little wounded by her unnecessarily direct jab.

"Some of us, Ms Mezarci, have learned to value research and development for their merits unto themselves," Severus said, scornful again.

"Apologies, Mister Snape. What do you need my help for?"

"I am asking you to assist me in the research because you come highly recommended. Albus was pleased with the work you did for him, and I," Severus paused and narrowed his eyes just a little, "trust that you would keep me accountable."

"What you mean is I'll triple check your work and I won't hesitate to skewer you if I think you've got something wrong?" Lourdes couldn't resist a wide grin at that; she'd had the dubious honor of being his spell guinea pig in their latter years at Hogwarts.

"We'll be starting fresh on this project; I do not wish to piggyback on another formula this time. Those attempts have proven almost worthless."

"Long term project, I'll do it. And I promise, once it’s all figured out, I'll let your name go first on the papers," she said casually, but her smile didn't last long.

Lourdes hardly heard her martini glass shatter because her left arm seared painfully, and a snowy location she'd never seen impressed itself sharply on her brain. "Is yours burning too?" she gasped, pulling up her robe sleeves to see the red brand had turned black on her arm.

"Get dressed," he hissed.

The room flew into a panic as they rummaged in the wardrobe for the boxes containing their gear. Lourdes struggled into her Death Eaters robes and coif, cursing at herself for putting the gloves on before she'd laced her boots. Turning to rummage frantically in her chest, she stuffed the bundle of “necessary” ornament belts into her pockets, just in case, before Severus Disillusioned her and they were off.

Luck must have been on their side, because they encountered no delays in the castle or down the drive. The moment they crossed the Apparition boundary line, Severus grabbed a hold of her, nearly crushing her forearm, and they vanished.

-***-

Severus looked around cautiously; they weren't as late as they might have been. In fact, they seemed to have been summoned first, as figures in black were still popping into the air all around them, trudging through the snow without exchanging greetings.

They set off on the track already carved into the snow, running along the edge of a cliff, and ending at the door of a little shack perched above the slate gray ocean. Once they passed through the wards that barred the door, they found themselves inside the rotting building where the Dark Lord sat enthroned on a moth-eaten velvet chair by the dark fire place. Snow and brine leaked through the gaps in the architecture, making it that much harder for the small crowd of Death Eaters pressed against the walls not to tremble or shiver.

Suddenly, Voldemort waved his hand and the group dropped simultaneously to their knees. "Most of you know what lies just out to sea," he murmured, gazing pensively out the shack's lone, rattling window. "Azkaban, the fortress guarded by our allies the Dementors. Many of you are also aware of, and benefiting greatly from, the fact that the world as we know it has yet to acknowledge my return… What a blessing it is that we may take advantage of the sloppy security measures that are now so common-place." Voldemort's red eyes surveyed the crowd of Death Eaters lazily, as if he were already deciding who to assign to the task.

"How I would hate to squander this opportunity; how I would hate to make my presence known any sooner than I have to. Not when the Ministry is so happy to turn a blind eye when my Death Eaters meet with one another for petty tortures... We will make the most of this." He ran one long finger over his lipless mouth before it twisted into a ghastly smile.

"Indeed, when you reach Azkaban the Dementor's powers will affect you; it is simply their nature to feed on humans. They cannot truly tell one person apart from another, but many of you have heard that we have a new addition. The rumor is true; we have been brought an Evocator…" Voldemort pointed straight at Lourdes, picking her from the crowd easily and beckoning her forward. The sea of black robed bodies parted as she crawled forward and knelt at Voldemort's feet.

"My little lich will be responsible for the Dementors. With her soul displaced they will not affect her; she will be able to walk into their midst as if she were one of them. And she does have so much in common with them; a hunger for souls, and a bond with decay. I dare say that the loss of one Dementor will hardly be a tragedy. When the souls are released from the dying creature, the others will not be able to resist feeding, and they will care little for the rest of you. All you will have to fear are the Aurors. There are so few on the island that guards the fortress that my Death Eaters are sure to make easy work of them."

He yanked back her hood quickly and tipped up her chin, boring into her eyes with his. "I am right in saying, of course, that you are capable of placing yourself in lich state?"

"Yes my lord," she replied in an oddly sweet tone.

Voldemort looked up from Lourdes and smiled imperiously at the crowd again. "We have Severus, of course, to thank for her presence. His loyalty to me drove him to the deserts to retrieve this little creature. It seems so many of you were ignorant of her while she was in our midst before. It is, of course, my hope that the rest of you will be more vigilant in finding me useful servants. Ah, Lucius…"

Voldemort called him forward with the twitch of a finger and Lucius stepped out of the lineup, kneeling next to Lourdes. If prostrating himself next to her as if she were an equal bothered him, he was careful not to let it show.

"You will be responsible for leading this expedition. I understand you are very familiar with the layout of Azkaban because of your visits to the Lestranges with your wife. We will need those Death Eaters of stouter stock and younger blood to endure this. You will of course take the lich, Avery, McNair, and Gibbon…"

"What about Crabbe and Goyle, my Lord?" Lucius asked quietly, eyes still trained on the ground.

"I think not. This is a task that will require a bit more than brutal efficiency." Voldemort cast a rather disapproving glance over at the two largest figures crouched in a back corner. "You will have to endure this without your personal retainers, so I do hope you are still capable of thinking on your feet. Snape, of course…"

"My Lord, if I might," Malfoy said quickly, his back and shoulders braced to receive a curse for daring to interrupt the Dark Lord twice. "Snape, I think, will be tied up with the Occlumency lessons he is now obliged to give Potter, on Dumbledore's orders. Surely he could not escape the school in time to meet us…"

Severus felt the bottom drop out of his stomach; this was certainly not how he had planned on breaking that particular bit of news to Voldemort. Malfoy was striking out, kicking him down the ladder a few rungs, and making Severus extremely angry that he'd attempted to appeal to Malfoy in the first place. Voldemort's head snapped up sharply, and Severus was suddenly sliding forward on his knees as if pulled by a rope until he was up on the other side of Lourdes.

"And exactly when were you planning on sharing this with me, Snape?" Voldemort asked, his voice even colder than usual. Severus took a deep breath and fixed his eyes evenly on the hem of the Dark Lord's robes. "My lord, you instructed me to relay all information through Malfoy because of my position at the school, I obeyed. I hastened to tell him the moment I was given the orders by Dumbledore, though I do not know why Malfoy has delayed in telling you…"

"I merely wished to present this news at a time when Snape would be present, so that he might assist in devising a scheme to thwart these plans of Dumbledore's, my Lord," Malfoy said sleekly. Severus was burning with anger in the pit of his stomach at this deliberate stab in the back, but was quick to force it aside.

"My Lord, it is true. I have been instructed to teach the boy Occlumency, and the first lesson does fall on the night you have chosen to free our comrades. But you need not worry about Potter, my Lord. He is without a doubt the last person on the earth who will be able to master Occlumency. No one can lie to you, my Lord, not even from hundreds of miles away; I will not even have to pretend to fail at teaching him." Of that much Severus could be sure.

"Even so, Severus, give nothing away that might shield the boy's mind." Voldemort was giving him a very suspicious sidelong glance that made Severus slightly frantic to make up for this.

 

"Could the retrieval of our comrades not be moved back only by a day, my Lord? Then I would be able to assist in this important task."

"We have selected this date because Mondays are the only day on which there is a crucial gap in the Guard Aurors' evening shift change, while they review the upcoming week's schedule. Therefore it is essential that Monday is when we strike," Voldemort said.

"My Lord," Lourdes said softly, "who will be charged with assisting me if Snape cannot come?" Voldemort looked back at her with an almost bemused look on his face, as if he found her lack of practical magic amusing, and scanned the crowd.

Suddenly Malfoy piped up again. "Pettigrew, perhaps? My Lord, this would be the perfect opportunity to force him to prove his worth to you."

Severus felt a fresh sear of anger in his gut; saddling Lourdes with a moron and a coward like Pettigrew? Malfoy was trying to get her killed.

"Perhaps… Fear is an excellent motivator, is it not? Pettigrew then, we will charge him with the lich's safety. Return without her body, or fail to return at all, and I will find you, Pettigrew. I assure you, your death will be a very, slow painful one for losing an asset this valuable. You cannot hide from me in your little animal body as you hid from your friends." Voldemort had a very nasty look of satisfaction on his face, as if happy to find a rock solid way of forcing Pettigrew to be useful. Severus thought he heard the faintest of squeaks coming from a corner in reply.

"Then we have Malfoy, Pettigrew, Gibbon, Avery, McNair, and the lich. That will make for fifteen when you have released the faithful from Azkaban. Malfoy, you will draw up the plans and review them with me before informing your comrades."

Concentrating very hard to keep his breathing very even and low, Severus' mind was racing for a way to make a foothold out of Malfoy. Loyal to Dumbledore or not, he would not stand for being forced lower down the ranks and risk missing out on vital information. Severus stole a small glance the Dark Lord, and was struck by a bolt out of the blue. The diary- the one that Potter had destroyed.

It had been entrusted to Lucius a very long time ago to be planted in the school when the time was right. That was part of the reason Severus was supposed to have been stationed at Hogwarts originally, as a gateway and a monitor for the Monster of Slytherin's progress purging the school. Dumbledore and Potter had suspected that Lucius threw it into the Weasley girl's cauldron to rid himself of ties with Voldemort, and to destroy Arthur Weasley's reputation.

"My Lord, perhaps I may be of service after all. The diary that you created to reopen the Chamber of Secrets- I would be able to place it into the possession of a student and we could see the Chamber re-opened. No one would know, my Lord, until you deem the time to be right. Dumbledore will not suspect me, especially if I place it in the possession of an unlikely child, perhaps a Hufflepuff. It will distract Dumbledore, he will struggle to explain deaths within his school, and will be even further discredited by the destruction of the Mudbloods. And the blow that it would deal to Potter if his Mudblood companion should die…" Severus suggested breathlessly.

Malfoy stiffened as soon as he heard 'diary,' and Voldemort seemed intrigued. He wore an expression of devious contemplation as he analyzed the merits of this plan. Suddenly Voldemort's face changed, a very sinister light came into his eyes.

"I smell fear Malfoy…why is it that I smell fear?"

Malfoy didn't reply, but the outline of his back rose and fell rapidly, like a cornered animal that knows it's about to be killed.

"Lich, Snape, back to the line," Voldemort hissed dangerously. Severus and Lourdes needed no further encouragement to push their way back into the crowd, for a front row seat to watch what was about to happen to Malfoy.

Voldemort cracked Malfoy with alarming ease, forcing a confession word by painful word from his mouth, so that every Death Eater present could hear exactly what he was being punished for. Malfoy had dared to use a tool entrusted to him by the Dark Lord for his own ends, for something as petty as destroying a blood traitor's reputation.

The series of tortures had a two fold purpose; to give Malfoy something to remember this by, and to show the Death Eaters a few more of the Dark Arts in his bag of tricks. While Cruciatus was a favorite among the Death Eaters, Voldemort favored more exotic fare. He made it an art, examining the effect of every curse the way an artist agonizes over each brush stroke.

Like any interesting painting, this elaborate series of tortures delivered a message: that anyone who thought about using the Dark Lord for their own ends should think twice, and think much, much harder. Some of the curses Severus knew - most of them dealt excruciating pain to specific organs and nerves (without leaving so much as a mark on the skin).

Severus stole a glance at Lourdes here and there to make sure that she wasn't going to have an inconvenient breakdown that might get them a taste of what Malfoy was experiencing. Her eyes were only narrowed slightly; he never saw her blink. She was watching Voldemort, not Malfoy. Voldemort had a grim, furious look on his features as he was about to deal his final blow. Scanning the crowd of Death Eaters, his eyes stopped on Lourdes, and a horrible smile spread over his face.

"Lich." He pointed to the ground in front of him and Lourdes hastened to kneel there. "How much of your life did you give to retrieve the prophecy at your initiation? How many days did you shave off when you fed that ghost with your blood?"

"Three months, my Lord," she replied, keeping her eyes fixed on the ground.

"Three months and she wasn't even mine yet," Voldemort said, in a contemplative tone. "You do not know what you have destroyed, Malfoy, but you will pay for it with your life. I think…ten years should suffice. The lightest of sentences. But that, coupled with your punishment, should leave an impression. My obedient little corpse, take ten years from this unfaithful servant and give it to the master. Also, take the hair and blood you would need to spoil…" Once he had pressed a conjured phial and a small parchment envelope into her hand, Voldemort's horrible smile settled firmly on his face as Lourdes knelt to pull the small silver knife Voldemort had conjured out of a holster on her boot.

Malfoy was still struggling on the ground, prone as a newborn and in twice as much pain. Gnawing on her lip thoughtfully for a moment, Lourdes pressed the knife point just under his eye, as if deciding whether or not she hated him enough to cut him across the face. The blood came from his shoulder instead; she wiped the blade on his collar before cutting a spiteful chunk of hair from the very front, coiling it neatly into the little envelope. After handing the materials over to Voldemort, she turned back to Malfoy, one hand shooting out to grip his chin.

The fear in Malfoy's face was completely undisguised now; as he struggled and gasped, pleading in mumbles for the Dark Lord's mercy. Anything, Malfoy swore, he would give the Dark Lord anything… As Lourdes muttered under her breath, Malfoy had his jaw clenched and his lips pressed together tightly as he struggled, both of his large hands wrapped around her arm, trying to pry her hand off. When she finished the incantation, his mouth was pulled open as wide as it would go, as if by a pair of invisible hands, while he made strangling noises and clawed at her chest.

When Lourdes lowered her head over his and parted her lips, the whole room was filled with the exaggerated sound of Malfoy's forced exhalation as something very bright began to congeal above his mouth. Soft, pearly wisps of light shifted in a little cloud before twisting into a single strand, and breaking off from the rest of the glow visible in Malfoy's throat and mouth.

She sucked the strand of light between her lips before dropping Malfoy, who lay in a gray skinned heap until the glow of life in his throat flushed back into his body. Lourdes held her breath as she knelt at Voldemort's feet. Slowly, he leaned over and opened the gash in his face, revealing a row of dirty, sharp teeth, before pressing his mouth to hers. The contact couldn't have lasted longer than a single, disgusting second, but Severus felt his stomach twist at the sight. Voldemort inhaled sharply before breaking away, the bright glow of stolen life vanishing as soon as it passed the neck of his robes.

Voldemort rose and bared his mouthful of teeth at the crowd. "That is the new price of failure. Fail your Lord and you will quite literally pay with your lives. Those of you awaiting instruction will receive them from Malfoy; I daresay he will not fail me again, or next time I will have the lich take everything… Go, you are dismissed."

Severus cut through the crowd to snatch Lourdes' arm, and they Disapparated in a heartbeat.

-***-

She was shuddering uncomfortably all through the walk back from the Apparition boundary, eager to get the taste of Malfoy's life and the Dark Lord out of her mouth. Severus did not touch her; in fact, he ignored her as determinedly as was reasonable until he had to Disillusion her. Lourdes knew the life transfer disturbed him; hell, it disturbed her.  It had been entirely too easy to hate Malfoy, all she had to do was think about the little girl with the diary. Malfoy gave it to her.  She hadn’t had to use her magic like this properly, formally in… in ages.  Since she was actively working with Capture Unit and she’d taken life from a suspect to resuscitate a victim.  Having to do that spell was an ugly reminder of the other edge of her blade.

Once they were safely inside his quarters, Severus flew into motion as quickly as he could, trying to find Albus. Lourdes forced herself to throw up and attacked her mouth with the tooth brush and a bottle of white spirit before heading for her trunk.  After a moment of searching, and a second of panic, she found it. She had seen ex-wives cling to their wedding rings with the same ferocity that she clung to her O.H.K. manual. While she had never had a husband and had lost a family twice, there had always been her job, her education, and her organization. But O.H.K. shed her the moment she faltered. They did not need her the way she needed it.

Even when there was no O.H.K. to rely on, she'd had a way to escape even if it was only into her head. What did she have now, she wondered, trying her best to combat the numb shock in her body.  

 

There was no organization, no escape, but she still had the books for structure. The manual was battered and dog eared; the inner leaves inked with passages from texts that had been comforting a long time ago. She went back to them now to see if the words still held any meaning in the middle of all this. Curled up on the floor by the trunk there was Jung; good, dependable, very dead Jung. His words spilled across one of the front leaves.

 

"The sad truth is that man's real life consists of a complex of inexorable opposites-day and night, birth and death, happiness and misery, good and evil. We are not even sure that one will prevail against the other, that good will overcome evil, or joy defeat pain. Life is a battleground. It always has been, and always will be; and if it were not so, existence would come to an end." The words were reassuring, not so much so as the pressure of warm arms or the vote of confidence from her superiors, but they did their job well.

Every day is a war; this is the nature of life. She had seen the casualties, spread out across festering crime scenes that would make a civilian want to drop dead or at the very least throw up. She had learned to look at them without blinking, with a critic's eye searching for the hidden clues that solved the puzzle of whodunit. Then she thought about feelings; about rage, anger, and fear. Slipping into them like trying on shoes to get a taste for the victim or the killer, but rarely did she really feel anything.

She compartmentalized her emotions instead, inside the sort of well-ordered mind O.H.K. screened for. They wanted an ambitious mind too, happy to shed personal taste and non-regulation anything for the organization's ideals and rules  Her wardrobe filled with uniforms, her offensively ‘ethnic’ braids grown out at the roots and wrangled into a bun, perfume, makeup, anything that might make her stand out more than she did were shed.  Lourdes made the trade willingly, happy to be inside a structure, because within a structure if you played by the rules and followed orders you were supposed to be safe and successful. It made Lourdes feel unfathomably stupid for having abandoned herself and any hampering ideal, with nothing left aside from uniforms and a manual…

 

Flipping through the pages to basic rules of espionage. The most useful passages had been underlined ages ago, when O.H.K. had thought about using her to infiltrate a small growing Dark Arts cell.

In the effort to integrate yourself with the target organization, the only action you are encouraged not to take, unless explicitly necessary, is to kill. All other action will be discussed with your handler. The operative is an actor playing a part. The operative must never confuse this part with themselves.

But these words left her cold, the instructions she’d built her life around no longer flooded her with the sense of relief and comfort it always had, when its pages had been proof of what could and could not be done.


For a horrible, brief moment sitting there on the floor, Lourdes felt exactly the way she had when her family had died. As if the whole planet, every structure she had ever relied on, had just dropped out from under her feet, leaving her with no foundation.

Lourdes thought about why she did it, about her old desk drawer- the locked one filled with padded leather boxes containing shiny enameled awards hanging on grosgrain ribbons, the ones they confiscated when she was sent to prison.  Lourdes counted the boxes in her head as she walked silently up the dark Head of House staircase behind Severus. The awards were beautiful, and her heart nearly burst with pride when she got to stand in front of a room of her peers to have that little box passed her way. "You are worthy, you belong," was the message, loud and clear. She lived for it, lusted after it every second of the day.   But no matter how many she received, there never seemed to be enough…

Sitting in front of Albus' desk in her chair while Severus spoke, she looked at him across the length of the desk, and felt right then that he was precisely that far away, and nothing more. You are worthy, you belong; that was the message they had both been longing to hear. That was the message that he'd been drunk on every time the Dark Lord looked his way, the same message she'd given up everything for with OHK. Was that the rhetoric that kept him loyal here under Albus?

Albus was at first shocked, but gradually accepting as Severus continued to explain how the meeting had gone, and how at this point things were going along on the Order's track quite nicely. Lourdes' participation in the prison break would be rock solid proof of her 'usefulness' and in turn, rock solid proof of Severus' value as well. Voldemort was, predictably, pleased with not having to operate in the open and the relative safety of the guard island Aurors was still fairly guaranteed. Besides, as Severus pointed out grimly, the public could not very well keep its eyes quite so firmly shut once ten Death Eaters were on the loose.

Most curious of all was how very interested Albus was about Voldemort's reaction to the diary's destruction.

She spoke up in her own defense at the very end. This was Malfoy they were talking about here, and ten years were nothing to the Dark Lord. Lourdes maintained that she had not volunteered for the task or made the suggestion, she merely followed to avoid breaking cover. After all, she said, when you get into bed with the devil, sooner or later you have to fuck.

In the end, both men had given her the wary look she had seen many times before, albeit from the inside of a prison cell. It stung a bit more than she remembered, especially when Severus seemed to be so close now. When she got up to leave, Lourdes tripped over the chair in her dazed state and heard a distant crack like wood breaking. The chair was alright, but Lourdes thought that something in her might not be…

After that, she descended into a frenzy of tactical planning. In an attempt to quiet those nagging worries, she started putting together a packet on Azkaban - memorizing the maps of the island, studying the classified Auror response instructions 'borrowed' from Moody. When Malfoy's plans arrived, they turned out to be surprisingly sound, but whether or not anyone would actually stick to them was another matter entirely. Just to be safe, Lourdes spent several nights in the pool to practice swimming the distance between Azkaban and the Scottish coast in cold water, and spare time pushing and lifting as much weight as she could.

Severus spent his time bouncing from meeting to meeting with any free Order member, trying to make sure that everyone knew what was about to take place. The Aurors had been understandably frantic but had agreed, with much coaxing from Dumbledore, to keep their mouths shut. Severus kept a cautious distance from her for the first two days after the Malfoy incident, but had slowly eased back into the usual routine.

When he presented her a wine-poached peach with balsamic and vanilla syrup one evening after school dinner, she knew things were back on track. He’d even consented to play dummy when she ran through wand-armed attacker neutralization drills, and affixed a plank of wood to the far wall so Lourdes could practice with her throwing knives.

 

Today the Wireless had been tuned to the loudest, most obnoxious station she could find, and the volume cranked to top notch, with some Dr Fillibuster’s Fireworks set off for good measure in an attempt to replicate O.H.K.’s stress inoculation training.  Her practice target had been enchanted by Severus to dart randomly around the room so she could continue to throw knives at it, although his idea of random was entirely too neat and tidy, Lourdes had worked out its pattern in the first twenty minutes and now it wasn’t a challenge.

Today was also Severus' last chance to tell Potter he had been assigned to teach him Occlumency, and he was guaranteed to be in a rotten mood when he got back. Just as Lourdes had shoved the furniture into the corners so she could run through a close quarters combat drill, Severus had come swooping into his quarters, clutching a small bundle of letters and a velvet bag.

“Oi! Snape, be a sport and stand off,” Lourdes shouted over the racket, cracking her knuckles and tossing her practice knife from hand to hand. 

He answered by growling and slamming the letters and the velvet bag down on the table, readying his wand.

"Ah, I see Black was present," Lourdes muttered, edging a few steps in either direction to get an idea of where his body actually was under the robes.

"Well of course, Ms Mezarci," he bellowed, "after all, it is…his house. “Vaccus.” He shot a blank spell in her direction, just a bit of spark light he’d come up with when she was training for the Hit Wizard trials in school. Lourdes snapped into action – it was still second nature - dodging down, around, edging closer to Snape with every missed spell.

Lourdes sucked her lower lip between her teeth and chewed on it for a moment, watching cautiously while Severus’ anger built up to the point where he could no longer contain it as he tried to keep a safe distance from her.

"Aside from his springing on me like an animal, I must endure accusations that I am not trustworthy, that I have not changed," Severus growled, his face lit up with a rare, undisguised hatred. "All this from a man who just got out of Azkaban…"

There was another round of hexes – live this time – that caught her on the hip.  She pushed through the momentary burst of pain and executed a wand disarm wrist lock, twisting him backwards and off balance so he fell flat on his back and she dropped onto his chest and pressed her knife to his neck.  One of the few upsides, even now, to all the time she’d dedicated to O.H.K and the MLEs was that now, fighting was as natural and easily remembered as walking or breathing.

Severus let a stream of rather creative expletives fly when she dropped hard onto his chest. Lourdes slipped off, feeling as annoyed as she had in school when he made a fuss about being tackled.

“My JAW, Ms Mezarci, hasn’t worked properly since I met you,” he hissed, rocking his head from side to side as if to shake off the disorientation. Groping for his wand, he silenced the wireless and the fireworks vanished leaving a crater of silence in their wake.

“Fine for you to complain, but that last round was LIVE.  I didn’t even hit you full force.” Lourdes jerked the hem of her henley up to show him the purple weal on her hip. "You know better than to let Black get to you," she muttered.

"A man only has so much patience. Mine, at the moment, is more than a little worn." He stayed on the floor, summoning the velvet bag from the table, and a glass from the kitchen before peeling the velvet off a crystal bottle filled with amber liquid.

"Since I’m guessing you don’t want to try a blindfolded round… how did it go at the Malfoy's?" she asked, one hand grabbing the other behind her back for a stretch.

"No better," Severus said darkly, pouring a precise amount of brandy and tipping the glass on its side to test the level.

"Care to share a little of that?" Lourdes raised an eyebrow and indicated the bottle with her chin. Grudgingly, Severus pushed the crystal decanter towards her.

"Whoa ho! Grande Champagne! How much is Albus paying you, and more importantly how on earth did you get a hold of this?" Lourdes smirked and waved the absurdly expensive bottle of brandy at him.

"It was a gift from Malfoy," Severus sneered, taking a little sip. "A very excellent way of reminding me of who is supposed to be the superior."

"I see, he left the price tag on.  Doesn't matter who it came from, it all drinks the same," Lourdes declared, wandering into the kitchen to fetch a tumbler.

By the time she'd plopped back on the floor and poured herself a measure, Severus was dangerously entrenched in sulky self-pity. His eyes were reduced to slits as he slouched against the wall, brandy glass under his nose to disguise his sneer. Sitting on the ground after a practice tackle with ill-gotten liquor, with Severus still sore about something Black had said, made her recall their study sessions by the lake.

Now, as then, his sulking pricked at her a little; she wanted to chide him as if he were one of her too-sensitive subordinates. Though something reminded her that Severus rarely allowed himself 'feelings,' so she ought to just let him ride it out.
