"I think you were saying something about the Malfoy's delightful little brunch with you; did anything useful come up?" She raised an eyebrow and then the glass to her nose.

"Naturally, I had to play off the mention of the diary. Malfoy is much less unpleasant towards me in the presence of his family; of course, once we were in the sitting room all bets were off. He's quite smug now, says he has a source of information on the Potter brat. Information the Dark Lord is interested in. Narcissa seems to know about it as well; therefore I suspect it has something to do with Draco. No doubt bullying one of the other students. I'm obliged to keep a closer eye on him now, of course, to see if I can discover which student he's been pushing around and for what information," Severus said, in an annoyed tone.

"Any changes to the schedule or tactics for the operation?" Lourdes smacked her lips and took the glass in one gulp, refilling it when Severus gave her a look of disdain.

"None whatsoever."

"Have they found Karkaroff yet?"

"Most definitely not. The Dark Lord encouraged McNair and his traveling companions to look for evidence of Karkaroff in his old haunts in Bulgaria after they'd spoken with the giants, but they naturally found no trace of him there." Right now he looked more miserable than she felt. As good as Severus was at all of this, it was clearly affecting him a little more than either of them would care to admit.   Most of the holidays had passed already and Severus, she had noticed, had not received a single personal gift, not even from Albus. Nor had he had cause to give any.   No matter who you were that might be a depressing prospect in addition to the multitude of other things he had to be upset about.  Once again Lourdes was struck by that odd, squirmy sense of guilt she’d had as a child when she realized how much she actually had compared to others…

"Wait here, Mister Snape; I have something I think you'll enjoy." She took the second glass in one swig and sprang up, feeling the sudden pleasant burn of light intoxication. Lourdes had been saving this as a bit of a bribe for the next time she had to do something disgusting in the field. But she decided now was as good a time as any to make an attempt at lifting Severus’ morale. Locating the key to the seventh compartment on her tiered locking chest, she popped it open and nearly fell in to the dark compartment in her eagerness to locate a particular object. Her fingers found it easily: a long, fat bundle wrapped in a silk piece-work tapestry of a peacock. Its contents had been a steady translation project that occupied her evenings over the last few years.

Severus' eyes were closed now; he was absorbed in thought apparently. But his head snapped up very quickly when Lourdes dropped the bundle. "Happy Mid-Winter holiday of your choice.  Personally I’d go with Saturnalia…"

"What's this?" he asked suspiciously.

"Open it and you'll see," she said. Severus put aside his brandy and appraised the outside first, very carefully running his fingers over the pieced silk covering and pulling it back to reveal a stack of rough, homemade paper sandwiched between two dark carved boards. Tibetan books were not bound, just sandwiched and wrapped up in a protective cloth before they were shelved.

"This can't be," Severus said obstinately. He cautiously removed the top cover and examined the first sheaf of paper, fingers a millimeter from touching it, while his eyes scrutinizing stylized drawings of plants and Tibetan script.

"Well, it is, and it isn't." Lourdes leaned forward and flipped through the first few pages to show her translations on the back of each leaf.

"First off, it's a copy of a copy of a poison book, and it's only half translated. Papa had his copy of the family book with him when he died. My grandmother had the original, I believe. The translation's been a side project for the past few years, not that I can do much more with it than that. I can stand to give you this copy because I haven't, and I won't, translate the khara sa-gdug potion- the life stealer. Everything else is in there though, including the poison doctor formulas, and the records of two thousand plants, one hundred twenty three animals and fifty minerals."

He now had a strangely pleased, yet slightly offended look on his face as his eyes darted from the book to her. As if he could not figure out exactly what this gesture meant; whether it was a move for power, a display of knowledge, or something entirely foreign…

"It's not that I don't trust you!" Lourdes said quickly, her hand shooting out to rest reassuringly on his forearm. "Papa made such a big deal about keeping secrets in the family; he was the one that trained me to do the funerals and taught me to read out of the Evocator books. If he hadn't, well, I don't think even Albus would have taken me in at school. It was a big deal to him, you know? But trust me, if there's anyone in the world that could do the things in this book, it'd be you. I think even my Grandmother would have to tip her headdress to you on that."

She smirked and raised her eyebrows. "I hope it makes Belby and those other prats at the Potioneers Society cry."

Looking slightly shell shocked, Severus flipped through each page slowly, scanning the papers as if trying to verify their authenticity, staring hard at the illustrations with the faintest of smiles.

"Do you think it'll be of much use? I don't know much about the plants, just what's translated there, but maybe there's something in here that could help with the Cruciatus potions?"

"I won't know until I've read through it. I hardly have a clue at what's in here that I can use, short of the fact that it is a poison book…" he breathed, squinting over an illustration of a turmeric plant.

Lourdes wrinkled her nose irritably as she stood up; she certainly hadn't expected him to dance on the ceiling, but a thank you might be nice. After all, he did have a copy of a book that was never supposed to leave Tibet under pain of death. "Well, you'd better be civil to me or I won't finish translating it."

Just when she'd resigned herself to Severus' bland reaction, she heard the sound of his robes rustling. He was shifting on the other side of the book; lips pressed thin, and eyebrow knitted together in a look of utter confusion. His fingers twitched on the floor as if he were not sure of his next move, before draping his arms around her and jerking her forward.

Lourdes' brain froze; slow to identify this gesture as "hug," and quantify it as "awkward, stiff, convex." Once the initial shock of the whole thing wore off, she was able to relax for a fraction of a second.

Severus put his hands on her shoulders, simultaneously pulling back and pushing her away to look her in the eye. "Thank you," he said in a suspicious, bewildered voice.

Lourdes felt her mouth move from a frozen "o" of surprise to a bemused smile. "Any time."

"Ms Mezarci? Are you still there?" There was a note of panic in Severus' voice, and it was followed by several very quick steps and the collision of two bodies trying to occupy one very narrow stair. For a moment there was only heightened panic, and the dizzy spinning feeling of falling down stairs over top another person, along with the smell of singed hair and wool before they both hit a wall. When she got her eyes to focus properly Lourdes saw the torch a few inches away still blazing merrily, though everything outside that little pool of light was hopelessly dark. There was a fluttering sound, something whipped by… ”Get the brank before she kills Ozama," one of them screamed. Seven, no…six men. Holding her down, resisting the urge to let go of skin as cold as ice. Her mouth stretched open and gagged by a heavy metal mouth piece, jaw prevented from opening by a series of straps.  She was confused – she felt sluggish and drugged but her magic was trying to fight… "Why can't we just cut her tongue out and blind her already?" "O.H.K. wants her tongue and her eyes in tact, in case they need her. Get the brand…" The cell was huge, she was shackled, both wrists behind her back, a web of heavy chain tethering her to the back wall. Heat…there was heat. Pain, she could not scream. Sickness, she could not vomit. Dark. Hot. Alone. A hand… Wait…a hand. On her wrist, hauling her up… Severus. "Shut them down, close your mind." She sorted through her brain, shut this down, close that, and forget that. When Lourdes finally managed to open her eyes it was still black all around, with only Severus' face under-lit gruesomely by the torch light. "Holy Dorje Bragsen," Lourdes choked. She was cold; it clung to her skin like a wet cloak and made her feel numb. "There are three fully grown Dementors here and an untold number of going-to-be's," Severus muttered. "This place is not a basement.  It’s a warren.  We should be trying to find our way back to the stairs." "No," Lourdes said firmly. "We're already down here, so we might as well gather as much information as we can." Severus squinted at her unevenly, and looked as though he was struggling to choose between impulsive curiosity about the dark things hiding in the basement corners and the 'responsible' thing. Lourdes folded her arms over her chest and gave him a challenging look, cocking an eyebrow as if to ask are you afraid? Suddenly, he drew up another torch and passed it to Lourdes. "Try not to drop it." They passed into an inner chamber after cautious navigation through the barrel ceilings and thick rough columns Severus's boot splashed in a puddle and Lourdes ducked to turn her light on it. There was something about half the size of a man growing like fungus there in a puddle of, there was no other word for it, filth. A scabby, skeletal upper torso covered in something that marginally resembled dead pussy yellow flesh (this flesh substance seemed to be a slightly more solid version of the puddle-filth), with arms and a hideous collapsed face. She felt her stomach turn sharply at the horribly familiar smell of a waterlogged corpse. "I wish I'd brought a camera…" Severus muttered, shoving his torch into Lourdes’ free hand and pulling a handkerchief out of his pocket to cover his mouth and nose as he stooped to examine the thing. He didn't even flinch when the thing writhed in the puddle like a beached fish, opening and closing its mouth impotently. When its mouth opened again, it exposed something like a little jellyfish, waving clear tentacles around in the air as if feeling for something to feed on. Lourdes felt her eyes widen and she leaned over Severus to have a closer look. "Disgusting…" "Fascinating," Severus said, balancing precariously on the balls of his feet as he leaned in. "Dorje! Severus, don't touch it," Lourdes snapped instinctively. She was unable to shake the feeling that she'd just arrived on a crime scene and the forensic crew would be just around the corner to poke, prod and yell at anyone who breathed too hard. “Where the hell did the bodies come from?” "There's no record of anything like this." Severus was staring hard at the mess as if trying to fix it in his memory for later perusal at his leisure. Lourdes felt her heart jump like a frog in her chest; a Dementor had just passed so close that she could smell it. "Do we know if Dementors have maternal instinct? They don't seem too interested in us…" "If you've got your mind shut down properly neither of us should be giving the mature specimens much to feed off. For the young there's so much violent energy here I hardly think they need us. Perhaps the mature ones are more concerned with the offspring," Severus muttered, clearly aching to bring back some evidence of this disgusting discovery. "Any species with vulnerable young benefits when the mature adults protect them. And these... things are clearly vulnerable." "We can't leave them here like this," Lourdes insisted. The basement seemed rather large, and she had no idea what the ratio of fully grown Dementors was to the puddle creatures. Which seemed to be partial human skeletons undergoing a very nasty refurbishment... Severus stood up slowly and huddled next to her by the thing in the puddle, eyes narrowed and lips drawn into a tight line as Lourdes handed him one of the torches. "I don't really know that we have a choice. There is no method thus far for destroying a breeding colony. No one has been foolhardy enough to actually go into one before, or at least we have no record of anyone who came back out." "They hate daylight don't they? Can we blow a hole in the ceiling?" Lourdes said, holding the torch as high as it would go.  The dungeon rooms were all interconnected, smooth and slightly slimy with low barrel-vault ceilings.  There was a wall at the end of this area, by the sound of it…    "Oh yes, that would be easy to explain. Besides, I have no idea of this building's structural soundness…" "Alright, so daylight's out." "Logic, Ms Mezarci, is what we need now. We are quite literally groping in the dark, and we do not know if there is a means for destroying them. They're like unforgivable curses, nobody's ever thought to do the research," Severus said scornfully. "Frazier’s Law of Balance suggests that which is created must also be able to be destroyed; nothing is eternally enduring, save for energy, which only changes form," she whispered, reciting a passage from the advanced charms textbook, feeling a warm surge of strength at the recalled knowledge. "Souls are a form of energy, do you think they're still rotting inside those bodies?" "What we do know about Dementors is scarce. We know they breed and grow nourished by certain types of leftover energy, like wraiths and shades, anywhere there was bloodshed or misery, or dark arts. Their favorite form of sustenance is positive scale emotion, the soul and accompanying concientia - but what nourishes them destroys them as well. They can be repelled with the Patronus charm." Severus paused and nudged the thing in the puddle with the toe of his boot, and it flopped pathetically. The minute Severus touched the thing in the puddle, Lourdes could hear the whipping of fabric, and the indistinct hoarse whispers swooping around them. What were they waiting for? "Alright, that's a start I suppose. What do we know specifically about their breeding, Professor?" she muttered. "We know this building is on a ley line, a very long history of violence and Dark Arts, and an unusually strong population of wraiths and shades. What do we know about wraiths and shades?" he countered. "Wraiths and shades are like poltergeists. A high concentration of emotional energy- sadness, torture, depression- makes wraiths and shades. It’s difficult get rid of them permanently, they just re-manifest as long as people occupy the building." "Sitting on top of a ley line might speed that re-manifestation, mightn't it?" "Now that you mention it…it probably would." Lourdes stopped and tried to put all that together, but Severus took a step forwards and she was forced to move. "Dark Arts activity leaves residual trace energy, and this place was absolutely soaked in it," Severus muttered, running his finger over the wall. "Perhaps it is time to consider the Law of Opposites. If Dementors breed in water and cold, heat and fire should be a suitable deterrent, should it not?" "If the Law of Opposites is correct then it should be… I could try to unravel the wraith and shade manifestations here, that ought to cut down the things the young ones are feeding on. Do you think it could weaken them enough?" "Let's not take any chances; we ought to take the mature ones out first. How were you planning on disposing of them?" Lourdes held up the knife she'd had stuffed in her pocket. "Violent disruption, of course. They have bodies, so I figure if I can do enough damage, it will break whatever hold it has over the sucked souls. Works on everything else with a body, right? If you cut open the stomach the contents spill out." "Release the souls and you are essentially dumping food all over the new creatures." "Then we'll have to act in advance. What if I drew up a dual ward system first? One to do a mass banishing of the wraiths, and then I'll activate another to banish the souls? If you can corral all three Dementors in one corner with your Patronus, I can use that as a cover to go in. Once we've got all three bodies destroyed, I can activate the wards and remove as much of the energy the Dementors are growing on as I can. What do you think?" "If we can throw them sufficiently off balance, I can attempt to maintain a hermetic fire," Severus said softly. "We need enough light, and enough heat to destroy the breeding bodies and dispel all shadows but the ones we cast. It won't damage the integrity of the building though." "Fiendfyre? Do you think it will work? Hermetic spells need a fair punch behind them, don't they?" Lourdes said fretfully. The last time she'd seen an attempt at a hard-line hermetic element spell, it was at the cleanup of a disastrous water spell that nearly drowned a whole neighborhood. It had been cast by a cracked old wizard who thought he was going to cleanse the neighborhood of the 'filthy' Muggles. The catastrophes department had a hell of a time trying to cover that up as a burst water main. These weren't the sort of spells you just tossed off when you wanted to water the garden or light the fireplace. "Unless you know of any other method, this plan is about as good as any other," he said. "Now aren't you glad you paid attention in Charms?" Lourdes said, in a weak attempt to lighten the mood. Severus found a reasonably large work space in the middle of the basement area with the highest activity, and began laying down patches of bluebell flame to give Lourdes enough light to work. With her phurba knife clamped between her teeth like an over large bit, Lourdes knelt on the floor and began drawing out the wards with a stub of chalk and a bit of string. One large circle she filled with a carefully calculated logarithmic spiral and one of the longest spells she knew, and for the other she drew a series of concentric circles with spells written around the edges. Severus was setting up a protective line between the two to keep them from being burnt to a crisp at the end. Everything looked good from here, even in the dim light. The last touch was a thread trap off the ornament belt in her coat pocket: a set of carved cross sticks with silk filaments wound around them, placed in the very center of the concentric ward. "They've been awfully quiet…" Lourdes said suspiciously. "Well, I'm afraid we're just about to put an end to that, aren't we?" Severus muttered, cracking his knuckles and fidgeting with his wand. "Are we at all sure this is going to work?" "No," he replied grimly. "Well then, here goes nothing," she said, shrugging off her coat and wadding it up in spite of the cold. It would be easier to move this way. "Whenever you're ready…" "Do it," Lourdes said firmly, shutting down every coherent thought except kill. "Expecto Patronum!" A silver fallow deer, a doe judging by the lack of antlers, emerged gracefully from the end of Severus’ wand and loped across the room, lighting up the three Dementors hunched low over a puddle by the odd back wall. The spindly legged creature wove circles around the crowd and the puddle, throwing the Dementors into a state of confusion. They didn't run from the Patronus though, they seemed bound and determined to keep it away from the young. In a flurry of motion, Lourdes' hand shot into the hood of the closest Dementor and closed around something that she reasoned was a neck, and she took a stab. Contact - the heavy knife sunk through the spongy flesh and brittle bones as easily as a tent stake anchored in sand. Was it screaming? If a Dementor scream sounded like a high, shrill, ringing alarm then it was definitely screaming. Giving the knife a sharp twist, she felt the Dementor's bones crack. She hit it again, and again, eyes narrowed against flying bone and flesh until she'd created a gaping, ragged hole in the creature's body. It sank to the ground, giving Lourdes the chance to grab its head and twist it, to hear the sharp snap of a spine breaking. The scream was replaced by an incoherent babble as a swirling silver mass escaped through the hole in the chest. Centuries of souls, reduced from separate entities into one rotted, indistinct mass. There was a heavy bruising pressure around her neck: one of them had its hand on her throat. She tried to press her chin to her chest, her free arm sweeping across the dementor’s as she twisted out of the grip.  The Dementor sucked desperately at the air as Lourdes struggled to keep her mouth shut.  The knife made contact, and Lourdes dropped to her knees, dragging it down with her weight before she heard the sick shattering noise again. The Dementor gasped lamely, as if making one last attempt to take her soul, before it dropped too. She reached out to get at its head, but fell over on her elbows. The Patronus was pawing the ground and rearing to try and repel the remaining Dementor which was reaching for its hood… She was fighting a loosing battle with her mind which was suddenly swimming with miserable images, Aberforth's face frozen in an anguished howl, the six patrons holding him back as the edges of her vision went dark. He was getting further away, she was being carried away. There was a horrible ache in her chest, her heart was breaking… There was a sharp shattering sound. When Lourdes uncovered her eyes, and saw the last Dementor's chest had been blown wide open – and so had the wall behind it. She wasted no time, snapping the two remaining necks before springing up. She ran right into Severus who'd had to get very close to use that curse, and he caught her under an arm and pulled her back into the center circle. Keeping rhythm with her hands, her whole body swaying smoothly, Lourdes chanted, blocking out everything but her work. The spiral in the first ward started to glow, the ward lines lighting up as she worked. The silver clouds released from the Dementor's bodies were being pulled into the ward, swirling around like a vast milky galaxy as a mirror image of the ward etched itself in bright light at the ceiling's height. When the entire ward was lit up, Lourdes changed rhythm and the silver clouds began to twist as it was sucked through the ward on the ceiling. The ward exploded in a burst of light like a dying star, before it collapsed into itself. Lourdes felt a hot rush of satisfaction at seeing a spell completed under her watch, and she turned to the next ward. Shades and wraiths were easy work; as soon as the ward filled up to the center circle with a crackling cloud like static lightning, Lourdes knew she had them all. Reciting the spell carved into the thread trap, she sent it spinning. As the thread flew off the cross sticks, the cloud itself seemed to unravel as well, changing from a crackling tendriled mass to a soft mist that funneled into the ground. When it went dark she heard the sharp snapping of wood, a sign that the cross sticks had cracked and the spell was broken. "Now that the distractions are out of the way," Severus said, pushing up his sleeves and rolling his neck to either side. He flicked his wand towards the ceiling, holding it so his index finger pointed upwards as well. "Creo Ignem." The initial searing blaze of heat was followed by a soft coolness, the protective line activating itself. Ghostly blue runes glowed on the floor, their soft light extending up to a smooth blue circle that floated in the air just above Severus' wand. Through the barrier she could see the whole floor lit up with molten heat that bubbled and lapped up the walls, shifting form elegantly. Slowly, steadily, it enveloped the whole room in waves, and turned the corners to seep into the next room and all the corridors. It was a beautiful spectacle; capering flame-forms of all manner of grotesque nightmare creatures blazed gold and orange, swirling and leaping across the walls and ceiling, and cascading down to the floor like rain. They seemed to be having a marvelous time, if such a thing were possible, while Severus kept his eyes narrowed in intense concentration. If anything survived this onslaught it would be a miracle. The fire ebbed away obediently, and when it slid back down the walls the air was clear, the atmosphere was normal again. "Finite." He looked a little pale and sweaty from the obvious effort and took a none-too-stable step forward in an attempt to collect himself. This time, she caught him. -***- She hardly flinched when she caught him under the arms and braced him while he got his legs back. With his face buried in her neck and her mess of hair he could smell soap mixed with something even worse- like decomposing flesh. Or more specifically, Dementor… "Say what you will about my bathing habits, Ms Mezarci, but on my worst day I never smelled anything like you do now," he coughed, pushing himself away and taking a step back to have a look at her in the wand light. Her clothes were covered in some viscous substance they'd just now noticed. "I don't even want to know what this is," she winced. "A little help here?" "Tergeo," Severus muttered, taking care to make sure every bit of the mess was removed for the sake of his sense of smell. He'd gotten a fair bit of it on himself when he landed on her. Lourdes paused, face frozen in an attractive expression of contemplation as if she were sniffing the air for something. "Mister Snape, I think we've done it." She was right - the basement was… normal. The air was clear. Severus rushed up the stairs to see if he could spot her from the top, and there was no trouble at all; the little electric light switch even worked now. He felt oddly buoyant as a vision of the Order of Merlin, glittering in its velvet and leather box, danced in his brain. Rushing back down the steps he stopped dead to give her a very serious look. "You do realize, Ms Mezarci, that we are probably the first people on record to have successfully destroyed a breeding colony of Dementors?" Before he knew it those wiry little arms were wrapped around him, nearly crushing his rib cage, before he was hoisted off the ground for a moment. "This was GENIUS," Lourdes snarled into his neck. Dropping him back on his feet, she pulled back and flashed him a wild expression.

 

There was something about the intensity of her expression - an exhilarated half-grin when she locked eyes with him - that sent a shockwave straight through his body.  It burned, flushing him with an inexplicable heat and ignited a sudden barrage of half-formed images and impressions that were in and out so fast he couldn’t make much sense of them.  All he knew was that it felt…good. The sight of her tattoos brought him firmly down to earth. She was an Evocator; they'd just theoretically broken about five go-straight-to-Azkaban laws. That little leather and velvet box went up in mental flames… With a sour expression, he wrestled himself out of her grip and smoothed his sweater back down. "Be that as it may, I doubt the Ministry would see it the same way." Lourdes frowned, and flopped down on the ground to re-holster her knife. "Good point. At least that fire burned off everything on the floor, and the thread trap. I've honestly never seen anything like it- was that one of the Dark Lord's old tricks?" "However did you guess?” he muttered. A brief investigation of the house was further proof that they'd succeeded; everything was as clear and bright as could be expected out of a Muggle-built Gothic Revival castle.  The wall he had blown out seemed to have been erected to cover a hilariously fake looking shrine in the fashion of Druids festooned with skulls and a goblet, but more ominously, there was a gaping hole behind it that Severus and Lourdes decided not to explore.  It was the remains of an informal charnel house, from the plague days.  Where the Dementors had gotten the bodies.  Severus hastily re-erected the wall, and Lourdes declined to do anything, insisting that spirits, and not long-dead bodies were the real problem.

"That's a very interesting change to your Patronus," Lourdes said in a sly voice, verging on a snicker as she locked the house door. She must have been doing her best to remain composed but she had her lips pressed together tight and her cheeks were pink as if she was trying very, very hard not to laugh. “It works, doesn’t it?” he said coolly “Yeah….I suppose it does,” she snickered this time, hiding her strained grin behind her hand before all composure failed her and Lourdes let out a long, derisive howl of laughter. She was laughing so hard in fact that there were tears gathering at the edges of her eyes and she had to lean against the castle to stop her self from falling down. Severus looked at her as if she’d gone quite mad, and Lourdes flapped her hands urgently at him, stammering something about “Gotta breathe, gimme a sec…”

When she finally collected herself and wiped her cheeks with her coat sleeve, Lourdes offered something in the way of an explanation. “Sorry, its well… wasn’t it a fox before?” “It was,” Severus said stiffly. “Gods, see, when I worked in Capture Unit they had everyone doing the Patronus charm just in case, because there were some rumors they were breeding in Bulgaria and it was quite a scare. But Ozama, biggest bloke I’ve ever met - neck like a telephone pole and this big bull chest and shoulders.   I mean here we are expecting this huge ferocious Patronus and what pops out of the end of his wand? Butterflies! A big cloud of BUTTERFLIES. We reckoned it was going to be something that matched him, a bear or something but… Dorje, we didn’t let that go for WEEKS, I mean people were charming them to fly around his desk, or hiding them in his locker. Ozama was a sport though, turns out his dad was an entomologist and used to take him to Oludeniz during the butterfly migrations. But when it got out that Degmez’s Patronus was a peacock…” Severus raised an eyebrow disapprovingly at the thought of Lourdes and her cadre of coworkers taking the piss out on some poor man thinking about his father. “And how well did they respond to your inability to produce one?” “Wasn’t an issue, during the scare I kept a Tngri, a fire spirit, bound on my blood. You can summon them in a snap if you’re willing to pay properly.” She pushed her coat aside and tugged on the waistband of her jeans to show him a bruise colored mark and a blurry bit of foreign script. “You use a charmed fang, sink it in somewhere and seal the charm. As long as one of them decides you’re suitable and if you aren’t afraid of loosing a teaspoon’s worth of blood every day you’ve got a dead handy companion on your hands for immediate materialization. It’s a lot less risky than trying to bind a demon or something else that’s constantly shifting form and perception. Tngris are reliable… They broke my charm when I went to prison though,” Lourdes sighed.  “I might see to putting it back in actually…” “And pray tell what form does your little fire take?” he sneered. “A tiger, if it likes,” she said brightly. “That was my Papas Patronus as well. I mean not that yours is funny, but it’s not what you’d expect. I would have thought the fox had stayed, or maybe bats or something like that.  It’s not really weird, but I mean, it is a bit dainty.  What do you think about? When you cast it?"  Her expression changed for a moment, becoming intense and focused "The night I came back." Severus said shortly. Tilting her head to one side, Lourdes looked at him as if he were a rather meaningful work of art, before she hooked her arm around his. "Let's go." She sighed and butted her head against his shoulder affectionately. "I sort of missed you." "Oh," he said slowly, not entirely sure how to feel about that statement and all it implied. "I came back because I missed everyone. I missed Aberforth, I missed you, and I even missed the bloody goats." Severus knew this was true; he felt that ugly thump in his chest again. Lourdes turned her neck in the other direction to crack it and then looked mournfully at the dirty snow lining the driveway. "Its cold." "It's winter," he replied thickly. "I should get used to it, you know? It's much colder in Tibet," she sighed. "What's in Tibet?" Severus asked cautiously. "Goats." "And what precisely do goats have to do with you?" "That's where we're going, Aberforth, me, and a whole mess of goats, when all this war rot is over. I think he's sick of the pub, and Tibet is the only country that hasn't got laws against people like me," she said winsomely. "We'll have one of the nice proper houses and I'll keep up my buisness." Something cold and slimy invaded his gut, resentment or betrayal perhaps. She was barely here and she was already talking about leaving. Why should I care, he thought rather bitterly. If she wanted to leap from one dead life to another, it was no skin off his nose. "I've seen pictures of Tibet; its all rocks and scrubby little trees. Not hard to see why your father left." "No, my father was from the south east, all jungle. I’ve still got distant relatives there, but I they’re not worth meeting. Rotten, inbred purebloods I’m told. Nearly bled Papa dry of magic when he tried to get the books for me. Papa though - left fulfilling a life debt to a French witch, acting as her guide out of the country. She was off her nut, trying to sneak through the country dressed up as a beggar monk and nearly got herself killed when my Grandmother slipped a little poison in her tea to try to steal her magic. Not that I blame my Grandmother, her family was all Dugma poisoners, apparently never saw the merit in wasting magic on morons. I think I told you how he ditched that French witch when he saw Mama in Tashkent. Ran off and married a woman he fell in love with at first sight. They just sort of kept going after that…" She smiled, soft and warm this time. "Your father came from a Dugma family?" How the hell had that escaped him? The Dugma's poison book was one of the most coveted, lusted after texts on Tibetan plants and brewing methods in existence, prized because foreigners were barred from Tibet as a rule, and there was an automatic death sentence for anyone caught removing texts or artifacts. Every so called poison book that had made it out turned out to be a poorly imagined forgery or a disguised Sutra. Severus still laughed when he remembered the very public humiliation of Dagworth, President of the Extraordinary Society of Potioneers. It had been at a meeting when Dagworth blustered that he was going to unlock the secret of the Dugma method for stealing life and magic. He spent two hours detailing a very unlikely adventure where he snuck into Tibet by way of Mongolia. He claimed to have rescued a Lama from a Yeti, and apparently the holy man was so grateful he gave Dagworth his 'most precious possession,' the mystical book of the life stealing poisoners. Dagworth presented it with pomp and circumstance, inviting a notable Himalayan scholar to examine it in front of the crowd. When the scholar flipped open the cover of the "Poison book", he read off the first few lines of the Heart Sutra. Dagworth's face had gone purply red like a slab of bad meat when Severus' laughter rang out loud and started the whole room cackling, even Belby, the stuck up git, had gone on doing impressions of Dagworth over pints for ages. "I'm sure I told you that." Lourdes screwed up her face as she thought through it. "I know I told you that. Within the first couple of weeks of Occlumency." He indulged in a very satisfying little fantasy in which he paraded not only a Dugma descendant, but a real copy of the sacred text in front of a room full of potions rivals and nay-sayers. Relishing the imaginary looks of deepest envy and awe on the faces of incurable snobs like Dagworth, Slughorn, and Belby… Ha! Wolfsbane potion that, Belby… Suddenly he could see it again: Severus Snape, Order of Merlin, first-bloody-class for outstanding achievement in the potions research sector. "Tibet is really all I have left," she said in a small voice. Severus paused, and looked at her; she didn't mean that. He knew it; Severus was getting rather good at reading between her lines. She said "Tibet is really all I have left," and she meant "tell me you want me to stay." Severus had to wonder if she could read him as well as he could read her. "Before you go anywhere, Ms Mezarci, to Tibet or to anywhere else for that matter, I expect you'll have to finish the report on exactly what we did here today…"

This chapter is rated GR- For Gross. Though if you have no problem watching CSI or your average zombie movie all should be well. To Heat and Frost Woe to you, wicked souls! Hope not ever to see Heaven! I come to carry you to the other bank, into eternal darkness, to heat and frost. - Dante, The Inferno Severus prowled the aisles of his fifth year Potions class fighting the urge to yawn or show any sign of fatigue. When he began teaching some fourteen years ago, the epidemic of ineptitude Severus saw in the sea of dead eyed children inspired a sort of artistic devastation. Now teaching was one of those chafing annoyances, like a pebble in one's shoe or an itch at the back of the throat. All they had to do was follow the instructions on the board; it wasn't as if he was asking them to write an existentialist novel or cook a flawless soufflé. Invariably, essays were sloppy and the class work was dismal with very few exceptions. If there was a purgatory worse than being forced to teach an art you excelled at to students who did not care, Severus could not think of it. Happily, Albus did not much care how he taught the lessons so long as the abuse remained verbal; apparently he operated under the idea that certain un-pleasantries 'built character.' If that was the case, Severus was the master character architect. He had eventually figured out how to enjoy himself on the job: by seeing how hard he had to squeeze the students to get a worthwhile result. Children were like grapes really- the harder you trod on them the more juice you got (and he might as well have been teaching raisins). Stifling another yawn, Severus drifted back up to his desk to have another drink of coffee, a beverage he only resorted to on the worst days. Today was bad because last night had been worse. Arthur Weasley had been attacked, but stranger still was the way it had been discovered. Potter (Severus was only half aware of the growl that escaped him at the mere thought of the brat) had dreamt he was the snake that attacked Arthur. Then Potter ran straight to Minerva, who ran straight to the Headmaster with the news and the Order was able to take quick action. Potter had in effect saved Arthur Weasley's life, without even being in the same bloody room. Once he and the Weasleys had been shipped off to headquarters and Umbridge had been dealt with, Albus had sent his Patronus messenger down to their bedroom. Severus in black woolen long-johns and dressing gown, and Lourdes in her cashmere pajamas and oversized cardigan had appeared in Dumbledore's office pale faced with dark circles under their eyes. For the rest of the night they struggled to stay awake, drawing up theories and shooting them down while Albus kept the hot chocolate and tea coming. They could not be sure if the snake had been Voldemort himself in an Animagus form, or if he was remotely manipulating Nagini. Apparently that was something that wonder-boy Potter had not seen in his dream. Lourdes had groggily suggested the Imperius curse, but it was a dead end. Animals, especially highly magical animals, were not as easily controlled. Their brains were radically different than humans. Possession of the snake's body might have been an option, but as Lourdes was quick to point out, only a disembodied soul could possess something, and it had to be invited too. That bit seemed to pique Albus’ curiosity and he left Lourdes and Severus to their bickering as he scooted along his bookshelves on the ladder, scrutinizing titles as he went. There was also the possibility that Voldemort was subverting a spell used by Aurors and Hit Wizard teams who sent in rats bonded to the mind of a controller in order to get an idea of a buildings interior before a strike. Having exhausted the possibilities on the snake issue, they attempted to tackle the question of how the child dreamt the events. The only thing they could be sure of at that late hour was that whatever they were dealing with now was absolutely out of the ordinary.  Lourdes had burst out shouting “BUSHMEN!” and going on about the divided soul in animals, stubbornly refusing to entertain any other ideas.    Severus turned on her and they'd had a rather long row about the outdated practices associated with sympathetic magic, and the laws of contagion and contact. Albus took that opportunity to start research, but had to break the fight up when Lourdes leaned in and snarled that just because something was outdated did not mean it was useless, and furthermore if his brain was as big as his conk (she leaned in and flicked him hard on the nose) he’d have figured that out already… The watch shifts at the Department of Mysteries had been completely called off; three casualties were too much for even Albus' conscience. Though on the off chance that Voldemort had realized the connection between himself and Potter, Albus had decided to take cautionary measures. He wouldn't say why he couldn't teach Potter Occlumency, he only assigned Severus to the task without entertaining any arguments. Severus received a letter he was to give to Black at his leisure, so long as he and Potter were informed before school began. With his potentially peaceful holidays already spoiled by the news, Severus decided to put it off for as long as he could. By the time they made it back to his quarters, it was seven in the morning, only an hour before he had to start lessons. Lourdes had taken advantage of his absence from the big bed and holed up there under her feather stuffed blanket, drooling on his favorite pillow. She did look awfully cozy, so much so that Severus had been tempted to shove her out once she'd warmed the bed up so he could have a little nap. Payback for the “conk” bit… Instead he'd had the house elves put on coffee and sat down to write to Malfoy about his assignment. He peppered the letter with assurances that Potter would never learn to block his mind, only grudgingly admitting that he had to teach the brat. Severus got a letter at lunch from Malfoy indicating that the Dark Lord had felt a disturbance in his mind and suspected that Albus would be trying to shield the boy. Though, when Severus went to tell Albus, he was gone. Glancing at the clock, he groaned inwardly; another fifteen minutes left with these little dullards before he could go reclaim his bed. When he looked up, he caught Granger stealing a glance at him as if she suspected he'd murdered Potter and Weasley just for fun. Cleverest witch of her age indeed; the little twit would jump off a cliff if she read it in a book. Then there was a shout from Longbottom's table. Well hoo-bloody-ray, it wasn't a Friday unless Longbottom blew something up. When Severus saw that the last of the slugs had been peeled off the walls, and that Longbottom felt as frazzled and twitchy as he did, he was finally able to retire to his quarters. Sure enough, Lourdes was still holed up in his bed, wrapped around his favorite pillow (it was the only one that still had a bit of spring to it), with a dreadfully smug grin on her sleeping face. Too tired to care anymore, he worked off his boots and flopped onto the bed's free space fully clothed. He was asleep before his head even hit the pillow. Midway through the night, he woke up to find Lourdes twisting herself up in all the blankets like a caterpillar in a cocoon, muttering something that sounded like "the goats." Groggily, Severus recalled that the primary reason Aberforth had hired Lourdes was because she was very good with goats (she had been a surly barmaid). If a nanny gave birth to a weak kid, she never hesitated to curl up under a blanket with it to help maintain body temperature; the old fashioned way is best, she'd insisted. After a futile battle to try to reclaim some of the blankets, Severus grunted a bit as he watched Lourdes sleep there; it was a bit hard to make the image of a cold government agent fit with the memory of the goat's nurse. When he slept, he dreamt of the time she carried the weakest kid swaddled against her bare back like an Eskimo baby as she hauled trays of tankards against one sharp hip. He woke up right on schedule on Saturday morning to the usual empty expanse of bed. Severus scrounged in the back of his wardrobe for his default Muggle clothes; a black army jumper and woolen trousers, with his hair in a ponytail. Unfortunately the disguise didn't make him feel terribly cunning, just itchier and more like a prat than usual. Lourdes actually looked excited when he found her at the tea table, bent over the Daily Prophet with a truly bizarre assortment of food crammed on a large plate and drenched in rosemary gravy. She'd dressed for the occasion with a gray knitted Henley shirt over a pair of well worn jeans with heavy military boots. She'd also caked on a layer of makeup that covered her scars rather well, but not her tattoos. Well, at least that accounted for the mess of discarded tins of "Gilderoy Lockhart's Fantabulous Correcting Coverall" in the bathroom. "Don't you look cozy," she snickered. Severus growled and sneered in response, feeling like a cat stuffed in doll clothes. Leaning over to spear a sausage off her plate, he took a big bite before brandishing his fork at her. "Let it be noted, Ms Mezarci, that I am giving up a perfectly good Saturday to escort you when I could have simply dumped you on the werewolf. You would be well advised not to irritate me." "Oh that would have been oodles of fun. Has Lupin changed much since Hogwarts? Did he ever get a spine or is he still subject to Black's every whim?" Lourdes stifled a yawn and looked expectantly at him. "I believe you're familiar with the events of Black's escape. Even when Black was supposed to be a murdering convict, Lupin kept his secrets. Interesting, though; one would have thought that an Evocator would be more understanding of a werewolf." "It has nothing to do with the fact that he's a werewolf, he never pulled his load on prefects duties. Lazy git," she said absent mindedly as she studied the social column. "Where are we off to Ms Mezarci?" he muttered, leaning over to scoop up a forkful of egg. "Charleville Forest Castle, Ireland, County Offaly. How are we going to get there?" "We'll Apparate." "I did a bit of research on the spot; apparently it has the sort of history that makes a lovely breeding ground for Dementors. Druid sacrifice site first, perfect intersection of Ley lines, a plague burial ground, and then someone put a castle on it around the Regency when all those Hell Fire clubs were popping up. Apparently there was a fair bit of Dark Arts activity on the site when the castle was first built and it's been all down hill from there." "Did Lupin's little service sift this one out?" Severus sneered as he tried to stab some bacon onto his fork. Lupin had been posing as a Muggle 'paranormal investigator' on the side to keep an eye on Dementor activity and any possible Dark creatures out of bounds. When Muggles sought help from 'ghost hunters,' requests matching Dementor activity were answered by an Order member with free time and a strong Patronus. The Ministry was not willing to admit that some of their Dementors were out of control. "We're answering the call today as agents from the service," Lourdes yawned. "Delightful." "And it's almost Winter Solstice, so we're in for some trouble." "Ms Mezarci, I know what to do with a Dementor," Severus sneered, jabbing his fork in the air at her. "That's the problem, I need to see if I can get near them without having to do a soul extraction on myself," Lourdes said quickly. Severus dropped his fork and stared at her incredulously. "Ms Mezarci, for the sake of security, don't you think it would be wise to go with the method you know best?" "If things go the way we expect, and they likely will now that the Dark Lord can't get into the Department of Mysteries, we'll be going to Azkaban, won't we?" "Obviously." "Well, if the Dark Lord's got any brains he'll have me taking care of the Dementors, just in case. And let's just say that I don't like taking out my soul if I don't absolutely have to. It's the safest way to get around the Dementors but…" Lourdes shuddered and shook her head vehemently. "I want to see if can stand to be near them long enough to do enough physical damage to disrupt the bodies, maybe incapacitate them." "I can't believe I am obliged to indulge you in doing something so unbelievably stupid," he muttered, surveying the plate to see if there was anything left worth eating. "Try the cheese, it won't kill you," Lourdes said, as she slid out of her seat and headed for the bedroom. The cheese did not kill him; in fact it was rather tasty once he scraped the gravy off. His wool trousers, however, were a different story. Severus had to resist the urge to scratch himself in unbecoming places as he rummaged for his beaten-up trilby hat and top coat that once belonged to his father. Lourdes, with sharply tailored wool overcoat and fur lined military hat, looked as though she were in uniform. As soon as all scarves were tucked neatly inside coats and their gloves were on, they took the usual path out of the castle. His sense of direction must have been off that day because Severus mis-Apparated twice before they got anywhere within range of County Offaly. Once they ended up in some poor farmers haystack, and the second time they ended up in the alley behind a pub in Tullamore. When they finally landed in front of a massive oak tree, they knew they were in the right spot. Lourdes fished around in her pocket for the scrap of paper Lupin had written the details on while Severus slipped his wand up his sleeve into a quick release holster, just in case. "Looks like we need to speak with one of the property owners, says here they're staying in the caretaker's cottage. Which should be right over there," Lourdes said, pointing to a very twee building that seemed out of place on grounds that fairly hummed with ancient magic. She donned a pair of mirrored sunglasses to hide her tattoos before rapping smartly on the door. It opened just a crack, revealing a sliver of a twenty-something boy, sandy haired and fine-boned with a slightly dazed expression that suggested he’d headed one too many footballs in his day.  His appeal wasn’t lost on Lourdes, who slid her sunglasses down her nose a bit, presumably to better take in the sights. Severus felt his face twist into an annoyed sneer. "Hello…?" The boy surveyed them cautiously before Lourdes composed herself and gave the boy a tight, rusty smile that did not sit well with the rest of her features. "Hello, my name is Lourdes Mezarci, and this is Severus Snape; we're from the Society for Psychical Research. You placed a request for our help?" Her hand shot out and the boy shook it warily. "Aye, we did. Please, come on in and I'll change so I can take you up to the castle. I’m William, by the way." William smiled a nervous, glittery smile that made Severus think of a threatened dog, and stepped back to let them into the cozy little living room. The moment he vanished down the hallway, Lourdes relaxed and sank into a wingback chair, tilting her head to look down the hallway after him. “Nice,” she said slyly. "He's your type is he?" Severus said casually, examining the kitschy figurines gathering dust on the mantle piece. “And a double barreled surname.  How’d you like to be a Hutton Bury?” "Nah, I’ve always been partial to meatier specimens. But I've never had time for one," Lourdes replied absent mindedly, turning to examine the family photos on the side table. Her eyes narrowed as she apprised groups of smiling people motionless inside the frames. She didn't seem to realize what she'd said- never had time - and in a flash Severus knew. He saw the tiny apartment crammed with cartons of books, papered in crime scene reports, the little refrigerator filled with single serve instant dinners, the wardrobe full of personality-less uniforms. He felt the miserable sticky heat of nights under a bare bulb in regulation under-things on graying sheets with only photos of the dead for company. Feeling an ugly little thump somewhere in his chest, he knew what she did not tell him months ago in her confession. Without even having to look her in the eyes, he saw her whole rawboned, dingy, overworked life married to an organization that did not love her the way she loved it. Before Severus could figure out whether he wanted to use this new weapon, William reappeared in a puffy coat and deerstalker hat carrying a keychain. Flashing a smile that seemed less threatening now, he led them out into the snow, starting up a wide path flanked by naked oak trees. Lourdes glided along at William's side, fairly purring as they discussing his university degree (Archeology, at Oxford) and the wonders of Hittite culture, while Severus stayed a few steps behind, unable to resist the urge to roll his eyes every time she let out a low, predatory laugh in response to one of his jokes.   Though the sky was gray and overcast, the icy mist that hung ominously around the castle and the trees… As soon as they got within spitting distance of the castle, William fumbled in his pocket for the keys and handed them off to Lourdes. "If you don't mind, I'll be heading back to the house. The castle gives me the collywobbles, so I'll leave it t'you professionals. If you need a bit of warming up afterwards, we've got plenty of soup and tea up at the house that you're welcome to, of course." With one last stupid grin, William was off. -***-

“Hear that? A bit of warming up, Mr. Snape.  I daresay you ought to wait in the living room.” Lourdes covered her mouth and gave Severus a coy look.  It was too easy to take the piss out on him when he’d spent the whole walk to the castle grumbling a few steps behind her like a horrible old man.

 

“But whatever will dear Brandon think when I have to tell him you prefer meatier fare?” he replied, voice thick with sarcastic “concern..”

 

“I expect by the time you can mention it to him, Brandon…won’t care.”  She fluttered her eyelashes and rolled her eyes before twisting the key and giving the door a good shove and a slam with her hip, admitting them into a dusty gallery with a checkerboard tile floor.  A vast staircase dominated the room with a grand crystal chandelier hanging cockeyed over top.   The change in the atmosphere was instant; it was dim, despite the windows, and strangely misty. Inside it was even colder than it was out in the snow, a sort of cold that crept through the clothes and under the skin. Lourdes heard them all at once, every voice muttering or sobbing, making threats and pleas to no one in particular. Wraiths, energy left behind by a violent death. She hadn't heard this many of them in one place since she was in prison, and the intensity of it made her sick to her stomach. Deep breaths, take it easy… you can do this, she thought, slumping back against a paneled wall for support. "How many wraiths?" Severus voice sounded distant in the midst of the noise. "Ah…" Lourdes sucked air through her teeth as a sharp pain shot through her head. "I don't…I don't know."  She struggled to look around and get her bearings.  There was only one option in terms of navigation and that was to go up the stairs. "Focus, Ms Mezarci," he said sharply. Her eyelids twitched and fluttered as she worked to shut down the part that heard the hissing and mutterings until the only sound left was the humming of her blood in her ears. She lurched uneasily up the stairs behind him, drawing deep breaths and counting her own footsteps as they drifted into the largest, brightest room they could find. "If you cannot even handle a minor wraith incident, how do you think you're going to survive getting near those Dementors?" Severus said coldly, folding his arms over his chest and staring imperiously down his nose at her once they’d reached the entrance of a grand and starkly furnished gallery. "Fuck off!  I'm a little out of practice you know," Lourdes shot back savagely, drawing herself up to full height to match him. "Where do you suppose we'll find the breeding activity?" "You said there was a Druids' circle here?" he asked, moving to stare out the window into the woods.  The room was bizarre – a long gallery with elaborate paneling and ceiling moldings and incongruous disco balls hung here and there.  The whole room was starkly white washed but that did little to brighten the feel of the room.  The whole place had an air of half-repaired and inevitable decay.  Evidently William and his family were short on funds, and the castles current occupants would have made them hard to gather… "Yes, but I think it's out in the woods." "Does this castle have a dungeon?" "It has a basement, I don't know that you could call it a dungeon," Lourdes said, raising an eyebrow as she took a few cautious steps across the gallery towards the end that looked dimmest. "Are you coming?" "Right behind you," Severus said, almost absent mindedly, as he threw one last glance out the window. "So, ah, where does one usually put the entrance to a dungeon?" Lourdes said, poking her head into the hallway and staring down either end. Strangely enough she was a little apprehensive. Humans she could deal with. Dementors…well that was what they were here to see about. Severus swept past her into the hall and took a moment to size the situation up, eyes darting coolly in either direction before starting down to the left, and Lourdes followed closely. The fog was definitely thickening in this end of the hallway as they approached a towerside stone staircase with crumbling plastered walls.  It was poorly lit and the shadows on the walls flickered and shifted as if they had lives of their own. They seemed to be whispering to one another, the voices sent a tingling shock of fear out from the center of her chest, making the hair on the back of her neck stand on end and tears gather in the corners of her eyes. "Do you hear that?" Lourdes muttered, her hand shooting out to grab Severus by the shoulder. He turned and gave her a withering look. "I thought you'd decided to focus away from the obvious wraith activity here, Ms Mezarci…" "This is different- look at the walls." Lourdes drew a little closer to him and pointed to the corner. The natural shadow there warped abruptly and Severus' muscles tensed under her hand, though his face remained passive. The shadows and the weird hoarse whispers threw her so off her guard that the sudden sounds of footsteps, a scramble, and then a horrible thud followed by a child’s scream near the staircase nearly made her jump out of her skin.

 

Lourdes felt an involuntary impression of a scene flash through her mind of the ceiling growing distant very quickly…and then nothing at all.

"Wraith…" Severus muttered dismissively. Lourdes was glad to see that for all his blustering his eyes were watering too. "Child," she hissed, looping her arm around his, drawing closer for warmth. "Ms Mezarci, you realize you're clinging to my wand arm, don't you?" he muttered with a sneer. "We should be approaching this… professionally. Do you want to take the lead?" she said crisply, dropping his arm and rubbing her hands together. "As I've got the wand, I think that's only proper." "Don't get too puffed up about it," Lourdes muttered, feeling a stab of irritation at his sudden urge to pull rank. "I'll head up the back." Severus began a slow survey of the walls and the floor once they’d reached the dank basement hall, stopping every once in awhile to tap the toes of his boots against the junction of wall and floor, or rap his knuckles against the wall, looking for any indication of a hidden entrance. Lourdes made regular rotations, keeping a very sharp eye on the shadows which were still shifting along the walls, trying to move when she was not looking at them. It gave her the very bizarre sensation that they were being observed… "Here," Severus said suddenly. "These Muggle architects are artless, you can see the hinges." As he searched for the device to open the door, Lourdes heard the hoarse whispers snickering and hissing as if they were very pleased. She grabbed Severus urgently by the shoulder and looked him straight in the eye. We're being watched, she thought firmly. Severus nodded to signify that he understood and flicked his wrist, causing his wand to slide easily into his hand. Lourdes reached down and hiked up the leg of her jeans to get to the heavy phurba knife she had holstered there. It was a far cry from the little ice pick of a dagger she usually chose. The phurba was stout with a three sided blade like a tent stake; it did a brutally efficient amount of damage. If there was anything to damage, Lourdes thought grimly. The wall clicked, and swung open just a little bit. The voices grew louder, and the air grew colder, but it was no worse than being hit by a chilly current in an already cold lake. Severus had the tip of his wand lit up, but she could not see any further than the length of his arm. "This would be the spot," he said. Looking down into the miasma of the basement, the darkness seemed almost hungry. As if the moment they crossed the threshold, the door might slam shut and the house would devour them whole.  Her body pulsed with a ripple of ice cold pinpricks just under her skin. "They're young, still hungry," Severus murmured, as if he could read her mind. "They don't really know what to do…yet" "It's bizarre. I don't feel any life at all." She was a little tired of waiting, and stretched her neck back and forth to ease the tension in her upper body. "Can you conjure up a torch or something for me?" Severus complied by tracing a long shape in the air. A moment later a heavy iron torch, like the ones that could be found in the older parts of Hogwarts, hung in the air. Lourdes reached out to catch it and raised an eyebrow at him. "This wasn't quite what I meant but…well never mind." Taking a deep breath to steel herself, Lourdes started creeping down the half rotted wooden stairs. The dark air seemed too dense to be just a fog, and the torch acted like an umbrella in a rain storm, creating a lone patch of light in the thick darkness.

Vanitas Vanitatum (II)


Pushing those memories and feelings aside, Severus nodded firmly, retreating to his seat at the tea table as Lourdes stepped into the overlap between the two circles and began moving her mouth. He only heard the sound briefly, the low droning grind of a chant vanished into eerie silence when the chalk lines on the floor began to glow pale, icy green. Severus fired off a shade charm for the windows as quickly as he could to keep the light in, and sealed off the cracks at the top and bottom of the door for safety’s sake.

She made a triangle out of her index fingers and thumbs, using it like a target sight to zero in on the circles and lines she'd drawn earlier, which now blazed sharp white against the glow of the mirror glass. The mirror's surface began to bubble and warp alarmingly as a misty sort of light seeped out and congealed into a little shape between her fingers.

A butterfly or possibly a moth, made of silvery light, beat its wings wildly in place, trapped in the section of the ward she'd designated for it. When she’d coaxed the first six out of the mirror, the very last one to emerge looked tatty and rather black in spots. Mouth still moving at a rapid pace, Lourdes reached out and trapped them in her fist one by one. Clutching the light close to her heart, rocking back and forth, she unfolded her hands and let it spiral off into the air where it vanished with a pop.

The only one left was the little blighted one that belonged to Quirrell; Lourdes had to spend three times as long on him. It hovered in the air between her hands, breaking apart and re-congealing, until something went awry. The darker parts that she’d been trying to sift out began to swirl around on their own. They took on a serpentine form, and darting around her head as Lourdes’ eyes widened with shock.

For just a moment, Severus panicked too; the situation looked astoundingly familiar. The last time she’d looked like that, she’d left the Hog’s Head on a stretcher, bleeding heavily from her chest. Severus leapt to his feet, but ran face first into the barrier formed by her magic.

Lourdes was trapped inside the boundaries, groping on her lap for the chalk, she bared her teeth at the thing and snarled something at it.  Pushing it back with the force of her magic emanating darkly from her hand, Lourdes scrawled a new design on the floor. Biting down violently on her lip, she swiped the resulting blood into a cross-in-circle pattern in the center of the new ward. The black thing was fighting her, blooming apart and trying to wind around her neck, or slither in through her mouth, its ghost tongue flicking at her ears as if it wanted to entice her. Her face contorted into a snarl, she inhaled and the thing was pulled toward her, snared between her hands where her magic was arrayed in shadowy lines as though she were playing cats cradle.

 

Forcing it into the boundary of the thing she’d drawn on the floor, Lourdes rose, and stomped three times, shoving a bronze mirror snatched from her ornament belt at the little black thing. As soon as it was confronted with its reflection, it began to loose its shape, twisting in the air before it folded into itself and vanished. In an instant the chalk circles stopped glowing and the room was pitch-black again.  Quirrell’s soul had escaped, fluttering wildly around the darkened room towards the bluebell flame on the table - the lone source of light now, before Severus heard the click of a ghau opening Quirrell was sucked away in a bright streak.

Severus counter charmed the windows to let moonlight spill across the floor, and saw that Lourdes had been blown clear across the room into the loom. Slightly cross-eyed and covered in sweat, she was clutching the mirror as if her life depended on it.

“What was that?” Severus asked numbly, though he could feel some of the blood returning to his face as he stared at her.

“Why didn’t you tell me he stole life from a Unicorn?” Lourdes sputtered as she mopped the sweat off her forehead.

“Pardon me, Ms Mezarci, you are the Evocator, not me. I had no idea such information was relevant,” he hissed, straightening up. Severus felt relief that she wasn’t dead wash over him first, followed quickly by anger that she would make such presumptions.

“Dorje, that knocked me proper," she muttered, patting the back of her head as if to check for cracks. "I’ve never seen anything like that, I should have put two and two together…the Dark Lord possessed this Quirrell, right?”

“I would have assumed you knew that the presence of two souls attempting to live off one life shortens the original occupant’s life span. We lost four unicorns that year. Did you have the opportunity to figure out what was attacking you?” Severus slid back into his chair and snatched up the quill, poised to take notes again.

“I was a bit busy in case you didn’t notice,” Lourdes muttered. “And that was…someone attacking me, not something.  Could you conjure me a bucket of water and a rag please? And if you could move this thing back against the wall.”

As soon as the mirror was cleared, Lourdes scrubbed at the chalk and blood until there was no evidence save for the drying water stain on the smooth stone. She stood up, dusting off her skirts before she seated herself across the table and laid her head down on her arms.

“Do you need something to drink?” he muttered, looking out the window. The moon had traveled quite a distance across the sky since they’d arrived in the room; it must be very late now. She nodded weakly in reply. With a flick of his wrist Severus managed to scrounge up a pot of jasmine infused tea and some of the leftover miniature fruit tarts from that evening’s supper.

“Why did you choose butterflies?” he asked coolly, popping a tart topped with a few blueberries into his mouth.

“They’re moths, you can tell by the thick bodies. I remember them because they always flock to light. When we stayed in the forest in Bulgaria, Everdika would hurry in to collect them after I finished a spell. I thought they were interesting.” Lourdes smiled softly as she selected a strawberry tart.

"You knew Everdika?" Snape asked cautiously.

"I did. She's the one who taught me to spoil and read aether when I was in school. I went to see her during the summers for a month or two before Mama and Papa would take me back home, and I saw her a lot when I was working in Turkey.  I was sorry to hear she decided to die, but it would have been her choice." Lourdes nodded. “This tea is really good by the way…smells like flowers.”

“Jasmine tea, the house-elves don’t usually make it,” he grunted. Picking up his quill again, Severus ran over the information he’d got down on parchment. “I must admit, Ms Mezarci, I was quite sure you were going to receive another gaping chest wound for a few moments there.  What did you say to it?”

 

“I told it that it had no idea what it was dealing with…”  Lourdes said ominously.

 

“Mind telling me the difference between this and what you did to me…?” He raised an eyebrow at her sharply, she had some of his life and he had no intention on letting her get away with it.

“Umm, well, best to begin at the beginning on that one," she said thoughtfully. "There are two kinds of things capable of self generated action; beings and non-beings, as opposed to things that are simply matter like…rocks and planets and stars.  There are four markers of a sentient being, as opposed to non-being; life, the force that keeps the body and soul together, soul, the essence of the individual, and the corporeal vessel, a body.   The fourth factor is that beings have a collective conscientia, a reservoir of the experience, time, and history of a species that a spirit or entity has no access to unless it's bestowed through a being with a soul.  Non-beings are anomie - without law or soul, outside the realm of concientia which leaves them with little concept of things like time, natural law or empathy.  Like beings they still leave their mark on the aether – the very impressionable and changeable transmission medium, so to speak – the thing on which all activity, all magic, all thought is impressed.  Beings are far less fluid by nature than a nonbeing like a daemon or an elemental that only knows what it can gather from ever changing aether.

“However being is pretty perilous because beings are mutable in some forms, that is to say a being can die.  And when I say die, I mean that the soul has to separate from its other elements, and once it’s out of a body its of little use.  If you run out of life or snuff it out by destroying the body, you separate the soul and produce the state of common death, which so easy it can happen by accident. And what I took from you was life, but I didn’t need to damage your body to shake it loose.  Some types of life can be easily taken by anyone but the cost is high, take unicorn blood for instance. Hags retain and Vampires develop a primitive but potent ability to steal life via blood or flesh, but at the cost of - well you've met them. 

 

I can’t tell you why Evocator’s magic is the way it is, other than that it’s known to be very primitive and low frequency.  Basal you might say, and very specialized which is limiting, but also affords some advantage.  Because we are the way we are, I can use the magic to touch and manipulate things on my frequency with relative ease, and one of those things is the soul-in-tact. We can use the magic to read patterns in the concientia and aether, to find and open a gateway to banish souls to, for lack of a better word, a crossroad.  That’s the way these souls would have gone if they’d had a common death with no complications like that mirror, and chosen to move forward. 

 

“What about the mirror is a complication?” Severus asked, genuinely curious about this aspect.  Obviously Erised was a powerful object created with very old magic, unlikely to be recreated now.  But Severus could not imagine why it held sway over souls…

 

“The mirrors is very old, older than the frame.  It’s not actually a silvered glass, it’s backed by physically manifested magic, the only thing like it I’ve ever seen…and I’ve seen a lot of antiques,” Lourdes said breathlessly, casting an admiring glance at the mirror.  “Incredible magic to perform, and that instant must have been when the magic was trapped in the glass.   I think it must have been done in Venice because it’s so flawless.    The way it’s been enchanted actually forms a little pocket in the aether the mirror is made of and occupies, so the mirror can exist as stably as we see it now – un-temperamental and unfailing.  But that little pocket can trap things. The mirror’s magic is designed to read the soul and concientia of an individual and construct a scenario that reflects what it sees, and that has a greater pull on a soul enraptured by it than a natural gateway.  I don’t think many things like this could exist, and not nearly as perfectly as this one. 

 

“Now, as for you, I ah…have about two weeks that belong to you. Do you want them back?” she asked softly.

“Yes.” Severus sneered at her and shook his head. What a stupid question, who wouldn’t want it back? Lourdes scooted her chair around the table so she was almost knee to knee with him, and motioned him forward with a flick of her finger.

“Open your mouth a little,” she instructed. “As soon as you feel it, take a deep breath…” Severus watched her close her eyes as she muttered under her breath again. Then there was the soft sound of her exhaling, and her breath clouded in the air as it would on a cold day. Filling his lungs fit to burst, he watched the little cloud being pulled into his body and felt a sensation of tingling warmth spread through his chest, all the way up to the roots of his hair and the soles of his feet.

As she hung suspended in concentration, Severus had a split second to examine her mouth, hovering about an inch away from making contact with his. It was an inviting, plump shape despite the ragged state of her lower lip and he was unsure if it was the distance or the renewed jolt of life in his body that made him wonder dizzily what might happen if he leaned forward just enough to touch her mouth with his. Would the lips pull back to reveal destructive teeth, or would the contact would be as soft and light as the brushing of moth wings…

Severus did not find out; when their eyes met, a flash of virulent green replacing the mental image of softness and warm breath, they both withdrew quickly. Something about that strange tension opened up an old wound inside of him, leaving him almost hungry- if that was even the word for it. The tarts did nothing for it, but he managed to grind the feeling down to a dull ache as they ate in silence for a few moments.

“Will you at least tell me how many people you think you killed?” she asked, tilting her head and resting it against her fist. “I gave you that courtesy.”

“No one, directly.” He had to pause for a moment and forced down a mouthful of tea. There was the familiar heavy feeling of sick guilt and weakness weighing on his whole body, almost choking him at the throat.

Drawing another deep breath, he forced himself to continue “I continued my attempts to modify and experiment with hexes and curses, the way I did in school. But I never stood before someone to snuff their life out. The Dark Lord does not hesitate to capitalize on the different personalities of his Death Eaters. As long as we felt we were in control of how we were being used, he was perfectly happy to let us go on believing it.” Severus looked up at Lourdes who seemed to be processing all of this very carefully.

“Let me see,” she said, leaning in and peering into his eyes. He saw that hungry spark in her face again, but it was different from the predator he’d seen a few days ago. No, this was more like the look she’d had the first time she managed to break through into his memories. I want to know everything, I want to see where you came from, she had insisted.

Severus found himself tensing up involuntarily, his eyes closing to block her out. There were so many things no one else should ever see or know about, lingering in the back of his mind, recalled more often in these past five years than before.

“I do not think you need to know any more,” he hissed, tilting his chin towards his chest so his hair swung forward to hide his face.

“You know, that’s the danger in telling people you went to university to study psychology. They clam up because they always think you’re psychoanalyzing them. I promise I won’t ask you anything about your mother,” Lourdes said wryly. Severus looked up for just a fraction of a second and raised an eyebrow inquisitively.

 

“Sorry, Freud humor.” Lourdes smirked awkwardly and extended a hand towards his. She touched his fingers tentatively a few times before letting it settle into place. Severus threw up the hardest, most unconcerned façade he could muster while he tried to figure out what this meant. He was not often touched, as if people were afraid that his skin was poisonous, so he’d come to regard any contact with a great deal of suspicion.

Strangely enough, though, he wasn’t eager to pull away. Severus felt his stomach squirm uncomfortably and he looked off to one side, feigning disinterest.

“It has been a long time, Ms Mezarci. I hardly remember anything.”

“I’ve got a Dark Mark too, you know,” Lourdes said pointedly.

“Do not imagine that yours and mine are the same,” Severus said, narrowing his eyes and curling his lip up. There was a sour tension taking over in the back of his throat, the same feeling he got when Black interrupted him at meetings to throw out some ridiculously uninformed proposition.

“Enlighten me,” Lourdes said, fingers sliding away as she leaned back in her chair and cradled her teacup between her hands, raising an eyebrow inquisitively.

“You are as presumptuous as Black,” he growled, watching as Lourdes frowned at the comparison. “With the benefit of an introduction, and years of information and research, you knew beforehand what you were getting yourself into, Ms Mezarci. I had no real idea of the breadth and depth of the organization I was aligning myself with.”

“Didn’t you?” Lourdes pursed her lips, the image of this stuck and batted about Severus' brain a little longer than was natural.

Severus snapped his eyes closed again and breathed, trying to clear everything that wasn't necessary out of his muddled brain. “The Dark Lord could afford to take his time then, not just anyone could receive the mark. If you were a person of interest you were approached by a Death Eater who had the most likely connection to you. In my case it was Lucius Malfoy because of our early associations at Hogwarts. There were different methods, of course, for each individual. You did not refuse an invitation without consequence, and I had no desire to die.”
