Lourdes shifted languidly in her chair before she took another long drink from her teacup. “And you were interested…”

“I was much less discreet about my ambitions then, and about my interest in the darker arts. That was the approach they used: the promise of unbridled study, again. The Dark Lord, I was told, was generously willing to overlook my blood status. I was able to parade my various school successes before Malfoy, the jinxes I had invented and my potions book corrections. I thought surely that I was a natural, too clever for them not to take. There was the prospect of belonging, Ms Mezarci, which I doubt you have ever had to ponder.”

Severus felt another deep stab of self loathing, and fought the urge to glare at her with the hatred and envy bubbling up inside. He’d been deeply jealous from the first moment he saw the other memories of her as a tall, skinny child, laughing and grinning with her pet camel and all her adoring aunties and uncles.

Lourdes winced when he said it, as if he’d just torn off a bandage to display a gruesome wound. “Schoolboys whose only accomplishments are petty cruelties have no idea what lies in store for them when they enter into the Dark Lord’s service. I completed my inaugural tasks, which amounted to secretive errand running, and faced the Dark Lord to receive my precious mark. I belonged, though I quickly discovered the Death Eaters had only social connections and competition. It was a much faster game than I was accustomed to playing. I imagined, though, that I could be the worst out of all of them and therefore the best. Once I had been marked, I agreed to anything to grasp at that power.”

“I know the feeling,” Lourdes said softly.

“Magic, we were told, was for the calculating, thinking mind that would probe its darkest depths, stretch, and transform it. I agreed, of course; however, it seemed the Dark Lord and I differed on the subject of usefulness. But when he was strong, when you heard the Dark Lord speak to you personally, praise you, elevate you for those few brief moments in front of everyone else, it seemed like bliss at first.

“The lights go out very quickly, Ms Mezarci, when you start to live every day in constant fear of a misplaced whisper or the slightest mistake. When your work and what you consider brilliance and innovation is brushed aside for base petty cruelty and artless murder. It is hard for me to say for certain when I began to realize I made a mistake, but there was no blow more devastating than the one I received when I realized that my life was not what I thought it would be. None of the things I had anticipated as pleasing or rewarding were enjoyable; I was but a servant to the whims of everyone that ranked higher than myself. I was losing, Ms Mezarci, and I did not want to lose.”

Severus chose his words extremely carefully; he was trying to weave them around the subject he never spoke of. ..

“Which of us is happy in this world? Which of us has his desire or, having it, is satisfied? Thackeray, you know.” Lourdes nodded wisely. “Learned that the hard way.”

Severus jerked back, a bit shocked and raised an eyebrow. “Did Albus tell you that?”

“In my first letter from him coming out of prison, along with a long lecture on the perils of ambition without conscience,” she sighed. “Of course he had no clue what he was talking about.”

“That…was what he told me a long time ago.” Severus almost laughed. The thought of Albus recycling the same speech made him wonder if all wayward Slytherins heard it. “When all the lights go out, you find yourself running scared towards the only one left on, don’t you? Like those moths you are so fond of.”

“Nobody left any on for me, I’m afraid.”

“There was one on for me here, as you know. It was not easy; I had to go to Albus. He was the only person who could ever realistically assist someone in leaving the Dark Lord. Albus is neither complacent, nor stupid. Over time, I was forced to confront the hypocrisy, the illogical nature of the arguments and ideals I followed in the most visceral ways Albus could dream up. It would be a great blow to the pride of anyone, I think, to discover the few things I actually valued- knowledge, ingenuity, and work as an extension of my ambition- meant nothing.” Severus finished, and silence hung between them as Lourdes gnawed on her lip thoughtfully.

For just a moment he felt strangely light, and indulged himself by closing his eyes to savor it. When he heard her voice he came right back down to earth.

“When I was working, it was very easy to justify killing. I told myself that I was an enforcer of the law. They broke it, they deserved to die. I imagine it must have been easy for you then, to justify joining them.”

Severus only grunted a bit in response. It had been incredibly easy to rationalize it then, but it was almost impossible to do it now. What was done, was done, he determined. It couldn’t be taken back; the only thing he could do was attempt to work against it, and hope that would be enough for the rest of the world.

“It was strange for me, when they took me to prison and branded me, because I know those people didn’t see me as human. I asked myself if I could forgive those people, and I still don’t know if I can honestly say yes. Then I had to think, in all that time when I was chained up, if the people who cared about the ones I killed could forgive me. Even if their loved ones did despicable, vicious, horrible things, they might still love them despite all of it, so then what right did I have to take their lives? I had to wonder if repenting and feeling sorry about it meant that I had to wash away everything I did during my career, even the good and helpful parts. It baffles me,” she was chewing on her lip again, squinting into her tea dregs as if they could give her the answer.

Severus was, for a moment, speechless. One particular part of what she’d said - even if their loved ones did despicable, vicious, horrible things, they might still love them despite all of it - cut straight through him.  And it hurt so much that he had to wonder if she planned it – if she knew about Lily. Right now he didn’t have enough patience to worry about what she meant; it was uncomfortable. “Forgive me for being direct, Ms Mezarci, but what exactly is it that you are trying to say?”

“What I am trying to say, Mister Snape, is that I am in no position to judge you. I am saying that as far as I can tell we will never really be able to know for sure if we can be forgiven, or redeemed; we can only say what we believe. Who decides if your spying makes up for what you did with the Death Eaters, or if my time in jail and all this now makes up for mine? I don’t know, I can’t say. I am saying I’m sorry, for going after you like I did,” Lourdes said primly. “That’s all.”

“I broke a promise to you, do you remember?” Severus asked suddenly.

“I do.”

“I am…sorry,” he said haltingly, taking another deep breath to force the next bit out all in one go. “It will not happen again.”

“Thank you, it means a lot to me.”

“I know.” She gave him a small, tired smile as she picked up her teacup and they finished eating in silence.

Severus felt as though something had lifted suddenly, perhaps it was because that persistent feeling of apprehension and stomach churning anxiety had finally lifted. All was forgiven…

With Lourdes, at least.

-***-

In a fit of what passed for whimsy with Severus, she was transfigured into a fat little moth instead of undergoing disillusionment, allowing her to hide on his neck under his hair, it was a bizarre experience. She’d never been an insect before.

When her body resumed a human shape again, she was not inside the Head of House’s quarters, but in some sort of private staging area with cool tiled walls and a fancy iron gate at the other end.

“Albus thinks you would benefit from exercise.”

“Are you saying I’m fat?” she teased, raising an eyebrow and crossing her arms across her chest.

“You were the one who complained about putting on weight, were you not?”

“Frankly, I don’t know how you don’t weigh a thousand pounds with the sort of food they feed you here.” Severus started down the tiled hallway and tapped his wand on the gate’s lock, leading Lourdes into a room she had no idea Hogwarts housed - a swimming pool, of all things, illuminated by the phosphorescent lights under the water. They cast an eerie blue-green light up onto the walls and the high ceilings supported by large filigree iron arches. Every surface seemed to be covered in shimmery gray-glazed tiles, with the pool lanes marked in deep green. The air smelled strongly antiseptic, making the whole room feel a bit more clinical than it ought to.

“Who put this in?” Lourdes gasped, tip-toeing to the edge of the pool where Severus was dipping a sample cup into the water, testing to see if the balance of purification potions was correct.

“I am told Phineas Nigellus Black had this installed when he became Headmaster; apparently there was a bit of an uproar about the cost of it, and the integrity of the building. They built it back when ‘regular bathing’ was being touted as a means to improve health and magical vitality. It’s been entrusted to me though, as Head of Phineas’ former house. No well bred Slytherin would deign to use the lake.” Severus dipped a little strip of treated parchment into the sample cup and deemed the blue color it turned acceptable.

“I see the position has its benefits. So this is how you keep from turning into a great big pudding. Makes you wonder if Slughorn knew about it,” Lourdes snorted.

The pool turned out to be their release valve; it kept the air clear between them. It was understood now that the need-to-knows were out of the way, and their behavior now was never anything less than proper and befitting. Three times a week without fail, at eleven in the evening, they went to swim. They began at opposite ends, Lourdes in her sensible black suit, Severus in trunks he must have had since his twenties and absurdly enough, a bathing cap. Lourdes wasn’t sure if he was trying to protect his hair from the pool…or vice versa.

Severus swam as if he were clockwork, each stroke perfectly and efficiently timed with the rest of his body, every motion crisp and perfect. Lourdes went at a languid pace between hard laps, lazily and twirling under water like a child before popping up for a quick breath. She wanted to stay under the surface and enjoy the beautiful, weightless feeling.

It was almost purifying to reduce everything in the world down to water and a moving body. There was no Dark Lord, no Order under the surface. Those thoughts, those entities could not penetrate the little world of the pool the way her body could the moment she broke the surface and felt the coolness of water envelop her skin. While the Order and the Dark Lord waited on the edge of the pool, there was still the matter of the other body in the water with her.

Things were amiable now they had settled in to being efficient room mates on their own mundane schedules. Lourdes had nearly put the house-elves out of business in her efforts to keep busy during the day, cleaning and scrubbing potions equipment, flicking flies into the spider webs, attacking mounting piles of paper work for other Order members. Severus would occasionally portion off first and second year essays for her to grade if she fidgeted or complained about boredom.

They listened to the call-in shows about political policy on the WWN, or hours of Liszt, Mahler, and Gesualdo lightened every once in awhile by an hour of Argentine tango. How odd, Lourdes thought as she bobbed up and down, treading water in the deep end; the nature of her situation and how much he had changed since school hit her with the force of a tidal wave.


Eighteen years would change the nature of anything wouldn’t it? There was a sense of separation between the two of them that was far wider than the tea table. In school they had been close in their way; secretly, of course.  Neither of them would have publicly admitted that they were so inelegant as to be close to someone, or that their ideas and improvements came from collusion. After all in one way or another they both longed to be seen as solitary geniuses.

It was the side effect of all the mental invasions, glimpsed memories, and shared knowledge. But it was a sort of comrade closeness that never strayed into the realm of cozy friendship, and he never looked at her with the same greedy intensity that he aimed at Evans. The one thing she appreciated above all else was that Severus only saw her as Mezarci – aloof and smug at times, clever, weird, determined, exasperating on occasion, and often downright infuriating.  But even during their worst rows she was never simply “the Evocator.” 
 

All that had changed apparently.  

 

Lourdes knew where he stood now, when he was younger he was ambitious little star in the pressure cooker with all the other children at Hogwarts.  Time, and his own gravity had exiled him to an empty quarter where he moldered half-dead like a pulsar star on the edge of a very vast galaxy.  She knew how deep the roots of that went, she’d seen him suffer a terminal change when he was in school, the aftershock of which caused ripples of change in her as well.  It removed the last cautious barrier between Lourdes, Severus, and a great deal of undiscovered emotional and magical territory. 


Things came to a head at the end of fifth year he turned - he’d fallen out with Lily Evans and they’d doubled their study sessions now that he wasn’t trying to keep company with three separate parties. His inhibitions seemed to lower almost instantly and his sense of competition and interest in things that he’d been wary of before was much, much higher.  Lourdes encouraged these new ventures because of the benefits she reaped,  But and sat across from him in the broom cupboards and abandoned classrooms after the Mudblood incident  he began to reveal a streak of intense, obsessive mania.

Lily was unreasonable, Severus would rave, even months and months after it had happened, it was just a word! He’d been called way worse by Potter and she never said anything to him. They’d been friends for ages, if it weren’t for Severus she wouldn’t have known anything when she came to Hogwarts!


And if it wasn’t for me, Lourdes had though traitorously, you’d have been dangling pants-less in front of the whole of fifth year!

Lily obviously fancied James Potter, Severus would hiss later, despite Lily’s constant objections that Potter was a bullying toe rag. And Potter obviously fancied her and that was unfair, stupid, how could she be so blind when Severus had warned her over and over.  Never once did Lourdes risk a hexing by pointing out that Evans likely fancied James Potter because washed his hair regularly, and likely wore shorts instead of grungy y-fronts.  And that next to Avery, Mulciber, and Lestrange, Black, Lupin, and Pettigrew looked like choirboy companions.

 

Of course Lourdes half hoped that if Severus didn’t change he’d have to like her instead…


She developed a deep sense of self loathing for wanting to be with Severus, those feelings were out of her control - alien, disgusting, and frightening.  A large part of her early life was spent trying to cure herself of the persistent lovesickness.  To spite him during school, she went out with Bertram Aubrey, the other Slytherin Prefect in their year, but not much came of that.  She liked Bertram, felt a mild fondness for him and the novelty of desire had been enjoyable, but was still plagued by the disease.   Whatever the ailment was, it seemed to have gone into remission when she began to dominate at O.H.K.  Success seemed to be the cure for lovesickness.  She thought once or twice in recent months she had thought she felt symptoms that filled her stomach with butterflies and made her clumsy and thick, but they appeared to be false alarms.

Annoying as it was to admit, Lourdes saw now that the attack had spun her even further out of orbit with him. Before she might have had better access, she might have easily extracted the whole truth if she had been patient.  Instead his confession was a performance, eloquently delivered. There was still the curiously unresolved factor of Lily Evans, and Lourdes could not quite see where that fit, she didn’t know enough. And she could not quite get over the feeling that she’d been beaten at her own game.

 

There were times when she stopped swimming and tread water to watch Severus, looking across the width of the pool to wonder how a gap like that could be bridged. She felt a strange little ache almost like loss somewhere between her stomach and her heart, an un-named want… Then she went back under water where it couldn’t follow.

Vanitas Vanitatum


“Ah! Vanitas Vanitatum! which of us is happy in this world? Which of us has his desire? or, having it, is satisfied?" W.M. Thackeray, Vanity Fair

 

Albus was just about to add the chocolate to the warm mixture of cream, vanilla, and cinnamon when there was a knock on his office door.

“Enter,” he said pleasantly, dropping a considerable quantity of Honeyduke’s Ykchaua Special Chocolate into the cauldron.

“Sir, a word with you please?” It was Severus, which was rather fortunate actually. Albus needed to have a word with him about those smashed up desks in the spare classroom.

“Excellent timing Severus, I’m just about to finish some hot chocolate. May I offer you some? It’s a new recipe Aberforth passed along to me, though I daresay I’ve had to make some minor modifications to the ingredients. I find too much essence of chili keeps me up all evening.” Giving the thick creamy mixture a good stir, Albus looked over his shoulder at Severus.

“Yes, thank you,” he replied, still standing at full attention in front of the large desk.

“Ah! Where are my manners, please have a seat. We’ll be drinking chocolate shortly, but in the meantime let me take just a moment to ask you to please refrain from destroying any more desks. Argus nearly had kittens when he found your wreckage. If you are looking for something in the way of stress relief, and I understand we need this now more than ever, might I suggest taking up a hobby?” Severus did not reply or make a sound; he must have come to discuss something a bit more serious than students or requests for further security for his office.

Carefully ladling a bit of hot chili infusion into the bottoms of two mugs, Albus added honey and the warm chocolate mixture from the cauldron. Two wand taps later he presented a mug of perfectly frothy chocolate to the morose looking man.

“Cortez the explorer once reported to his king that chocolate was the divine drink. I quite agree. Now, Severus, tell me what’s on your mind.”

Severus stared down intently at the chocolate as he began to speak. “Sir, I’m afraid that Ms Mezarci and I have had a… disagreement.”

Albus’ gaze quickly turned penetrating and Severus seemed to feel it, and winced as if burned.

“Severus, you are aware of course that having a disagreement of a serious nature with Lourdes would be most inadvisable? And that your personal safety might very well depend on a small reformation of your interpersonal skills? This is not an issue we can afford to take lightly. If you present Voldemort with even the smallest opportunity to split Lourdes off, he will take it,” Albus said, a little more sharply than he’d intended.

“I intend to correct this. It’s making amends that’s become a problem, sir.” Severus began recounting the events of the past few days from the details of her disconcerting interrogation to the very panicked incident in which he pulled a wand on her in a frenzy, and Lourdes evidently stole a little life from him. Right now, he reported, Lourdes was asleep, and she’d been that way for about two days.

“I daresay civilized confrontation, or for that matter conversation, may be a bit of a problem for Lourdes,” Albus said thoughtfully. “She seems to be well learned in the theories of social interaction but with little interest in applying them outside of her discipline. Once the two of you have found a way to mesh your respective experience, I think you will be just fine.”

“You’ll pardon me for saying so sir, but just fine is hardly safe.” Severus looked as though he was struggling to remain composed, and there was a familiar angry edge in his voice. He was always extraordinarily irritable if he thought he was not being trusted.

“Severus,” Albus said forcefully, compelling the younger man to look at him. “I have not placed her next to you because I find you wanting in skill or honesty. But all our lives are in grave danger, and there is the very real possibility that I may not last through this war.” Severus looked very briefly shocked by that revelation and nodded solemnly.

“Sun Tzu, who has written a treatise on war I find most enlightening, informs us that one can never have too many spies. I took pains to select a second spy I knew you got along with well enough to learn a difficult, restricted magical art on your own. Trust me when I say I needn’t have gone out of my way to fetch Lourdes; there were many eager volunteers to assist here already. Andromeda Tonks offered to leave her husband and family and insert herself alongside her sisters, and her daughter Nymphadora has offered to leave her job and assume any disguise. Remus Lupin has offered to align himself with the creature that bit him.”

Try as he might to control it, Albus could feel some of the strain and some of his frustration leaking into his speech. Frustration over innocent Podmore in Azkaban because of his orders, Fudge’s willfull ignorance, Broderick Bode in the Permanent Spell Damage Ward, and Dolores Umbridge upending the normally smooth running of the school. The frustration ate at him while he ought to be sleeping, and the anger at himself lapped hot up the back of his throat whenever he read the paper or looked at Dolores down the Staff Table. It made negotiating peace talks between two fully grown, competent adults absolutely unacceptable.

“That night I asked you to return, you could have said no and I would have understood. It is because I respect you that I am trying to arm you in any way I can. Severus, I know you are not accustomed to depending on, or working with other people. But occasionally it is necessary. Though, from what you’ve told me thus far, it seems the two of you have done an excellent job, and Voldemort suspects nothing.”

He watched Severus twitch and fidget for a moment, every few seconds he would shift his weight from one side to the other. “Have you told her anything about what I did?” Severus blurted, his long hand shooting up to span his forehead like a vice as he massaged his temples.

“In the interest of fairness, Severus, I gave her the same advice my brother gave you- that she ought to go straight to the source,” Albus said, feeling a bit calmer after a few sips of chocolate.

Severus looked concerned and vaguely calculating as he digested that. “I don’t know… how she worked it out.”

“You understand that logical analysis of human behavior used to be her livelihood? I daresay she neglected every other aspect of her life to excel in that area, so I do hope she’s quite good at what she does,” he said frankly. There was no need to mince words with Severus on that subject; it seemed he’d received the worst of what she could dish out.

“Sir, I called her a lich, among other things” Severus admitted, as contrarily as if he were being forced to confess to hexing a classmate in the hall.

Albus took a deep drink of hot chocolate to hide his frown. If there wasn’t so much riding on the two of them being civil to one another, it might have been amusing (in a grim sort of way) to see Severus subjected to the same unapologetic nastiness that he inflicted on students. While Albus had no desire to treat either of them like students, but they were acting less like adults and more like spoiled teenagers. That was something he hadn't anticipated.

“Severus, I am more than willing to acknowledge that there are some wounds too old and too deep to heal completely. But, do you recall another instance in which your use of a word caused you, and another you cared for great pain?” Albus paused, and watched Severus for a moment. For scarcely a second an expression of white hot rage flashed over Severus’ features. Not an unusual response when this topic was broached.

“She wouldn’t listen to reason,” Severus hissed, twitching in his seat uneasily. “It was only a word…”

“To you, perhaps. You knew the damage it would do when you used it, I daresay you intended to hurt her as badly as you were.” Albus breathed deeply, preparing to remain calm no matter what would happen next....

“She wouldn’t let me make it RIGHT,” Severus spat as he dug both of his hands into his scalp.

There was a moment of stillness, suddenly, and Severus sat almost paralyzed by his own anger, only his chest moved irregularly as he struggled to breathe. That anger and desperate expectation had been accumulating in him for so long, like thick black bile. Albus watched it in his progress over the years, slowly poisoning Severus, turning him bitter. He must have been starving in a way, but would not eat for anything. And he knew that feeling, what it was like to turn away from things for lack of trust in yourself, to avoid pleasures as private penance.

Severus bore the wounds, as Albus did, of someone who had seized his gift by the blade in the heat of impatience and ambition, and still felt the pain. The weight of the death of someone dear carried like a millstone you could not drop for fear of forgetting. But at least Severus knew who had truly struck the blow that took Lily’s life even if he could not let go of the feeling of failure to protect someone important to him…

But this was the wrong time for these notions.

Albus shook his head firmly to clear away the mingled, muddled thoughts and associations before he could focus on Severus, who was paler than usual and staring into his mug.

"I find myself at a loss for how to proceed," Severus admitted at last, voice painfully quiet.

“While I understand this is not exactly the easiest situation for the two of you to resolve, I cannot continue to play moderator. I will assist you this time, but after this you’re on your own,” Albus said firmly.

Severus nodded and took another deep drink of his chocolate. “I understand sir.”

“I know,” Albus said quietly.

Picking up a crisp square of parchment and his quill, Albus began jotting down a little note to Lourdes. “You know, Severus, I think there is a task the two of you would be well suited for that does not involve Voldemort. Think of it as a training ground. The Mirror of Erised could use some cleaning, and I would certainly like to know as much about those that died in front of it as possible. Has Lourdes mentioned her request to be allowed out of the castle for research during the break?”

“No, she hasn’t.”

“If you’ll kindly consent to escorting her it would be much appreciated, as you’re capable of producing a Patronus. I’m afraid she’s going out to do a bit of field research for the Dementor project I asked her to put together. She has some theories she’d like to test, and word from Remus is that there are a few stray Dementors taking up residence in an Irish castle. They may be starting a breeding cycle there.” Albus folded the little note one last time before handing it over.

“Of course, sir,” Severus muttered. Rising from his chair with a determined look on his face, he pocketed the note and turned crisply on his heel before gliding to the door.

“One last thing, Severus,” Albus said firmly. The younger man paused, hand on the door ready to open it, but he did not turn around.

“I am once again compelled to remind you that your words are the most powerful magic you possess. Please be more mindful in your use of them…”

-***-

Severus contemplated the little curled up form of Lourdes for a moment as she drooled a little on her pillow. It was almost a shame to wake her. Almost. Wrenching her jaw open, he let three drops of Wiggenweld trickle down her throat. Within seconds Lourdes was bolt upright in the bed sputtering and blinking rapidly.

“Whathell!” she muttered thickly before she noticed the little folded up parchment he’d thrust in her face. Lourdes had to read the note several times, because she was yawning and blinking constantly for a few moments. Looking up suspiciously, she simply nodded to signify her consent.

“Do you need anything unusual for this process?” Severus asked in his coolest, most academic tone.

“Chalk,” Lourdes replied shortly, heaving herself off the squashed feather mattress. Her movements were stiff and sluggish at first, as she rummaged in her trunk scrutinizing little strings of ornaments and embroidered belts before selecting a few and slinging them around her hips. Doing her best to smooth out her ruffled hair, she held out an expectant hand to receive a fresh stick of chalk and a firm wand tap to the head for Disillusionment.

Their destination was in a remote room on ground floor of the North Wing. Severus ran a hand over the battered surface of the door which had no handle, and whispered the password (desire) into the keyhole. The door swung open to admit them to a long room with an entire wall of gothic windows whose iron grilles still sported remnants of gold leaf. The other walls retained faded remnants of a mural, but the smooth plastered surface had been chipped away in places to reveal the stone walls.

Albus had told him this room was designed by Helga Hufflepuff as a solar, and Severus could hardly imagine how beautiful it would be in here during daylight hours with sunlight spilling over the smooth floor. The furnishings here were sparse: a few brocade chairs were clustered in a corner around a rickety table, and a large ancient loom had been pushed back against a wall. The mirror in question stood against the far wall - its gold frame glittering innocently wherever the light struck it.

Lourdes wasn’t paying attention to the mirror, or anything else; she was staring out the window, apparently transfixed by the huge orange moon rising over the black mass of the forest.  After a few moments of taking in the view, Lourdes turned and marched straight up to the mirror, not bothering with Severus or any questions. She stood so close to the massive thing that her breath fogged the glass, before she closed her eyes, sank to the floor and pressed her cheek and ear to it.

“Seven people…” she murmured, fingers skipping over the heavy gold carvings on the mirrors frame.

Severus had settled into one of the chairs and laid a roll of parchment, quill and ink out, conjuring a little blue flame to dance above the table top. “There is no record of the mirror’s true age, or its creator. Its function is to display the very deepest desire of the viewer’s heart. Albus would like to know as much as possible about the people trapped inside.”

“You know, superstition dictates that you’re supposed to cover all the mirrors in the house before someone dies or else they might get stuck," she said thoughtfully. "But I can’t imagine anyone thought about that when they were wasting away. The oldest person in here died in 1564, or so he says.”

She turned just a bit to flash him an imperious look that asked shouldn’t you be writing this down, apparently pleased to be an object of study instead of a figure of suspicion. Severus dashed that off, but he was more interested in watching her do the preliminary work for whatever ritual she had to conduct.

While not as useful or efficient as wand magic, potions, or even astrology he saw certain elegance in the old ritual magic. Especially old Dark magic, but he was not so sure which category this would fall into.

“Can you see anything in the mirror?” Severus asked casually. He wouldn't go near that thing for all the money in the world. He already knew what he wanted, and to stand in front of that vicious reflection and see it all play out with no hope of touching it would be far too painful.

“I’m sure I’ll be able to once these people have been extricated.  But that’s not really what I’m looking for. As it is, I only see fragments of their desires. Have you had a look, Mister Snape?” Her expression was keen and curious, but it seemed that in her eagerness to get on the task she’d forgotten the element of malice.

In fact, the whole situation reminded him very much of their stolen study sessions - the far away, secret location, the note, and the exciting prospect of seeing something bizarre and learning something new.

Severus decided not to waste this. “I haven’t had the opportunity to do so," he lied, hoping it would not be blatantly obvious. "This mirror was used as a guard a few years ago for the Philosophers Stone, but otherwise it has been locked up for the precise reason you are looking at it. We wouldn’t want anyone dropping dead in front of a mirror because they were too stupid to get up and move on with life,” he said harshly.

Ten minutes, maybe more, passed in absolute silence as Lourdes leaned against the glass, listening intently to voices he could not hear.

“In the interest of- ah- scholarly curiosity how long do you estimate this process taking, Ms Mezarci?” Severus muttered. There was, after all, a Ministry witch with a nasty grudge against half-breeds and freaks somewhere in the building. Hopefully Umbridge was locked in her office full of kitten patterned gimcracks, plotting Trelawney’s doom.

“Well they’re hardly eager to leave; I need to identify them all to a certain degree before I’ll know what sorts of wards to set. It could take a few hours in all honesty. If you’d like to put on some music, I understand,” she muttered, not bothering to look away from the mirror.

“That will not be necessary.” Severus was deeply curious as to what she was seeing in that mirror and bit back the urge to say anything. Either Lourdes could sense that, or she simply didn’t like the silence.

“The oldest one wanted a woman in the very worst way. The next is a warlord, blood thirsty for a great big Muggle genocide; he might be a bit harder to get out, goes on and on about opposing the oppression of Muggles so wizards may take their rightful place as rulers.”

Severus jotted all that down while she recited the victims with all the dispassionate flatness of a grocery list as Lourdes squinted and moved her finger down the mirror. She'd been tracing shadowy circles and interconnecting lines like a constellation map on the glass with the tip of her finger.

“And one last person, four years ago?” Lourdes looked at him incredulously.

“Ah, yes. I think I know who that is.” Severus sneered involuntarily at the thought of stuttering, skinny Quirrell with the Dark Lord hidden underneath that ridiculous turban…

“He’s an absolute mess, all sorts of malignant influence,” she muttered. "This could be a problem to repair..."

“Well being possessed by the Dark Lord for a year or two might do that to a person,” Severus muttered. “Have any of the others given you names?”


“The two holding out for their respective loves have forgotten their names. The demonologist is called Johannes Weyer, our warlord is Symeon of Durham, the playwright is named Robert Greene, and our actress is Anna Scott, and of course we have Quirinus Quirrell.” Lourdes said, scooting across the floor on her knees as she pulled the chalk out of her pocket.

Positioning herself in the center of the room, Lourdes began the first of two large overlapping circles, filling them with lotus petal shapes and triangles, writing out spells in a fluid language with the strange constellation shape she had traced on the mirror at the center She stood back to survey her work, scrutinizing each line and every strange word, making small corrections here and there until she deemed it acceptable.

“Could you please move that mirror into the center of this circle?” She indicated the side with the web drawn into it. Severus complied, being extra cautious because he had no idea what effect shattered glass might have on the mirrors inhabitants.

“What language is that?” he asked coolly, gesturing towards the swirling script that bordered the circles.

“Gongpe-ke, twilight language,” she replied, squinting as she leaned in to inspect a particular area.

“And those are mandalas?”

“Sort of,” Lourdes said, turning away from the chalk design with a final nod of approval. “Are you sure you want to sit through this?”

“How so?” Severus asked, curiosity piqued by that last statement.

“Most wizards don’t ever see one soul, let alone seven. These aren't shades or ghosts, it's a fair bit more intense than those weak and wasting scraps. I shouldn't think you'll be in danger, the boundaries are unbroken and this is solid spell work but..." she trailed off and bit her lip, both hands folding over the point on her chest where there had formerly been a sucking wound.

"I haven’t had someone sit in on me in ages."

Severus squirmed on the spot when she seemed to doggedly avoid looking at him. No, while this bore some resemblance to their study sessions it most definitely lacked the mutual air of arrogance and a desperate attempt to impress. Lourdes spoke about the ritual frankly, almost deliberately so, as if plain speech was a charm to ward off disaster. Pride goeth before a fall - that much both of them knew...

"This wasn't my idea," he offered. He wondered vaguely if she'd become afraid of herself, after the imprisonment and the disastrous summon.

"I know, and it shouldn't be dangerous for me, this is complex work but it's relatively benign. Though I'm not sure about Quirrell. He’s in terrible shape. I’ve never tried to remove large scale possession damage before, I know the theories and I've done a little work, but to be honest it just doesn't turn up very often. I don't know exactly what he's been possessed by, or if it's more than one influence, but it's not safe to release it without analysis. But just in case…” Lourdes sorted through the clattering amulets and innumerable pouches and strands of charm-pills and sticks wound with thread that hung off her belts and selected a small silver box with a large chunk of sickly blue turquoise set into the lid between the figures of dancing skeletons.

“I brought a ghau just in case. I can trap Quirrell in here for safe keeping if it doesn’t work out. I might have to do a little more research to send him off properly I can’t finish it here.” She snapped the ghau at him, opening and closing it like a set of jaws.

“Do you have any idea what sort of price you could get for that at Borgin and Burkes?” Severus stopped writing and stared intently at the little box, with a rather greedy glint in his eyes. Ghaus were considered Dark magical objects, certain types being incredibly handy for the keeping of many slippery, immaterial things. There were a number of rather sinister bits of magic you could do with one of those little boxes if you were so inclined, and foolhardy enough to attempt that sort of work as a wizard in this day and age. But they weren’t easy to come by, as they were only ever made in a scant few secretive beyuls in Tibet and the surrounding area and were tightly controlled family heirlooms.

”I might have a small fortune up in that box if I added up all the family ornaments, and this here.” She pulled up a sleeve to display what looked like an innocent leather bracelet set with an eye charm of blue glass. She gave the charm a tug, extracting a wire that glowed hot sinister blue. “This little beauty is a metal charmer’s garrote. I trained it to recognize my flesh, but it cuts through other people like a hot knife through butter; dead useful.” One more tug on the wire made it snap back into the leather band like an automatic tape measure.

“Do you own any female adornments that aren’t potential weapons?” he smirked, raising an eyebrow and folding his arms over his chest, crushing his sheet of parchment.

"Gods no, what good would that do?” It was when Lourdes laughed right then that Severus really recognized her. It was the smile, the laugh he only vaguely remembered from the better times.  He knew her- that was the girl he’d shared textbook revisions and revenge plots with, who concealed notes in cleverly titled library books for him to find, who cut through the Hog’s Head on a crowded evening to spend her breaks drinking tea and making plans and boasts. It hadn't all been misery, fights, and failure. For all their sparring, and screaming matches, there had been the triumphs, successes, and conspiratorial scraps of joy.

He watched her face iron itself out, the crinkles at the corners of her eyes and the creases in her cheeks vanishing in an instant. Just as quickly as she had appeared, the traces of the Lourdes he’d known retreated back behind that cracked façade. More important, though, was knowing that she was still in there somewhere…

Part Two

The Third Thing

 

“Beyond living and dreaming there is something more important: waking up.” ~ Antonio Machado

 

It had only taken a quick glance around the main room for Lourdes to figure out that she’d been stashed in Severus' quarters at Hogwarts. Though, she could have guessed by the decor alone. The low ceilings, stone walls, and flood-proof mosaic floors were just like the ones in the Slytherin dorms. Only here every inch of wall space and the windows were covered in dark bookshelves crammed with books, flasks of potions or constituents, and the occasional odd curio.

He had so many books, in fact, that there simply wasn't enough room for them on the shelves; a few heavy, metal-hinged tomes were propped up on stands and piles of smaller books sat in neat stacks on the floor next to boxes overflowing with un-filed notes. There was a secretary desk built in to the bookshelves but it was nigh on unusable at this point, its drawers and cubbies over flowed with spare sticks of sealing wax and rolls of letter-ribbon, parchment scraps and other resident junk.

Clearly Severus didn’t entertain guests here - there was no comfortable sitting area, or cozy sofas to lounge on, just a rickety tea table acting as a desk and two spindly chairs, one of which was occupied by a stack of books and papers. The dingy kitchen had nothing to eat, she'd checked. The cupboards were filled with books, cauldrons, and cooking implements in various stages of decay, while the windowsills and counters had been turned into a makeshift greenhouse where quite a number of exotic plants were attempting to grow in the weak watery light filtered through the lake. Several fat, shiny black spiders hung on to webs in the kitchen corners, apparently they were the closest thing Severus had to pets (if you squinted and looked at them sideways they were kind of cute actually…).

She didn’t even have her own space here. There was only one bedroom, furnished with a great-bed so old that Salazar himself might have slept in it and a rickety wardrobe containing thirty copies of the same black robes. Lourdes and her eight lock trunk had been relegated to a far corner by the bathroom where she slept on a little feather bed.

She had objected loudly to being shuffled from one basement to another. After all a person needed sunlight and fresh air… freedom (and the name of the neighborhood drug dealer). Apparently Albus didn’t see it that way, as he gently insisted that Severus should oversee her rehabilitation, and Severus was taking his job very seriously. The minute her trunk came through the door he riffled through every compartment and found all of her pipes, picked out her lamp, found every opium-laced cigarette, and all of the little white pills she carried when she knew it would be awhile until her next smoke. If she’d harbored any hope of being doted on during the detoxification process, it was shattered when he tossed a bottle of disinfectant at her and left her alone to bandage her bleeding knees.

The man had no bedside manner to speak of.

But the withdrawal itself was ten times worse than any lecture or silent treatment Severus could dream up. When she'd smoked there were no messy emotions to consider, she'd just gone off to some warm, safe little part of her mind where it was quiet. She didn’t think about the things which were off limits, which were disturbing. Even the daily grind was easier with the opium - she could work for hours on a book restoration or forgery without distraction, and smoking had made her imprisonment at Grimmauld place seemed bearable.

 

Withdraw ripped down all those cautious mental barriers, and now too many memories to deal with at once were jamming her brain, screaming to be dealt with.

Her body was revolting as well, with aching cramps in parts she could not properly locate, she could barely force herself to eat, even the task of crawling to the bathroom seemed too taxing at times. Day and night ran together for…well she couldn't be sure how long she'd been here, suspended between asleep and awake in an oily sweat, gnawing on her fingers and muttering like (as Severus chose to put it) a prisoner in their first night at Azkaban.

Severus steadfastly ignored her plight as if she were a house elf with a head cold. The bastard was a bloody potions master, Lourdes though mutinously. He could have eased her down but instead he dropped her and watched her writhe like a maggot. He stood over her smugly as she choked down bowls of soup, or glasses of water, probably relishing the thought that she might be sick right afterward. Every sideways glance or flick of his upper lip seemed to convey the same nasty sentiment – who’s the weak one now?


At least hating Severus was useful. It gave her something concrete to deal with, and it was rather entertaining to imagine the numerous ways in which he might be killed and humiliated for forcing her off.

When the worst of the withdrawal had ebbed away, it left only the "mortal boredom of the smoker who is cured" as that Muggle, Cocteau, put it. Time crawled by and it was everything she could do to keep herself busy, though she was so tired that all she really wanted to do was lay down and stare at the ceiling. While Severus was out doing whatever it was he did, Lourdes had spent seven restless and dusty days sprawled on the floor combing through his books, making lists for future reference on what needed to be repaired and what would need to be translated. Everything was meticulously organized and tidied despite Severus’ protests that there was indeed a system in place and she was going to spoil it. When the work around his quarters ran out, she wrote Aberforth three foot long rambling letters describing the events of her life she was now able to recall in perfect detail.

Aberforth decided to try and remedy her boredom by sending her childhood spindle, great bats of home dyed yarn, and knitting needles. So Lourdes had taken to riding out the times Severus was in his quarters by hiding in the bathroom, trying to remember what Aberforth had taught her about knitting ages ago. When she was little her mother had taught Lourdes to spin to keep her occupied on long trips. The spinning, her knowledge of goat care, and a willingness to scrub out the filthiest of tankards had gotten her the job at the Hog’s Head, and long evenings by the fire as she taught Aberforth how to transform the goats wool and he taught her how to knit it into something useful.

Albus was encouraging this venture, possibly because he saw a few pairs of socks in the deal for himself, Aberforth hadn’t knit him anything in ages. He called it “an opportunity for meditative contemplation.” She called it “bloody frustrating,” because the heels of the socks were coming out bunchy, and at points it was like wrestling with an unwieldy porcupine, but at least it was keeping her hands busy.

Right now she was sitting in the huge marble bathtub in her under-things, relishing the coolness of the stone against her skin. She’d propped a knitting manual against the long disused soap dish attempting to follow a diagram for a pair of Turkish rose pattern stockings. The situation gave her a clear view of her various scars so could Lourdes entertain herself between stitches by trying to remember where she'd gotten a particular wound. Most were merely the side effect of being in Magical Law Enforcement, others were different, distinct. Like the scars across the palms of her hands - those had been inflicted with a bit more care.

Her meeting with the Dark Lord left her with new scar where the demon wound had been, and of course the ugly skull and snake burned on her forearm. All of that was going to take some time to piece together, but she’d formulated a plan for dealing with the situation using the only logical method she knew - research and data compilation.

Just then, there was a sharp knock on the door.

"Ms Mezarci, are you decent?"

"Sure. I'm in my underwear."

"Get dressed. You're going to eat."

"Aye aye, captain," Lourdes grumbled under her breath, pretending the black wool ball was Severus’ head as she jammed the needles in to hold her place.

-***-

Lourdes shuffled out with a sullen expression on her face, wearing an obnoxious set of pajamas- bright blue flannel with a pattern of green pears. They were a gift from Aberforth upon discovering that her wardrobe wanted for proper nightwear. Apparently he still thought she was fifteen, given the all-engulfing cut and cartoonish colors. Somewhere along the line she'd industriously knit herself a little pair of lurid green mitts to match them (though why she always wore them was beyond him, his quarters weren’t that cold). The ensemble struck Severus as dishonest, the cheerful colors and patterns suggested she might be much more pleasant than she really was.

"How…charming," Severus said with a mocking sneer as she plopped into her chair and snatched up the Daily Prophet.

"Well, as off the mark as Aberforth may be on nightclothes, at least he took pains to make sure I didn't freeze to death." Lourdes turned up her nose and propped up a copy of the Daily Prophet.

"And I took pains to make sure you didn’t spend the rest of your miserable life face down in an opium den," he said lightly. It was just like Lourdes; completely ungrateful despite the obvious risk he had taken in bringing her here. Especially considering that she'd spent seven years at Hogwarts without uttering so much as a thank you to Dumbledore, whose risk had been much greater.

"Of course, because who would you have to torture if you threw me back there hmm? No students to hiss at during the summer months so something must be better than nothing. Besides, you could be genuinely evil and just trying to butter me up.”  Lourdes let out a little hiss of anger thinly disguised as a snicker. "I suppose you're angry because now you're not the imperiled spy out there suffering all on his lonesome. Honestly, if you want the credit you can have it."

"Because you are here for your fee. And I don't expect you to stick around very long once you've found a way to get your hands on it." Severus' eyes flickered up from the supply list to see Lourdes twitching and seething as she turned the pages of the Prophet.

"Well would you look at this. Podmore arrested for trying to get through a door, five whole months just for that?" She thrust the paper in front of him and drummed her fingers on the tabletop.

"You'll get more than that if we're caught," he retorted coolly. Actually Lourdes was likely to get a Dementors Kiss, if they could find anything to remove.

"If Albus doesn't come out in force for us I'll make it my mission living or dead to get back at him. I don't intend on going to prison…" Lourdes bit off the end of that sentence fiercely as if she had just exposed something. "And honestly Mr. Snape, the window of time in which you could have safely scared me out of this job has long passed. So you can stop trying to intimidate me now."

He glanced over at her again; Lourdes' head was bent over a Turkish newspaper scanning the pages for any tidbits of interest. She looked completely unconcerned with the fact that only a few weeks ago she'd made a pact with the Dark Lord and was going to be expected to contribute sooner or later...

"Have you finished the first set of the packets on Dementors?" he muttered, feeling slightly annoyed that she could be so nonchalant about the whole thing.

"No," she grunted, "I have a new project, very hush-hush."

"I don't know why you couldn't finish both; it's not as if you're wanting for leisure time."

"OH YES! It's been delightfully relaxing with the night sweats, and muscle cramps, and the vomiting! I really wish I could do it more often.” Lourdes said, in a tone thick with false cheer, wrinkling up her nose as she gave him a broad, toothy grin.

"You brought it on yourself," he replied coolly.

"I could make a case against that theory..."

"Spare me your excuses," Severus said with a dismissive wave of his hand.

"I’m really starting hate you, you know," Lourdes chirped.

"Then my work here is done.”

Suddenly, there was a loud pop and the Malfoy's old house elf appeared, under its usual mound of ratty sweaters and hats, bearing a serving tray laden with portions of roast boar with lingonberry preserves (cheeks for Severus, tenderloin for Lourdes), roasted root vegetables, goblets of mead, a pot of stewed tea and an envelope with a silver wax seal. "Here you is Mister Snape, your letter came through the Floo. Dobby found it before the other house elves could see."

It looked rather pleased with itself, and Severus merely rolled his eyes at the elf's enthusiasm. "That will be all. And remember, under no circumstances are you to mention to anyone except Dumbledore that I have a guest." Snape jerked a thumb towards Lourdes, who smiled and gave it a little fingertip wave.  The elf nodded vigorously, apparently pleased to be entrusted with such an important secret, before vanishing with another sharp pop.

"You don't think that elf could get me some decent tea do you?" Lourdes asked slyly, sawing an ungainly chunk of meat free from her tenderloin. She grumbled about how weak and bland the tea from the kitchen was compared to the tea she was accustomed to. And she'd been eyeing his personal teapot with much suspicion. Rightly so, Severus kept his own stash of unusual teas and had been hoarding them to spite her.

"It has more important things to do. After all, this building has upwards of hundred toilets. I think that chore would rank about two above fetching tea for an addict."

"You know, those elves are dead talented at cleaning up hopeless messes. Maybe you could get one of them to help you brush your teeth? You’ve got a little something…right here.”  Lourdes bared her teeth and used her finger to indicate her whole mouth.

“Ouch,” Severus muttered, looking up to give her a condescending look.

“But you’ve got to give me points for style,” she said breezily. “That letter is from Malfoy I assume? He's a little late getting back..."

He only grunted a little in reply before applying the charm needed to decode a letter from a fellow Death Eater. Lucius, for all his private brutality, had excellent manners, and that showed through in his letters, even when he was determined to undermine and insult.

-***-

Dear Severus,

I hope this letter finds you, and your new pet, in good health and spirits. As our Lord requests, I am writing to update you on several details you may have missed in your current position. Perhaps you will recall those many years ago when you brought to our Lord's attention a certain prophecy, that we now know to be incomplete. Of course no one can fault you for being so rudely ejected from a shabby establishment such as the Hogs Head, most especially before you could hear the ending of such an important piece of information.


Now our Lord is most eager to discover the ending of this particular prophecy, as it quite likely contains information that will give him the advantage in battle. While I am sure he is most pleased that you have delivered your little gift, who may prove to be exceedingly useful in the future, right now the most pressing concern is with obtaining the prophecy which has been stowed away within the Department of Mysteries at the Ministry.

As I have spent the past few years building bridges with certain influential members of our Ministry, I am afforded access to the building and its employees without suspicion. Our comrade in arms, Avery, has of late been our informant in all matters concerning the department's inner workings. His observations however, are second-hand accounts supplied to him by Augustus Rookwood.

Thus far we have only made one attempt to infiltrate this area of the ministry, and I am sad to say it was unsuccessful. If you should stumble upon any useful bits of information concerning this prophecy or any ideas for accessing it, would be most pleased to discuss them with you. I know you most of all would want to be of assistance to our Lord in this most vital hour, as your recent gift will assure your usefulness in the future.

Yours Sincerely,
Lucius Malfoy

-***-

Severus was studying the letter with a sort of distant amusement that made Lourdes extremely curious. "What is it? What's he say?"

"Nothing we don’t already know.  It seems that Malfoy doubts your value to the Dark Lord. Seems to think that Avery's half cooked theories on how to get into the Department of Mysteries are going to prove more valuable."

"Malfoy can't help if he's short sighted, can he?" Lourdes snorted.

Severus raised an eyebrow and gave her a dark look. "With talk like that Ms Mezarci, people might think you are genuinely dedicated to the Dark Lords service..."

 

“Speaking of,” Lourdes began hesitantly, “the Dark Lord’s first request has made me think I’ll need to do things I haven’t done in a very long time.  It wouldn’t hurt if I was allowed some time and space to practice like I had in school – in the forest if it can be managed.  Nobody monitors the activity there, as far as I know.”

 

“I will do what I can, Ms Mezarci, to see that you make yourself adequately prepared.  I should wonder though, why you were brought if you are so sorely out of practice…” he replied, raising an eyebrow for an expression which was both mocking and condescending.

 

“Well, you know.  In my day to day life I’ve found that there’s little need to say, summon up something eldritch, do a bit of necromancy, or set control over demons or a spirit.  Raising a corpse army though – that’s every Christmas,” she hissed, stabbing at her carrots and potatoes.

They fell back into silence, and she glanced up surreptitiously over the top of her newspaper as he began his reply. Severus Snape, she noted, was a very ugly man. And he only seemed to get uglier the more time she spent with him. Well it wasn't so much that he was actually unattractive, if he actually tried bathing and standing up straight he might have a bit of novel appeal (if you liked your men as skinny and pale as an Edgar Allen Poe character). He’d been…sort of cute at school if you discounted the terrible haircuts he had until fourth year, when he finally grew into that beak of his. No, it was all the dammed up hate, stale secrets, and the grudges he was still clinging to that made him really ugly.

Neither of them had bothered to discuss what they'd done for the past seventeen years. He was definitely eager to avoid any discussion about himself at all costs, and true to form had also completely refused to hear anything she might have to say on why she'd effectively stopped working and started cultivating an addiction.

Lourdes had begun a mental list of all his recent habits and tics to get a better idea of what he might have done in the meantime, the same sort of system she'd used when pursuing a mark. The system had never failed her before.

"Putting off your work to read fairy tales again?" he sneered, pointing to the book of South East Asian folk tales Lourdes had just opened in search of a story about a wizard named Punchkin and a witch named Bidasari she’d heard as a little girl. "Wasn't that the cause of your miserable performance in school?"

"I topped you on every essay we ever had to write,” Lourdes sneered, “and every test.”

“And yet failed every practical…” Severus replied, tapping his cheek with a finger thoughtfully.

“Practical indeed,” Lourdes snorted. “How often have you turned a pincushion into a porcupine? Besides I am not reading fairy tales Mister Snape. I am researching the historical concept of the external soul in folk literature. Albus' idea." Lourdes tore off a little piece of parchment and slipped it into the book to mark her spot before adding it to the pile next to her chair.

"Is that so? And this is more useful than patterns in Dementor behavior...how?"

"Vastly more useful. Albus has been clarifying theories about how the Dark Lord survived the killing curse, and how he might have gotten started. He gets to do the legwork, I get to do the book work," Lourdes grumbled, gnawing absentmindedly on the end of her quill.

“There’s really only one way to do that…now,” Severus said, condescendingly.

“There are more things in heaven and earth, Mister Snape, than are dreamt of in your philosophy. You’re so sure you’ve got it all figured out aren’t you? The modern way, the western way, wands and Latin?” She raised an eyebrow and propped her fist against her chin.

“Well, several centuries of blending magical traditions across the continent to discover the most effective method for channeling and enhancing inherent magical power does tend to prove its own worth,” he muttered, glancing at her, and then his wand as if there were no compariason.

Severus was right at it again, Lourdes thought smugly, it was still dead easy to wind him up.

“Oooh that’s right, magic is might, might is right. Forgot all about that. After all you are descended from the great European tradition that’s systematically managed to wipe out most diversity, inbreed to the point of evolutionary backpedaling, humiliate those who happen to be born without your specific strain of ability, enslave creatures you find threatening… did I miss anything?”

“Only the centuries of advancement and invention, discovery and…” he began.

“HA! That’s rich. If YOU lot steal it from someone else its discovery! And the rest of the world are just a whole lot of brutal savages, mucking about with our primitive ways!”

“Simply because the majority have advanced beyond bleeding and chanting…”

“Advanced at a price - watered down magic,” Lourdes spat. “Anything to get around seers, psychometrics, Evocators, or anyone else a little out of the ordinary! Puppet corpses, stones of resurrection?” She brandished a copy of an English bard’s fairy tale book at him. “Who do you reckon really came up with that?”  She jerked her head upward haughtily to stare down her nose at him.

"An allegorical figure, perhaps? Don't suppose you could call on a dead someone for the answer," Severus smirked. “Isn’t that why they brought you up here?”

"Well if you’re so clever why don’t you tear something out of the great beyond and get the answer yourself? If I had to perform a ritual to answer every one of your more difficult homework questions I'd have sacrificed enough of my own life to have been dead by the time I was twenty," Lourdes said coolly, rolling her eyes and moving on to a book of Bulgarian folk tales bristling with slips of marked paper jutting out of the pages.

"So...what did you tell him?" she asked, raising an eyebrow and pointing to the letter Severus was examining again.

"Only the usual - we appreciate his patronage, we're doing everything we can, and we’re restricted in what we can do by the position here in the school and the fact that you're supposed to be dead." He scanned the letter, ticking off points paragraph by paragraph.

"How the hell are we supposed to give him a shove in the right direction if we don't know what they've already tried to get in?” she sputtered.

"Once again Ms Mezarci, your level of social short sightedness astounds me. Lucius Malfoy does not want our help. He is merely making it explicitly clear where he sits right now, and that's higher than the two of us. I told you before, all this has very little to do with furthering the Dark Lords intentions, its about making sure you're as close to power as you can possibly get while keeping everyone else as far away as possible. Avery is a great deal easier to manipulate than I am so he is vastly more useful to Lucius. So right now we are playing a waiting game."

"And we have no idea what Avery is telling him?" Lourdes sighed.

“Unfortunately, I have no connections to Avery. A letter to him would be entirely too suspicious so I have to hope that Malfoy can be plied. Albus has taken the other Order members off shifts at the Department of Mysteries until things at the Ministry settle down a bit. After what happened to Podmore we simply cannot risk having any more members on duty until the Ministry security either increases so that we do not need to patrol or more likely, Death Eaters loose interest in patrolling the area and the Order members are less likely to be caught,” Severus muttered.

“You don’t think it’s a coincidence do you? Podmore gets caught after Malfoy…” Lourdes last words were garbled by a wide yawn as she slumped down on the table and blew at a few strands of hair stuck to her eyelashes.

“Now we know it’s not a coincidence Ms Mezarci. Few people would question Lucius to begin with, not when he’s throwing so much money at the Ministry.”

“Too right. Your ministry’s been rotting from the inside out since that blood-status-worshiping dullard took office. Closing down to cover up –“ Lourdes stopped, feeling for the second time that evening, as though she had just avoided tumbling into a spear pit.

“And how would you know that?” Severus asked sharply.

"I read the papers,” she replied.

“In any case if someone at the Ministry had suspected him I would wager he cleared that right up with a bribe. I’m sure the Ministry did everything they could to get Podmore to implicate Dumbledore though,” he sneered.

“Everything they could?” Lourdes said darkly, her fingers twitching against the table uncomfortably.


“Ms Mezarci, if Podmore holds out after that time with Dementors and is still loyal to Dumbledore he would be as forgiving as that…what was his name?” Severus’ brow furrowed as he tried to finish his metaphor.

“Job,” Lourdes finished. “And if you ask me, Job was stupid and his god was cruel.”

-***-

No good deed, it seemed, went unpunished. Severus had searched for a way to get her back OUT of his quarters once it became clear that keeping her under watch was going to be a great deal more awkward than he'd initially anticipated. If she was not in the bathroom she was content to glare at him from behind her books (and she kept leaving half finished socks in the tub).   There was something

suspicious and evasive about her retorts to his intimations about her greed.  When she had spoken to him at Grimmauld Place she'd been so evasive about what she had done for the Turkish Ministry.  There was something very off about her tone now and then, as though their conversations were interrogations and she was pulling all the strings.

He used to know everything about Lourdes, and that kind of knowledge was power.  Now, just how much he didn't know put him at a direct disadvantage.   It was as if Lourdes was proof that Severus was not to be trusted.  Not around the dark arts, and not alone in his post in the field.  The secrets she was keeping were the elephant in the room, a dangerous third presence. If he could be rid her, he could be rid that danger as well. 

He'd even tried talking to Aberforth about taking her in, and he'd been quite amiable about it until Severus had brought up his involvement in her little substance abuse problem. Aberforth had become immediately hostile and declared that he'd assist Lourdes in any way she felt necessary. Besides, Aberforth had said pointedly, the Hogs Head wasn't exactly the place you stored something that needed to be kept a secret.

Not exactly as direct as his brother, that was for sure. Severus had had almost no luck in regaining the trust of that particular member of the Dumbledore family. Especially considering Aberforth had irrationally decided to hold him responsible for Lourdes' supposed death and possibly several other murders. As for his absolute willingness to do anything she asked despite the legal consequences? Aberforth had simply snapped at him to try speaking with Lourdes about it, and promptly slammed the keg room door in his face.

To make matters much, much, worse Dumbledore had been forced to give Fudge a foothold into Hogwarts with the advent of some ridiculous educational act. And Fudge appointed a beastly little toad of a woman named Dolores Umbridge who, according to McGonagall and Flitwick, had already taken the time to corner some of her future coworkers and wring out as much information on Dumbledore's practices as possible.


Severus had been able to avoid her thus far the same way he avoided everyone in the castle he didn't wish to speak with, slipping through the dungeons and the castles little known halls. He'd given Umbridge the slip all summer long, but there had been no escaping her at the start of term. She was seated right next to him.

Unpleasant women had emerged from every crevice to assume his jobs...if Dumbledore did not think him capable of maintaining the delicate balance of allegiances alone that was fair enough. But digging up Lourdes? She had been a brutal girl, in the same way many Slytherin girls were (his mind flew immediately to the troll-like face of one Millicent Bullstrode), faster to fight with her fists than anything else. The only thing she was ever dedicated to was herself.

People like that, he knew, were very hard to trust...

Nekyia

 Thus solemn rites and holy vows we paid / To all the phantom-nations of the dead / Then died the sheep: a purple torrent flow'd / And all the caverns smoked with streaming blood /When lo! appear'd along the dusky coasts
Thin, airy shoals of visionary ghosts~ Homer, The Odyssey

 

"How very rude of you to be late," Voldemort murmured lazily, swirling long fingers over the smooth surface of his makeshift throne of glen rocks.

Severus had come a full ten minutes after the summons, dragging a woman by the arm. They were both out of breath and the woman, dressed in drab molting gray, looked as though she might drop dead on the spot. Severus genuflected automatically, but had to give a mighty tug on the woman's robes before she toppled onto her knees.

"And what have we here?" He gestured towards the panting woman, not bothering to leave his niche.

"An Evocator, my Lord." Severus seemed to have caught his breath and he kept his gaze fixed on the ground.

"For your sake, I do hope so. You know how very much I hate liars." He ambled over to Severus smoothly and took a deep breath, sniffing the air by his head and contemplating for a moment.

Not a great deal of guilt about him, but there was an uncharacteristic amount of hopeful apprehension. With a twist of his fingers, Voldemort lifted Severus into the air as easily as he would a marionette, and slipped inside his mind.

One of the more frustrating aspects of Legilimency was that one needed to be looking for something in order to find it. With a little effort he had found a dim, scratchy memory of Severus as a schoolboy - lip turned up and arms crossed stubbornly over his chest as he watched the bedraggled woman as a girl.

She crouched in the dirt, scratching circles and symbols into the ground in the Forbidden Forest. See what I can do? she hissed before stabbing the ground with a heavy foreign knife, drumming her thighs with her hands as she muttered a little charm-song, leaning in and pursing her lips as if she were about to blow the fluff off a dandelion. Something crackled and exploded in front of her, a miniature firework in a shower of silver sparks before it took shape. A minor air demon, if Voldemort recalled correctly, which hovered in form between the shape of a tiger and a wind gust.

The girl showed no fear of it, in fact she seemed to regard it as a playmate. And it reciprocated, lifting her off her feet, swirling around her as she giggled and twisted in mid-air.   Her expression when she confronted a slack jawed Severus was smug. She seemed to think of this summoning, an arcane and dangerous art for even the most practiced of wizards in any age, as a game played with all the childish abandon of blind man's buff.

There was a rush of other memories, spirits and ghosts, and something else, huge and malevolent being summoned in the damp darkness of a cellar...

"Interesting," Voldemort said appraisingly. He released Severus, who tumbled to the ground in a heap while he approached the woman.

"And what is your name?" he whispered as he leaned over her, flicking a finger to force her chin upwards. Voldemort could hear the sounds of muffled bells and charms under her traveling cloak when she arched her back.

"Lourdes Mezarci."  

She did have the eyes; the same green a Death Curse left hanging around a corpse. The rest of her was less than impressive - scarred face, missing ear, gaunt body evident in her protruding collarbone and the ribs he could see under the skin on her chest. Her mind was equally damaged, full of memories that lurched and flickered as he perused them, the smell of fire blackened flesh, the scent of blood and earth, the weight of iron all reduced to sensory snippets by some drug.

Everything he needed was right there; she was poisoned by bitterness, floating through life without aim or purpose. That aimlessness was a problem he was only too happy to remedy.

Under the damage in her mind Voldemort quickly found the connection to a sort of magic that seemed too old and primal to belong to a human frame. It was so abundant that he could see its form. It was frighteningly calm, spread like an inky black cloud with innumerable nautilus-tendrils, entirely different from the colorful clouds and sparks that indicated magic in most wizards…

And it was after him, a chilly tendril that bloomed in to his mind and floated there for a moment as if it could not decide which direction to go. The fear of it gripped him at the core, and the air of darkness and age that had entered with it made Voldemort feel as though he were a child in the orphanage again - alarmed and thrilled by the thing that was gathering within him and the promise it made.

Her magic made him a promise as well. He could have death's servant, a foul incarnation of the weakness lesser men succumbed to without a fight, under his mark...

When he could push past the black fronds that skimmed the edges of his consciousness as he ventured further, he noticed another whisper of malignant magic, appearing as a deep aubergine clot, around her heart.

"And this?" Voldemort asked, maintaining practiced indifference as he pressed his palm to the center of her chest.

"An accident." There was a sharp twist of shame in her chest that failed to show up on her cheeks.

"What sort?" he coaxed, fingers running the length of her collarbone.

"I...Severus, there was a summon, I lost control and the chthonic thing attempted to claim my heart as fee before I could exorcize it -" she gasped, lower lip vanishing between her teeth, and blood blossoming underneath them when her face twisted into a grimace. "After that all I remember is Turkey, and work there as a book dealer, and an enforcer..."

"What did you take for the pain?" He gave her a look that imitated sympathy well.

"Something to make me sleep," she said, he caught another flicker of shame on her part, and let a hateful smile creep over his face.

That made perfect sense, she had so little cunning that it was not hard to believe she'd smoked her life away while working a dead end job, petty thuggery and intimidation when she had all that power under the lock of a memory charm. What an unsuitable task for someone with so much...potential.

"Severus found me, and broke the memory charms," she added enthusiastically.

"And how is it that I am meeting this remarkable little creature just now?" Voldemort turned slowly towards Severus who did not dare look up when addressed, but there was a sly smile playing on his lips.

"Years as Head of Slytherin house afforded me many opportunities to peruse the Headmaster's office during his summer jaunts. I was only recently alerted to a file, in possession of the schools Healer of all people, which contained information about the historical practice of drawing out malignant magic from severe wounds. Ms Mezarci was, as you now know, wounded by a chthonic entity during your first rise.  She was not dead, as I thought, only patched and hidden away. Information about her treatment and current location was included in the file so I took my own jaunt to retrieve her." Severus said lightly.

Voldemort had previously been well aware of Lourdes Mezarci's presence, he'd heard the rumors about her unusual condition. Upon reflection, it seemed many of the things he could have used the first time around had been protected at the Hog's Head- that prophecy, and this particular witch, and botched by Severus. But young Lourdes had always been by the side of formidable Hogs Head barman during holidays, that or safely tucked away within Hogwarts the rest of the year…

"Your blood is pure, it must be," he said. "This condition does not occur in mongrels." He traced the script under her eyes with a fingertip, feeling her lean into the touch. The tattoos held no special magic except that which would make them impossible to remove, they were merely warnings.

"What a journey your patron has taken to bring you to me, tell me did you come willingly? Or have you been coerced?" Voldemort looked at her greedily, thinking of the things he could use her for, the fear she could instill…

"When Severus told me the great things you have done, and mean to do, I had to come," she breathed.

"You wish to belong…" Voldemort leaned in to whisper in her disfigured ear. And then, despite what must have been her very best effort, he could feel the weak heart leap in her chest.

Oh, this was very suitable indeed, talent and desperation had proven a much more reliable combination than talent and ambition. For his followers at least…

-***-

"I do." Lourdes injected those words with as much absolute devotion as she could.

Both her knees were bleeding into her robes after Severus' unnecessarily rough shove into the rocks, and her brain was swimming. Recalling every fact and snippet she'd learned about him, to put it all together with what she was seeing now. There were shadowy figures milling about behind Voldemort, the distant sound of whispers and water, vine draped trees that opened up to a black sky hung with piercingly clear, bright stars and a sickle crescent of a moon.

Severus had not lied when he said Voldemort was an incomparable Legilimens, his method was slow, gentle, and deliberate.

In his pursuit of memories he almost became part of her. He didn't stay long, he couldn't. Lourdes had felt it surging up through her blood to drive him out. Putting on the act was easy though, she'd read enough about Voldemort to know what he would want to see – pliancy, the suggestion that she could be molded and used, with no resistance returning only utmost devotion. It stung her pride to pretend to be listless, but it had to be done...
